questions.text: Identify the suturing technique in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horizontal mattress

 

MATTRESS SUTURES

 

  • Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal (image) and tend to be used to produce either eversion or inversion of a wound edge.
  • The initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle moves either horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again.
  • Such sutures are very useful in producing an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially when the edges to be anastomosed are irregular in depth or disposition.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has had abdominal pain for the past 3 days. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed and the gastric mucosa has the appearance depicted in the image shown below. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely involved in the pathogenesis to produce this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

 

  • Prostaglandins are lipid compounds that have a protective role in the gastric mucosa.
  • They help maintain the mucosal barrier and reduce gastric acid secretion.
  • In conditions where prostaglandin production is reduced, such as due to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) use, gastric mucosal damage can occur.
  • Prostaglandins themselves are essential for mucosal protection, and their deficiency can lead to erosions and ulcerations in the gastric mucosa.
  • Therefore, option B (Prostaglandin) is the most likely mediator responsible for the appearance in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferon gamma: Interferon gamma is a cytokine that plays a role in the immune response, particularly in the activation of macrophages and T cells. It is not typically associated with the direct damage to gastric mucosa, as seen in the image. Therefore, it is unlikely to be the primary mediator responsible for this appearance.

 

Option C. Complement C3b: Complement C3b is a part of the complement system, which is involved in immune responses. It plays a role in opsonization, which marks pathogens for phagocytosis. However, it is not typically associated with the direct damage to gastric mucosa, as seen in the image. Therefore, it is unlikely to be the primary mediator responsible for this appearance.

 

Option D. Interleukin-6: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that can be released during an inflammatory response. Elevated levels of IL-6 are associated with various inflammatory conditions. While IL-6 may contribute to inflammation, it is not primarily responsible for the mucosal damage depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prostaglandins play a crucial role in maintaining the protective mucosal barrier in the stomach.
  • Deficiency of prostaglandins, often due to NSAID use, can lead to gastric mucosal damage, including erosions and ulcerations.
  • Understanding the role of prostaglandins in gastric mucosal protection is important for diagnosing and managing conditions related to gastric mucosal damage.

choices.text: Gestational trophoblastic disease
Primary ovarian insufficiency

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of absent menses. The patient had a vaginal delivery 4 months ago and has not yet had a menstrual period. Her postpartum course was complicated by a retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage that required a blood transfusion and emergency suction and sharp curettage. At her postpartum visit 2 months ago, the patient was given a prescription for combination oral contraceptive pills; she has had no vaginal bleeding or spotting during her week of placebo pills. Prior to this pregnancy, she had regular monthly menstrual cycles with 34 days of moderate bleeding. The patient has had increased fatigue since returning to work. The patient had no headaches, galactorrhea, or hot flashes. Vital signs are normal. BMI is 31 kg/m². Pelvic examination shows clear vaginal discharge throughout the vault and a well-rugated vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted, and both ovaries are small and non-tender. Urine pregnancy test is negative. FSH and TSH levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asherman syndrome

 

  • Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions or scarring that can occur after uterine surgery, such as dilation and curettage, particularly when it follows a pregnancy or delivery.
  • These adhesions can lead to menstrual irregularities, including absent menses (amenorrhea), due to the scarring obstructing the passage of blood from the uterus, as well as potential infertility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Gestational trophoblastic disease. This condition involves abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue, which can occur after any type of pregnancy. While it can cause abnormal bleeding or elevated hCG levels, the patient's negative pregnancy test and history point more towards Asherman syndrome.

 

Option C) Postpartum thyroiditis. This condition can cause transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism, which might affect menstrual cycles. However, the patient's normal TSH levels and the specific history related to uterine interventions make Asherman syndrome a more likely cause.

 

Option D) Primary ovarian insufficiency. This condition involves premature loss of ovarian function before the age of 40 and is characterized by high FSH levels, which are not reported in this patient. Additionally, her history of uterine surgery postpartum is a more direct cause of her current symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize Asherman syndrome as a potential complication following uterine surgery, especially after procedures like dilation and curettage that are performed in the context of retained placenta and postpartum hemorrhage. Asherman syndrome can lead to amenorrhea and infertility due to intrauterine adhesions that form as a result of the surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of heartburn and black, tarry stools. He states that he has been eating much less than usual, although he still manages to drink at least one beer per day, which he reports having done for the past 20 years. On physical examination, the patient exhibits diffuse tenderness and guarding over the entire epigastric area. Serum levels of which of the following substances are likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrin

 

  • This hormone stimulates the stomach's parietal cells to secrete gastric acid.
  • Elevated gastrin levels can be seen in conditions that increase gastric acid secretion, such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (a gastrin-secreting tumor), or in response to chronic inflammation of the stomach lining.
  • Gastrin levels can be elevated in peptic ulcer disease, especially in the presence of Helicobacter pylori infection, which can cause increased gastrin secretion as part of the disease process.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cholecystokinin. This hormone is primarily involved in digestion and is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of fats and proteins. It stimulates the gallbladder to contract and release bile into the intestine and the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes. It is not typically associated with the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease or with the symptoms described.

 

Option C) Intrinsic factor. This is a protein secreted by cells in the stomach that is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine. Intrinsic factor levels are not directly related to peptic ulcer disease or the symptoms described.

 

Option D) Secretin. This hormone is produced by the small intestine in response to the presence of acidic gastric contents in the small intestine. It stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate to neutralize the acid, but it is not directly involved in the pathology of peptic ulcer disease or associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the role of gastrin in the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion, which can contribute to the development of peptic ulcers, especially in the presence of risk factors such as chronic alcohol consumption. Recognizing the clinical presentation of peptic ulcer disease and understanding the underlying physiological mechanisms are crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to an urgent care centre by his parents due to a rash. The patient awoke yesterday with a rash on his trunk, but his mother says that "it now seems particularly red in his underarms and private area". Over the last 2 days, he has also had headache, fever, and sore throat. He has no allergies, and his immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 38.3⁰C (101⁰F), blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is tired-appearing but playful and in no acute distress. Examination reveals a fine, erythematous, papular rash with a rough texture on the anterior trunk. The rash appears more concentrated in the axillae and groin and blanches with pressure. Tender, shotty, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present, and the posterior oropharynx is erythematous with tonsillar exudates and soft palatal petechiae. The father adds, "Two kids in his class had the same symptoms, and now their skin is peeling". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scarlet fever

 

 

  • Scarlet fever is an illness caused by group A Streptococcus that develops most commonly in children who have streptococcal pharyngitis. 
  • Certain strains of Streptococcus pyogenes produce erythrogenic exotoxins, which are responsible for the characteristic rash of scarlet fever.
  • Fever, sore throat, and headache typically precede the rash, which usually spreads across the trunk, groin, and axillae. 
  • The exanthem has a characteristic, finely papular, "sandpaper" texture and is most pronounced in the skin folds. 
  • As the illness resolves, desquamation of the rash results in skin peeling.
  • An erythematous pharynx with tonsillar exudates, palatal petechiae, and a strawberry tongue are classic findings on examination. 
  • The area around the mouth may appear pale in comparison with the red cheeks, giving the appearance of circumoral pallor. 
  • Tender, shotty (i.e., multiple and small), anterior cervical lymph nodes, as seen in this patient, is another non-specific finding.
  • Scarlet fever is managed in the same way as streptococcal pharyngitis. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by rapid streptococcal antigen test or throat culture, and treatment is done with penicillin. 
  • No additional therapy is required for the rash.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by exfoliative strains of Staphylococcus aureus and presents with superficial, flaccid bullae followed by extensive exfoliation of the skin. It is most common in infancy and rarely occurs beyond age 5.

 

Option C) Kawasaki disease. Diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires 5 days of fever and ≥4 clinical criteria: >1.5 cm cervical node, polymorphous rash, edema of the hands/feet, conjunctivitis, and mucosal changes (e.g., strawberry tongue, dry/cracked lips). Kawasaki disease is unlikely in this patient with only 2 days of fever and 2 of the listed criteria.

 

Option D) Mononucleosis can present with exudative pharyngitis and a rash; however, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is typical.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Scarlet fever is caused by group A Streptococcus (S pyogenes) and presents with fever, pharyngitis, circumoral pallor, strawberry tongue, and rash. 
  • The classic "sandpaper" rash is prominent along skin folds (e.g., axillae, groin) and often results in desquamation.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic because he has been pulling on his ears. Two weeks ago, the patient was taken to an urgent care centre for fever and irritability and was found to have acute otitis media of the right ear. He completed the prescribed course of amoxicillin, with resolution of symptoms. However, for the past few days, the patient has been tugging at both of his ears, and his parents are concerned that he may have another ear infection. Temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.2⁰F). On otoscopic examination, air-fluid levels are visible posterior to both tympanic membranes, which appear translucent and gray. Pneumatic insufflation demonstrates reduced mobility of tympanic membranes bilaterally. Both external ear canals are clear. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Observation and follow up

 

  • This patient has otitis media with effusion (OME), defined by middle ear fluid without tympanic membrane (TM) inflammation (e.g., bulging, erythema). 
  • Young children, particularly of age 6-24 months, are predisposed to fluid accumulation within the middle ear due to narrow, straight eustachian tubes that drain poorly. 
  • Most effusions develop in the setting of a viral infection or following an episode of acute otitis media.
  • OME is typically asymptomatic but may cause mild discomfort (e.g., ear tugging and pulling, as seen in this patient) due to pressure on the TM. 
  • Because the effusion limits TM vibration, conductive hearing loss is also common. 
  • OME does not cause fever or severe ear pain. 
  • Physical examination reveals air-fluid levels posterior to the TM and poor TM mobility on pneumatic insufflation. 
  • In contrast to acute otitis media, the effusion in OME is non-purulent, and the TM is not bulging or erythematous.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Additional antibiotic course. Patients with persistent or recurrent acute otitis media have TM bulging with middle ear effusion and are treated with an additional antibiotic course. This child has no signs of TM inflammation and therefore, does not have acute otitis media.

 

Options B and C) Glucocorticoid therapy and Intranasal decongestant. Intranasal glucocorticoids and/or decongestants do not decrease the duration of OME and are therefore, not indicated. Although oral glucocorticoids are associated with shorter OME duration, they are also not recommended because rates of speech delay and long-term hearing loss are unchanged.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Otitis media with effusion (OME) is defined by middle ear fluid without tympanic membrane (TM) inflammation (e.g., bulging, erythema). 
  • Examination shows air-fluid levels and poor TM mobility. 
  • Management is observation with follow-up for resolution because chronic OME is associated with speech delay and long-term hearing loss.

choices.text: Slit skin smear
Potassium hydroxide mount (KOH)

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of itching over scalp. On examination, a patch of hair loss, with redness is noted as shown in the image below. Which of the following investigations would help to diagnose the most probable diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Potassium hydroxide mount (KOH)

 

TINEA CAPITIS

 

  • If a child presents with complaints of hair loss and itching, the most likely diagnosis based on these clinical findings is tinea capitis.
  • KOH is the test useful to confirm the diagnosis in this case scenario.
  • It is a simple and quick test that helps to diagnose fungal infections of the skin, nails and hair, which are a common cause of itchy scalp and hair loss in children.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Scalp biopsy. It is a more invasive test that's used for complex cases where the diagnosis is not clear. It's not usually the first step.

 

Option B) Gram stain. It is used to identify bacterial infections, which are less likely the cause of itchy, red bald patches.

 

Option C) Slit skin smears are used for certain skin infections, like leprosy, which do not typically present as an itchy, red bald patch on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a child with an itchy scalp and a patch of hair loss, a KOH mount of the scalp can help diagnose a fungal infection, often the most likely cause.
  • This test is simple, quick, and a good first step in such cases.

 

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 32.39; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1339

questions.text: In a dramatic turn of events at a large industrial plant, a worker is found lying motionless near a high-voltage electrical panel. The emergency response team rushes to the scene, where they find no visible injuries but the worker is unresponsive and without apparent signs of life. Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in a state of suspended animation, where the victim might appear lifeless but is still alive?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electrocution

 

Explanation

 

Suspended animation is when an organism’s bodily functions, like breathing and heartbeat, are drastically slowed down or paused as seen in electrocution.

 

Suspended animation

 

Suspended animation is a condition in which vital signs of life (heart beat and respiration) are not detected by routine clinical methods, as the functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum.

 

Mechanism: The metabolic rate is greatly reduced so that the requirement of the individual cell for oxygen is satisfied through the dissolved oxygen in body fluids

 

Other options

 

B. Strangulation/ hangingC. Firearm injury and D. Burn: suspended animation is not usually seen in these conditions.

 

Educational Objective

 

Suspended animation is found in following conditions:

 

 1) After Anaesthesia 

 2) New Born, Barbiturate poisoning

3) Cholera, Coma, Cerebral Concussion                                   

 4) Drowning 

5) Electrocution 

6) Frozen state (Hypothermia)

6) Sunstroke, Shock, InSanity

7) Yoga practitioners

questions.text: A 5-year-old, previously healthy girl is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy and altered mental status. The patient was in her usual state of health until 5 days ago, when she developed fever, malaise, headache, cough, and nasal discharge. The fever resolved with over-the-counter medications, and the patient was feeling better until this morning, when she developed nausea, vomiting, and lethargy. She has no chronic medical conditions and takes no prescription medications. Temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.2⁰F), blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min. The patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Hepatomegaly is present; there is no splenomegaly. CT scan of the head reveals diffuse cerebral edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's imaging findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperammonemia

 

  • This patient has acutely altered mental status and cerebral edema on CT scan findings, concerning for toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. 
  • The potential underlying etiologies are vast and are characterized by brain dysfunction in the absence of primary CNS disease (e.g., infection, tumor). 
  • In this case, the patient's recent upper respiratory infection treated with over-the-counter medications, hepatomegaly, and rapid progression make Reye syndrome most likely.
  • Reye syndrome is a rare but potentially fatal condition that occurs in children who were given salicylates (e.g., aspirin) for a viral illness (e.g., influenza, varicella). 
  • The pathophysiology likely involves mitochondrial dysfunction from aspirin, which leads to impaired fatty acid metabolism and acute hepatic steatosis, as seen by this patient's hepatomegaly. 
  • With declining liver function, excess ammonia (i.e., neurotoxin) accumulates and causes cerebral edema and encephalopathy (i.e., altered mental status). 
  • Initial symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., vomiting, lethargy) can rapidly progress to seizures, coma, and death.
  • Liver biopsy showing micro-vesicular steatosis in the context of acute toxic-metabolic encephalopathy is consistent with Reye syndrome but is not required for the diagnosis. 
  • Treatment is supportive, and parents should be reminded that aspirin is contraindicated in children except in the management of Kawasaki disease and rheumatologic diseases (e.g., juvenile idiopathic arthritis).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Adrenal insufficiency. Adrenal crisis can be precipitated by infection and cause hypotension, vomiting, and acute mental status changes. However, cerebral dysfunction is due to poor perfusion, not cerebral edema, from lack of cortisol. This patient's hepatomegaly, cerebral edema, and normal blood pressure make adrenal insufficiency unlikely.

 

Option C) Hypoglycemia, which can cause confusion and lethargy, may occur in Reye syndrome from decreased hepatic production of glucose but does not cause cerebral edema. Cerebral edema can be caused by hyperglycemia (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis), but this metabolic derangement is not seen in Reye syndrome.

 

Option D) Hypothyroidism. Severe hypothyroidism (myxedema coma) can present with lethargy and disorientation, but hypothermia and bradycardia would also be present. In addition, hypothyroidism does not cause hepatomegaly or cerebral edema.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Reye syndrome is a rare toxic-metabolic encephalopathy in children who have taken aspirin for a viral illness. 
  • Liver failure (microvesicular hepatic steatosis) leads to hyperammonemia, cerebral edema, and encephalopathy (i.e., altered mental status).

questions.text: In the management of a treatment-experienced HIV-infected patient with multidrug-resistant HIV-1, which specific antiretroviral drug combination, including cobicistat, is recommended to achieve optimal viral suppression while minimizing potential drug interactions and side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Darunavir

 

  • Darunavir is a protease inhibitor commonly used in combination with cobicistat (a pharmacokinetic enhancer) to boost its effectiveness.
  • This combination can be particularly effective in patients with multidrug-resistant HIV-1, as it enhances the drug's potency while minimizing side effects and drug interactions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Indinavir.

 

    •  
  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS.
  • Mechanism of Action: It inhibits the protease enzyme, preventing the cleavage of viral polyproteins and the formation of mature infectious virus particles.

 

Option C) Ritonavir.

 

    •  
  • Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor used primarily as a pharmacokinetic enhancer in HIV therapy.
  • Mechanism of Action: Ritonavir inhibits the metabolism of other protease inhibitors, increasing their plasma levels and duration of action.

 

Option D) Saquinavir.

 

    •  
  • Saquinavir is another protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS.
  • Mechanism of Action: It, too, inhibits the protease enzyme, preventing viral replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to familiarize individuals with different antiretroviral drugs used in the management of HIV/AIDS, particularly their mechanisms of action. Understanding these mechanisms is essential for healthcare professionals to make informed decisions about drug combinations and regimens for HIV-infected patients.

choices.text: Tumor cells are strongly estrogen receptor positive
No metastases in the sampled lymph nodes
Flow cytometric analysis with aneuploidy and a high S-phase
One relative who had a similar type of breast cancer

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman notes a lump in her left breast while taking a shower. The nurse practitioner palpates a 3 cm firm, irregular, non-movable mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast on physical examination. A fine needle aspiration of this mass is performed, and cytologically the cells are consistent with infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The mass is removed with lumpectomy along with an axillary sentinel lymph node sampling. Which of the following findings will best predict a better prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) No metastases in the sampled lymph nodes

 

  •  
  • The absence of metastases in the axillary sentinel lymph nodes is a strong predictor of a better prognosis.
  • Lymph node involvement is a critical factor in determining the stage and prognosis of breast cancer.
  • The absence of lymph node metastases suggests that the cancer has not yet spread to distant sites, indicating a lower stage and a more favorable prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Tumor cells are strongly estrogen receptor positive.

 

  •  
  • Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity is an important prognostic factor in breast cancer.
  • Tumors that are strongly estrogen receptor positive tend to respond well to hormonal therapy, such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.
  • ER-positive tumors are associated with a relatively better prognosis compared to ER-negative tumors.
  • Hormone receptor-positive breast cancers tend to grow more slowly and have a lower risk of recurrence.

 

Option C) Flow cytometric analysis with aneuploidy and a high S-phase.

 

  •  
  • Flow cytometric analysis with aneuploidy and a high S-phase suggests a more aggressive tumor phenotype.
  • Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes, and a high S-phase indicates a high rate of cell proliferation.
  • These features are associated with a worse prognosis, as aggressive tumor characteristics often indicate a higher risk of recurrence and a poorer response to treatment.

 

Option D) One relative who had a similar type of breast cancer.

 

  •  
  • While having a family history of breast cancer is an important consideration for assessing risk and may prompt genetic counselling and testing, it is not a direct predictor of the patient's prognosis.
  • Family history can influence the patient's overall risk of developing breast cancer but does not specifically predict the prognosis of an individual case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity is an important prognostic factor in breast cancer, with strongly ER-positive tumors associated with a better prognosis.
  • The absence of lymph node metastases is a strong predictor of a better prognosis in breast cancer, indicating a lower stage and a lower risk of recurrence.
  • Certain tumor characteristics, such as aneuploidy and high proliferation rate, are associated with a worse prognosis.
  • Family history of breast cancer influences overall risk but does not directly predict an individual's prognosis.

choices.text: Metastatic disease affecting the lung

questions.text: A 64-year-old smoker visits his primary care physician because of recent weight gain and worsening coughs. On physical examination, the physician notes that the patient’s extremities are thinner than before, while his waist is increased in girth. The patient also has a pad of adipose tissue at the base of his neck and purple striae on his abdomen. The physician decides to run some blood tests and obtain an x-ray of the chest, which shows a central lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small cell carcinoma

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's presentation.
  • Small cell lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking and is well known for producing paraneoplastic syndromes, including ectopic ACTH production leading to Cushing's syndrome, which explains the patient's cushingoid features and central obesity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Adenocarcinoma. This is the most common type of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers, but it typically presents peripherally in the lungs and is less likely than small cell carcinoma to produce paraneoplastic syndromes like ectopic ACTH production.

 

Option B) Bronchial carcinoid. Carcinoid tumors can cause paraneoplastic syndromes, but they more commonly produce symptoms related to serotonin secretion (carcinoid syndrome), such as flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing, rather than Cushing's syndrome.

 

Option C) Metastatic disease affecting the lung. While metastatic disease can involve the lung and cause various symptoms, the specific combination of symptoms described is more characteristic of a primary lung tumor producing a paraneoplastic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features of paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer, particularly small cell lung cancer. Small cell lung cancer can produce ectopic ACTH, leading to Cushing's syndrome, characterized by weight gain, fat redistribution, muscle wasting, and skin changes. Identifying these signs and symptoms in the context of lung cancer can aid in the diagnosis and prompt further investigation for appropriate management.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a 2-year history of infertility presents to her gynecologist for a follow-up visit. She has been diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) based on oligomenorrhea, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no significant family history of metabolic or reproductive disorders. Her BMI is 32 kg/m². She has been on clomiphene citrate for the last 3 months without achieving ovulation. Her fasting glucose and insulin levels suggest insulin resistance. The patient is eager to conceive and inquires about additional treatments that could improve her response to clomiphene. Which of the following medications can be added to improve the clomiphene response in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metformin

 

  • Many women with PCOS also have insulin resistance.
  • Insulin resistance leads to compensatory hyperinsulinemia and dyslipidemia.
  • Interventions that reduce circulating insulin levels in women with PCOS may restore normal reproductive endocrine function.
  • Insulin-sensitizing agents like Metformin help in the treatment of PCOS.
  • Metformin administered to women with PCOS, increased the frequency of spontaneous ovulation, menstrual cyclicity, and ovulatory response to Clomiphene citrate

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin administered to women with PCOS, increased the frequency of spontaneous ovulation, menstrual cyclicity, and ovulatory response to Clomiphene citrate.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Biopsy of the nasal septum
﻿﻿﻿Complete blood count and coagulation panel
Nasal corticosteroid sprays

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent epistaxis. Every morning, the patient wakes up with significant nasal congestion; when he blows his nose, he often sees crusting and blood clots in the tissue. Afterward, his nose frequently (several times a week) starts bleeding. It stops within 5 minutes of pinching his nasal alae. Medical history includes obesity, hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the nose has bilateral crusting with excoriations on both sides of the nasal septum, but there is no bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CPAP humidification

 

  • This patient's nasal crusting and recurrent epistaxis are likely related to his use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
  • After beginning CPAP, many patients develop new nasal symptoms, including dryness, obstruction, and epistaxis due to mucosal damage caused by the cold, dry, pressurized air.
  • On examination, the nasal mucosa appears dry and erythematous with significant crusting.
  • Nasal symptoms often improve significantly with warming and humidification of the air through the CPAP machine.
  • Nasal saline irrigation is recommended to moisturize the nasal mucosa and assist with clearing of dry secretions.
  • Patients may also apply a lubricating jelly (e.g., saline gel, petroleum) to the anterior septum.
  • However, improvement in nasal symptoms does not appear to increase compliance with CPAP therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Biopsy of nasal septum. Excoriations and crusting sometimes represent malignancy, which can present with recurrent epistaxis and may require biopsy for diagnosis. This patient has no focal lesion, and exposure to dry air from the use of CPAP is a much more likely reason for his symptoms.

 

Option B) Complete blood count and coagulation panel. A complete blood count is ordered in cases of severe epistaxis that may require transfusion, but that is not needed in this patient. Coagulation studies are required in patients who are receiving anticoagulation medication or who have recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis. This patient has an obvious cause of epistaxis (СРАР).

 

Option D) Nasal corticosteroid sprays. Although corticosteroid nasal sprays are effective in the treatment of allergic rhinitis, they have no effect on nasal symptoms induced by CPAP use. In addition, corticosteroids may cause thinning, dryness, and/or damage of the nasal septum, further contributing to epistaxis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) predisposes users to recurrent epistaxis because of its drying effect on the nasal mucosa. Humidification is often effective in preventing CPAP-associated epistaxis.

choices.text: Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby
Perform serum VDRL of the baby
Perform CSF VDRL of the baby

questions.text: A 29-years-old pregnant female's routine investigations showed VDRL positive with 1:16 titres. TPHA was also positive. The pregnant female was adequately treated with injection benzathine penicillin. What is the next step of management for the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

 

  • Since the mother had a positive VDRL and TPHA, indicating syphilis, the baby must be tested after birth to rule out congenital syphilis.
  • The serum VDRL is a standard test to screen for syphilis in the newborn.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby. Prophylactic treatment with penicillin is not recommended without evidence of congenital syphilis. The baby should be tested first before any treatment is given.

 

Option C) Perform CSF VDRL of the baby. A CSF VDRL test is used to diagnose neurosyphilis. This would only be necessary if the baby's serum VDRL is positive or if there are clinical signs suggesting neurosyphilis.

 

Option D) Wait and Watch. It is not appropriate to simply observe the baby without testing, given the risk of congenital syphilis. Early diagnosis and treatment, if necessary, are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to screen a newborn for congenital syphilis when the mother has a history of the infection, which is done by performing a serum VDRL test.
  • It's critical for medical students to understand the importance of screening and the potential implications of congenital syphilis for appropriate clinical management.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no. 297

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.34

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1459

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of occasional episodes of chest tightness, wheezing, and cough. The symptoms are often mild and resolve spontaneously. He has been healthy otherwise. His respiration rate is 13/min. The lungs are clear on auscultation. Cardiac examination and chest x-ray show no abnormalities. Which of the following agents is most appropriate to treat acute episodes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Salbutamol

 

  • Salbutamol is a short-acting β2-adrenergic receptor agonist that causes bronchodilation by relaxing the smooth muscles in the airways.
  • It is commonly used as a first-line agent for the quick relief of acute asthma symptoms.
  • Given the patient's need for immediate relief during episodes, salbutamol is the most appropriate choice for treating acute episodes.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Beclomethasone. Beclomethasone is an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) used for long-term control of chronic asthma to reduce inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the airways. While very effective for managing persistent asthma, it is not appropriate for immediate relief of acute symptoms.

 

Option C) Cromolyn. Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer used as a prophylactic treatment to prevent allergic reactions and asthma symptoms. It is not effective for the treatment of acute asthma symptoms and is less commonly used in current asthma management compared to other long-term control medications.

 

Option D) Ipratropium. Ipratropium is a short-acting anticholinergic agent that causes bronchodilation by blocking muscarinic receptors in the airways. While it can be used in the management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and as an adjunct in asthma, it is generally not the first choice for acute asthma symptoms, especially in patients who are likely to respond well to β2-adrenergic agonists like albuterol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the pharmacological management of acute asthma episodes. The primary goal in an acute asthma attack is the rapid reversal of airway constriction, for which short-acting β2-adrenergic agonists like salbutamol are most effective. Other medications, such as inhaled corticosteroids and mast cell stabilizers, are crucial in the long-term management of asthma to reduce chronic inflammation and prevent future attacks but are not appropriate for immediate relief of acute symptoms. Anticholinergics like ipratropium can be used in certain cases but are generally less effective than β2-agonists for acute asthma symptoms.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband due to anxiety. The patient had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery a week ago and was discharged on postpartum day 2. Her husband notes that she was "really nervous" after returning home. The patient would watch the infant overnight to check for respirations and followed a strict feeding regimen. At the first well-child visit, she expressed concerns about the newborn's weight but was told he had surpassed his birth weight and was healthy and doing well. Despite this reassurance, the patient has continued to worry. For the past 2 days, she has been pacing around the house, sleeping poorly, and eating minimally. This morning, the husband found the patient mixing protein powder with formula due to concern that the infant was "shrinking." The patient says, "I know my baby is sick, but the doctors won't tell me the truth. They're trying to hurt my baby." She has no psychiatric history. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. The patient appears tearful and exhausted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Postpartum psychosis

 

  • This patient's acute onset of agitation, mood symptoms, and delusions shortly after giving birth is consistent with postpartum psychosis, a relatively rare condition (1-2 of every 1,000 births) that generally occurs within the first 2 weeks after delivery.
  • Clinical features include depressed and/or manic moods, severe insomnia, agitation, disorganized behaviour, and delusions and/or hallucinations, with content frequently related to the infant (e.g., this patient's delusions that the infant is "shrinking" and that doctors are trying to hurt her baby).
  • Postpartum psychosis is a medical emergency because affected patients, under the influence of delusions, may harm the child and are also at high risk for suicide.
  • Hospitalization to ensure safety and rapid intervention with antipsychotic medication are often necessary.
  • Postpartum psychosis is most often seen in patients who have a history of bipolar disorder or who are later diagnosed with bipolar disorder based on mood episodes occurring outside the postpartum period.
  • These patients are at especially high risk for recurrent episodes in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Adjustment disorder with anxiety. Adjustment disorder is diagnosed when non-psychotic symptoms (e.g., depressed, anxious mood) develop within 3 months of a stressor. Although this patient has severe anxiety related to her newborn's health, adjustment disorder would not explain her psychosis.

 

Option B) Delusional disorder. A diagnosis of delusional disorder requires delusions lasting ≥1 month in the absence of other psychotic or mood symptoms. It is not consistent with this patient's 1-week history of symptoms characterized by delusions and prominent mood symptoms.

 

Option D) Postpartum blues is a common, self-limited condition of mild depressive symptoms, tearfulness, and irritability. It typically peaks at day 5 postpartum and resolves within 14 days. It does not include psychotic symptoms.

 

Educational objective:

 

Postpartum psychosis is characterized by an acute onset of delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behaviour within the first 2 weeks postpartum. It is typically accompanied by mood symptoms, agitation, and severe insomnia.

questions.text: You notice the below shown instrument being used in the gynecology OT. Which surgery would this instrument be used in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Total laparoscopic hysterectomy

 

  • This is a uterine manipulator.
  • Uterine manipulator is used to assist movements of the uterus in laparoscopic surgeries, particularly in laparoscopic hysterectomies.
  • They are beneficial in improving visualization and providing a landmark for the colpotomy during hysterectomy.
  • They also help in other laparoscopic surgeries as they can manipulate the uterus and assist the surgeon during different laparoscopic pelvic surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • This is a uterine manipulator
  • Uterine manipulator is used to assist movements of the uterus in laparoscopic surgeries, particularly in laparoscopic hysterectomies.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and multiple transient ischemic attacks presents to the emergency department after two hours of left-sided weakness in his upper extremity and face. After a CT of the head shows no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, a fibrinolytic enzyme is administered. Two hours later, the man develops bleeding from his gums as well as several large subcutaneous ecchymoses. Which of the following drugs could stop this man’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminocaproic acid

 

  • This is an anti-fibrinolytic agent that inhibits plasminogen activation, thereby preventing the breakdown of fibrin clots.
  • It is used to treat or prevent excessive bleeding in conditions where fibrinolysis contributes to the bleeding, such as in the case of fibrinolytic therapy.
  • Aminocaproic acid would be the appropriate choice to counteract the effects of fibrinolytic therapy and stop the bleeding.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Protamine sulfate. This drug is used to reverse the effects of heparin, an anticoagulant. It binds to heparin, neutralizing its anticoagulant effects. Protamine sulfate is not used to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic agents and would not be appropriate in this case.

 

Option C) Recombinant factor VIII. This is used in the treatment of hemophilia A, a genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in factor VIII, leading to prolonged bleeding. It would not be effective in stopping bleeding due to fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option D) Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). This is the fibrinolytic enzyme likely administered to the patient to treat the ischemic stroke. Administering more tPA would exacerbate the bleeding, not stop it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the management of bleeding complications associated with fibrinolytic therapy. Aminocaproic acid is an anti-fibrinolytic agent that can be used to counteract the effects of fibrinolytic drugs and stop bleeding by inhibiting plasminogen activation and the subsequent breakdown of fibrin clots. Recognizing the appropriate use of anti-fibrinolytic agents in the context of bleeding due to fibrinolytic therapy is crucial for patient safety and effective treatment.

choices.text: Escherichia coli count of <103 colony-forming units per millilitre (CFU/mL)
An average of 1 pus cell per high power field (HPF)
The presence of one rod-shaped bacterium per high power field

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of high fever, a burning sensation during urination, and lower abdominal pain. She has no significant past medical history and reports no recent sexual activity. A diagnosis of uncomplicated acute cystitis is made based on her clinical presentation and initial urinalysis results. Which of the following urinalysis findings is inconsistent with a typical diagnosis of uncomplicated acute cystitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Escherichia coli count of <103 colony-forming units per millilitre (CFU/mL)

 

  • In the diagnosis of urinary tract infections (UTIs) including uncomplicated acute cystitis, typically an E. coli count of ≥105 CFU/mL is considered diagnostic. 
  • However, counts of ≥102 CFU/mL may be significant in symptomatic women.
  • A count of <103 CFU/mL is lower than the standard threshold for diagnosis and may not be consistent with an active infection, making this statement incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) An average of 1 pus cell per high power field (HPF). This is consistent with infection, although the pus cell count is usually higher in UTIs.

 

Option C) The presence of one rod-shaped bacterium per high power field. This could represent E. coli, which is the most common pathogen in acute cystitis.

 

Option D. Positive urine nitrite test. This indicates the presence of nitrate-reducing bacteria, such as E. coli, and is consistent with a UTI diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The uncomplicated acute cystitis, an E. coli count of ≥105 CFU/mL is considered diagnostic.

choices.text: Increase in Renal Blood Flow
Decrease in Colloid Osmotic Pressure
Increase in Filtration Fraction
Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of extreme stress and anxiety. He reports a recent traumatic event and is experiencing a "fight or flight" response. Which of the following statements regarding the effect of strong sympathetic activation on the kidneys is most accurate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decrease in Glomerular Filtration Rate

 

  • Strong sympathetic activation causes the afferent arterioles of the glomerulus to constrict.
  • This constriction reduces the flow of blood into the glomerulus and, consequently, decreases the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • Less blood is filtered by the glomerulus, which is an important function of the kidneys when sympathetic activation is high.
  • Therefore, option D is correct.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Increase in renal blood flow. Strong sympathetic activation, as part of the body's "Fight or Flight" response, results in the constriction of renal arterioles. This constriction reduces the flow of blood into the kidneys because the body redirects blood flow away from non-essential functions like kidney filtration to prioritize other vital organs during a stressful situation. Therefore, renal blood flow decreases, making option A) incorrect.

 

Option B) Decrease in Colloid Osmotic Pressure. Colloid osmotic pressure is primarily determined by the concentration of proteins (colloids) in the blood. Sympathetic activation may affect blood vessel constriction and blood pressure, but it doesn't directly influence colloid osmotic pressure. Therefore, option B) is incorrect.

 

Option C) Increase in Filtration Fraction. Filtration fraction is the ratio of Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) to Renal Plasma Flow (RPF). Strong sympathetic activation typically does not lead to a significant increase in filtration fraction. Instead, it reduces GFR by constricting afferent arterioles, which decreases the flow of blood into the glomerulus. Therefore, option C) is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the physiological response of the kidneys to strong sympathetic activation and how it can impact renal function.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, page no. 498

questions.text: Moynihan’s hump is an anatomical variation with respect to which of the below structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right hepatic artery

 

  • The right hepatic artery can be tortuous (caterpillar turn/Moynihan’s hump) and may lie very close to the gall bladder and the cystic duct before giving off a short cystic artery.

 

 

(b) Tortuous CHA and (c) Tortuous RHA are examples of the ‘caterpillar turn’ or ‘Moynihan’s hump’, which can lead to inadvertent arterial injury or bleeding during cholecystectomy.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Edition, Page no. 1233

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with fragile skin, arrives at the Dermatology OPD. On examination, it was observed that he has bullae which are healing with scarring, and erosions on the extensor surfaces of his elbows, hands, and knees. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy findings revealed antibodies against type VII collagen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

 

  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy showing antibodies against type VII collagen is suggestive of Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA).

 

 

Image depicting structure of DEJ/BMZ

 

 

 

  • Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA) is an acquired autoimmune disorder, presenting in adults between 44-54 years.
  • It has a chronic, relapsing course.
  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy is positive due to the presence of antibodies against type VII collagen.
  • DIF is negative in the below given Genetic conditions, as there are NO antibodies in these diseases.

 

 

EB = Epidermolysis Bullosa

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Epidermolysis bullosa simplex. It is a condition characterized by skin fragility and blistering, but it is due to mutations affecting keratins in the epidermis, not autoantibodies against type VII collagen.

 

Option C) Hailey-Hailey disease also known as familial benign pemphigus. It is a genetic disorder that results in a blistering skin condition but does not involve autoantibodies against type VII collagen.

 

Option D) Darier's disease. It is a genetic disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques, particularly in seborrheic areas, not by bullae that heal with scarring, and it is not associated with antibodies against type VII collagen.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with fragile skin, scarring bullae on extensor surfaces, and DIF findings showing antibodies against type VII collagen, the most likely diagnosis is Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 50, page no. 50.41

choices.text: Diffuse 3-Hz spike and wave discharges on electroencephalogram
Generalized slowing and periodic sharp wave complexes on electroencephalogram
Low concentration of hypocretin (orexin) in the Cerebrospinal fluid
Low concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in the cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in her apartment by her roommate. First responders found empty bottles of acetaminophen and clonazepam as well as a note on the floor beside the patient. The patient had been increasingly isolative in recent months and hired a lawyer to help write a will last week. She has a long history of episodic sadness and despair dating back to her adolescence. During these periods of sadness, the patient often needs to be reminded to eat, get out of bed, and take care of herself; on 3 occasions, she was hospitalized after attempting to hang herself. Temperature is 37.2⁰C (99⁰F), blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 12/min. She is somnolent but arousable. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in the cerebrospinal fluid

 

  • Low levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are associated with suicidal behaviour.
  • 5-HIAA is the primary metabolite of serotonin, which is one of the most important neurotransmitters responsible for modulating mood and behaviour.
  • Low levels of CSF 5-HIAA are thought to represent dysfunction of the serotonin system. Serotonin is the target of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, the class of medication considered first-line for depressive disorders.
  • This patient has several important risk factors for suicide, including a history of suicide attempts (the strongest predictor of future suicidal behaviour) and a history of psychiatric illness.
  • Other risk factors for suicide include the presence of a medical illness, concerning substance use, and family history of suicide.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) A diffuse 3-Hz spike and wavepattern on electroencephalogram (EEG) is characteristic of childhood absence seizures, characterized by short period of profound impairment of consciousness with intact body tone.

 

Option B) Generalized slowing with periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (e.g., progressive dementia, myoclonus, pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction, mutism).

 

Option C) Low concentration of hypocretin (orexin) in the CSF is found in narcolepsy, characterized by daytime sleepiness, hallucinations, sleep paralysis, and cataplexy (transient muscle weakness with certain emotional states).

 

Educational objective:

 

5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin. Low cerebrospinal fluid 5-HIAA is associated with suicidal behaviour.

questions.text: Eutectic mixture of local anesthetics (EMLA cream) is sometimes used to numb the skin before attempting an intravenous access in pediatric patients. Which of the following local anesthetics is combined with prilocaine to produce this cream?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lidocaine

 

  • Lidocaine is a commonly used local anesthetic with a rapid onset of action.
  • It's versatile and can be used in various forms, including topical, injectable, and as an oral gel.
  • In the case of EMLA cream, lidocaine is the local anesthetic that is combined with prilocaine.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Bupivacaine. Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic used for regional anesthesia in various surgical procedures. It's not typically used in topical preparations due to its potency and risk of systemic toxicity.

 

Option C) Mepivacaine. Mepivacaine is similar to lidocaine and bupivacaine in its action but is less commonly used and typically not included in topical anesthetic preparations like EMLA cream.

 

Option D) Ropivacaine. Ropivacaine is another long-acting local anesthetic used for surgical anesthesia and postoperative pain management. Like bupivacaine, it is not used in topical preparations due to its potency and potential for systemic side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the composition and clinical application of EMLA cream in pediatric medicine.
  • Knowing that EMLA cream contains lidocaine and prilocaine, helps healthcare professionals choose an appropriate topical anesthetic for minimizing pain associated with needle punctures or minor surgical procedures in children.
  • Awareness of the different types of local anesthetics, their characteristics, and uses is crucial for safe and effective patient care in various medical settings.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She did not sustain any serious physical injuries, but she appears drowsy and states that she is feeling very sleepy. Emergency medical staff collected several open medication bottles from the floor of her automobile. Although the contents of two of the bottles could not be determined, the patient’s recently filled bottle of diazepam was almost empty. The patient quickly becomes unresponsive and stops breathing. Administration of which of the following agents will reverse these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flumazenil

 

  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines.
  • It competitively inhibits the action at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, thereby reversing the sedative, hypnotic, and respiratory depressant effects of benzodiazepines.
  • It is the appropriate choice for reversing the symptoms caused by a benzodiazepine overdose such as that suggested by the nearly empty diazepam bottle.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Glucagon. Glucagon is primarily used to treat severe hypoglycemia in diabetes patients. It can also increase heart rate and force of contraction and is sometimes used in β-blocker overdose. However, it has no role in reversing benzodiazepine-induced sedation or respiratory depression.

 

Option C) Midazolam. Midazolam is another benzodiazepine, used for sedation, anxiolysis, and anesthesia induction. Administering midazolam to a patient with a suspected benzodiazepine overdose would exacerbate the sedation and respiratory depression, not reverse it.

 

Option D) Naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose symptoms, including respiratory depression caused by opioids. While naloxone is effective in reversing opioid effects, it would not be effective in reversing the effects of a benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize flumazenil as the appropriate reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose. Flumazenil works by competitively inhibiting benzodiazepines at their binding site on the GABA-A receptor, which can reverse the central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepines, including sedation and respiratory depression. It is crucial to choose the specific antidote based on the type of drug overdose to effectively reverse the symptoms.

choices.text: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)

questions.text: A 1-day-old boy is in the neonatal intensive care unit due to congenital anomalies noted at birth. The infant was born vaginally at 36 weeks gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, who declined prenatal testing and reported decreased fetal movement in the week preceding delivery. The infant was not latching well for the first 24 hours but has urinated and stooled. Examination shows a small face and jaw with a prominence on the back of the head. The oral mucosa is pink, but the hands and feet are mildly cyanotic. There are no skin creases on the palmar aspect of the digits. There is overlapping of the fingers bilaterally along with convexity of bilateral soles and limited hip abduction. A murmur at the left lower sternal border is heard on auscultation. Which of the following cardiovascular abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

 

  • This patient's microcephaly, micrognathia, overlapping fingers, absent palmar creases, and rocker-bottom feet are consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). 
  • Congenital heart disease occurs in more than half of affected patients, with ventricular septal defect (VSD) being the most common abnormality. 
  • As pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth, VSD presents as a holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the left lower sternal border. 
  • Central cyanosis, which typically affects the trunk and mucous membranes, is not usually present with an isolated VSD, as evidenced by this infant's pink oral mucosa. 
  • This patient does have acrocyanosis, or peripheral cyanosis, which affects the hands and feet and is present in most healthy newborns.
  • The prognosis for trisomy 18 is very poor as most affected children die in the first month of life. 
  • Surgical repair of VSD improves survival, but those who survive are severely intellectually disabled.

 

Other options:

 

Options A and B) ASD and PDA. Atrial septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus are associated with trisomy 18. However, atrial septal defect most commonly presents with a fixed, split S2 (due to delayed closure of the pulmonic valve) and/or a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the pulmonic valve). Patent ductus arteriosus presents with a continuous flow murmur, best heard in the left subclavicular region. None of these findings are present in this neonate.

 

Option D) TGA. Transposition of the great arteries is a congenital heart defect that present with central cyanosis and a single S2 sound. This infant has acrocyanosis, or peripheral cyanosis, a normal finding in the first few days of life. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is characterized by micrognathia, microcephaly, rocker-bottom feet, overlapping fingers, and absent palmar creases. 
  • Ventricular septal defect is common in these patients and presents with a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done in India for such cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Police Inquest 

 

INQUEST

 

  • An inquest is an inquiry or investigation into the cause of death.
  • Types of inquest in India: 

 

1. Police Inquest: Done under section 174 CrPc. It is the most common inquest in India. Minimum rank of police officer who can conduct the inquest is Head constable.

 

2. Magistrate Inquest: Done under section 176 CrPc. It is done in few conditions in India. It is of further two types:

 

a. Executive Magistrate: It conducts inquest in two cases:      

                           

  • Dowry death (Death within 7 years of marriage, and death was unnatural and related to dowry) 
  • Exhumation: digging out of buried bodies

 

b. Judicial Magistrate: Done in Custodial Deaths (custody of state. E.g., police custody, jail, rehabilitation, psychiatric hospital etc.)

 

  • The case in question does not fulfil any of the conditions of magistrate inquest, so it will be done by police. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Magistrate Inquest. It is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths. 

 

Option C) Coroner inquest. Not done in India. It is done in UK. Here, the inquest is done by judicial officers.  

 

Option D) Medical examiner’s inquest. Not done in India. It is done in USA. Here, the inquest is done by doctors. It is the best inquest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the commonest inquest is police inquest. Other than police inquest, the other inquest is magistrate inquest which is done in few conditions like Dowry death, exhumation, and custodial deaths. Coroner’s inquest and medical examiner system are not done in India.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair with respect to its nerve supply of the marked structures in the given image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

  • Geniohyoid muscle is innervated by C1 fibres not by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Facial nerve. Platysma muscle is innervated by cervical branch of facial nerve.

 

Option B) Trigeminal nerve. Anterior belly of digastric is innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D) Hypoglossal nerve. Styloglossus muscle is innervated by hypoglossal nerve.

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy, vol. 3, Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy, 7th edition, page no. 142

choices.text: It is a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus.
The virus is icosahedral in shape.
Conjunctivitis is typically caused by type 17 D adenovirus.
Haemorrhagic cystitis is caused by serotype 40 & 41.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a fever and a sore throat. Upon examination, he is found to have red, swollen eyes and small blisters on his upper respiratory tract. Laboratory tests confirm an infection with a DNA virus that is non-enveloped. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The virus is icosahedral in shape.

 

Option B:

 

Adenoviruses are double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses with an icosahedral capsid. They are known to cause a variety of diseases, including conjunctivitis, respiratory illnesses, and gastroenteritis. While adenovirus type 17 can cause respiratory illness, it is not the only type associated with conjunctivitis. Adenovirus types 11 and 21 are associated with hemorrhagic cystitis, and types 40 and 41 are known to cause gastroenteritis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adenoviruses are not ssDNA viruses; they contain double-stranded DNA.

 

Option C. Type 17 adenovirus can cause respiratory illness, but it is not the only type associated with conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Serotypes 11 and 21 are more commonly associated with hemorrhagic cystitis. Adenovirus types 40 and 41 are typically linked to gastroenteritis (especially in children)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p449-50,2/e p467-468

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of hypercholesterolemia is enrolled in a clinical study to evaluate the efficacy of a new statin medication. The research team records his fasting cholesterol levels, which are notably elevated. He is then started on the statin therapy, and his cholesterol levels are re-measured after 6 weeks of consistent medication use. The primary aim of the study is to determine the statistical significance of the change in his cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Given this scenario, which statistical test is most appropriate for analyzing the data?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paired t-test

 

  • The paired t-test is the ideal choice in this scenario because it is used for comparing two sets of related data.
  • In this case, the cholesterol levels of the patient before and after the treatment with the statin medication are being compared.
  • This test helps to determine if there is a statistically significant mean difference between these two related samples.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Unpaired or independent t-test. This test is used for comparing the means between two unrelated groups. In this scenario, since the same patient’s cholesterol levels are being compared before and after the treatment, the groups are not independent, making this test inappropriate.

 

Option C) Analysis of variance (ANOVA). ANOVA is generally utilized when comparing the means of three or more groups. In this study, there are only two related sets of data (pre- and post-treatment), so ANOVA is not the correct choice.

 

Option D) Chi-square test. The chi-square test is intended for categorical data, particularly to test the independence or association between two variables. It is not suitable for comparing mean differences in continuous data, such as cholesterol levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paired t-test is specifically used when the same group of subjects is measured twice, as in before-and-after treatment studies, to determine if the intervention had a statistically significant effect on the outcome being measured.

choices.text: Decreased estrogen levels
Increased bleeding time

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with oligomenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have enlarged, non-tender ovaries bilaterally. The patient’s body mass index is 31 kg/m². What other symptom or finding is this patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hirsutism

 

  • The diagnosis here is most likely PCOS in view of oligomenorrhoea and enlarged ovaries on examination.
  • A high BMI also is in favour of PCOS.
  • Hirsutism, or excessive hair growth in areas where men typically grow hair (face, chest, back), is a common symptom of PCOS due to elevated levels of androgens (male hormones) such as testosterone.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Decreased estrogen levels. Women with PCOS typically have normal or elevated levels of estrogen. The excess androgens in PCOS can be aromatized to estrogens, contributing to the hyperestrogenic state, not a decreased estrogen level.

 

Option B) Epicanthal folds. Epicanthal folds are the skin of the upper eyelid that covers the inner corner of the eye. They are a normal anatomic variant in many ethnicities and are not related to PCOS.

 

Option D) Increased bleeding time. PCOS does not directly affect bleeding time. Bleeding time is influenced by platelet function and other coagulation factors, which are not typically altered in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), which include menstrual irregularities, polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, and signs of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism. PCOS is often associated with obesity and insulin resistance, contributing to its pathophysiology. Understanding these associations is crucial for the diagnosis and management of PCOS.

choices.text: Decreased absorption in the intestine
Decreased distribution to the brain
Increased excretion by the kidneys
Increased metabolism by the liver

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents, 30 minutes after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure while playing in a soccer game. She currently takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After further testing including 24-hour continuous EEG monitoring, carbamazepine is prescribed. This patient’s use of additional medications should be monitored because of which of the following changes in drug disposition after starting pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased metabolism by the liver

 

  • This is the correct option.
  • Carbamazepine induces hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes, which can lead to increased metabolism of many drugs.
  • This effect can decrease the plasma levels and effectiveness of co-administered medications that are substrates for these enzymes.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Decreased absorption in the intestine. Carbamazepine does not significantly affect the absorption of drugs in the intestine. Its primary effects are on drug metabolism rather than on absorption, so this option is not directly relevant to the changes in drug disposition related to carbamazepine therapy.

 

Option B) Decreased distribution to the brain. Carbamazepine does not primarily affect the distribution of drugs to the brain or other tissues in a way that would significantly alter their therapeutic effects. Its impact is more pronounced on the metabolism of drugs.

 

Option C) Increased excretion by the kidneys. While carbamazepine can affect the excretion of some drugs indirectly by altering their metabolism and thus, their pharmacokinetic profiles, its most notable effect is on hepatic enzyme induction rather than direct changes in renal excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational objective here is to understand the enzyme-inducing effects of carbamazepine on hepatic metabolism. Carbamazepine can increase the metabolism of various drugs by inducing cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver. This effect necessitates close monitoring when carbamazepine is used in combination with other medications, as it may reduce their effectiveness by increasing their metabolic clearance.

choices.text: Permanently reducing thyroid activity
Binding to and blocking the iodide transport mechanism of thyroid follicular cells
Binding to intracellular nuclear receptors of peripheral tissue and activating genes
Blocking the peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine

questions.text: Patients with hyperthyroidism have several options to treat their disease, including subtotal thyroidectomy and radioactive ablation. When a patient is unwilling or unable to undergo these procedures, pharmacological therapy is often pursued. One particular medication inhibits the conversion of iodide to iodine and inhibits the organification of iodine with tyrosine. Which of the following is an additional mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blocking the peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine

 

  • This is an additional mechanism of action for propylthiouracil (PTU), one of the thionamides.
  • PTU, in addition to inhibiting thyroid hormone synthesis in the thyroid gland, also inhibits the peripheral conversion of thyroxine (T4) to the more active triiodothyronine (T3).
  • Methimazole does not have this peripheral action.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Permanently reducing thyroid activity. Thionamides like PTU and methimazole do not permanently reduce thyroid activity. Their effects are reversible, and thyroid function often returns to its previous state upon discontinuation of the medication.

 

Option B) Binding to and blocking the iodide transport mechanism of thyroid follicular cells. This mechanism is associated with perchlorate and pertechnetate, which inhibit the sodium-iodide symporter, not thionamides. Thionamides do not act by blocking iodide transport into thyroid cells.

 

Option C) Binding to intracellular nuclear receptors of peripheral tissue and activating genes. This mechanism describes the action of thyroid hormone itself, not the action of thionamides. Thyroid hormones bind to nuclear receptors and modulate gene expression, but this is not a mechanism of action for thionamide drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the mechanisms of action of thionamide medications, such as propylthiouracil (PTU) and methimazole, used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism. While both inhibit the synthesis of thyroid hormones by blocking the iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin and the coupling of iodotyrosines, PTU has the additional mechanism of blocking the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. This understanding is crucial for selecting appropriate therapy in the management of hyperthyroidism, especially considering the specific clinical scenario and patient preferences.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman has noted enlargement of her anterior neck region over the past 8 months. On physical examination, her vital signs include Temperature = 36.8°C, Pulse rate = 64/minute, RR = 16/minute, and BP = 155/105 mm Hg. There is diffuse, symmetrical thyroid enlargement without tenderness. The chest radiograph is normal. Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid yields cells consistent with a neoplasm. Laboratory studies show that she is euthyroid, but her serum ionized calcium is elevated. She is taken to surgery and frozen sections of several thyroid masses show a malignant neoplasm composed of polygonal cells in nests. A thyroidectomy is performed. Immunostaining for calcitonin of the permanent sections is positive, and the neoplasm has an amyloid stroma with Congo red staining. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary carcinoma

 

  •  
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.
  • It is often associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels.
  • The presentation of thyroid enlargement, elevated ionized calcium, and positive immunostaining for calcitonin are all indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • The presence of an amyloid stroma with Congo red staining is a characteristic feature of MTC.
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma can present with palpable thyroid masses and may be associated with familial syndromes, such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Anaplastic carcinoma. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is an aggressive and rapidly growing thyroid cancer. It typically presents with significant local invasion and a poor prognosis. It is not associated with elevated calcitonin levels or amyloid stroma.

 

Option C) Papillary thyroid carcinoma. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer. It typically presents as a thyroid nodule and is associated with characteristic nuclear features, but it does not exhibit elevated calcitonin levels or amyloid stroma.

 

Option D) Metastatic renal cell carcinoma. Metastatic renal cell carcinoma may involve the thyroid gland, but it is not associated with elevated calcitonin levels or amyloid stroma. It typically occurs as a metastatic lesion in the thyroid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland and is associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels.
  • MTC may present with thyroid enlargement and is characterized by an amyloid stroma and positive calcitonin immunostaining.
  • It can occur sporadically or as part of familial syndromes, such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Composite graft

 

  • A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis.
  • Depending on the donor site, it can contain subcutaneous fat, cartilage, and even muscle.
  • This makes it ideal for deeper defects in which a partial-thickness or full-thickness skin graft would give a poor cosmetic outcome.
  • A flap is a vascularized piece of tissue that is mobilized from its original site to another location.
  • A free tissue flap involves severing the original blood supply with anastomosis to blood vessels in the recipient site.
  • The remaining defect in this patient is too small to warrant the need for a flap.

choices.text: Presence of white and red pulp

questions.text: Which among the following is a prominent feature of the histological slide given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Presence of white and red pulp

 

  • The spleen is an organ with unique histological features.
  • It consists of white pulp and red pulp.
  • White pulp is primarily composed of lymphoid tissue and plays a role in immune functions, while red pulp is involved in filtering blood and removing damaged blood cells.
  • This option is relevant to the histology of the spleen given above.
