Other options:

 

Option A) Brunner’s glands. Brunner's glands are found in the duodenum, which is a part of the small intestine. These glands secrete alkaline mucus, which helps to neutralize stomach acid and protect the duodenal mucosa from damage. They are not typically found in the liver or spleen.

 

 

Option B) Central vein and Hepatocytes. The liver consists of functional units called lobules, and each lobule contains a central vein surrounded by hepatocytes (liver cells). This arrangement is characteristic of the liver's histology, and it is responsible for many of the liver's functions, including detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and bile production. This option is relevant to the liver's histology.

 

 

Option C) Lymphoid follicle. Lymphoid follicles are commonly found in lymphoid organs such as lymph nodes and the spleen. They are sites where immune cells, including lymphocytes, congregate and respond to antigens. While lymphoid follicles can sometimes be seen in the liver or other organs during inflammatory responses, they are not typically a prominent feature of the liver or spleen histology.

choices.text: All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema.
Pruritus is hallmark clinical feature.
Nummular eczema is the other name for Discoid eczema.
Pityriasis versicolor is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy.

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement about Dermatitis among the following.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis versicolor is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy.

 

  • Pityriasis alba (NOT versicolor) is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy.
  • Pityriasis alba is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature.

 

 

  • It is seen in the age group of 3 years till puberty.
  • It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.
  • Pityriasis versicolor is a fungal infection due to Malassezia globosa.
  • It has no relation to atopy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema. Dermatitis is an umbrella term, covering many skin conditions associated with inflammation of skin including Eczema, so All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema.

 

Option B) Pruritus is hallmark clinical feature. The hallmark symptom of eczema is intense pruritus.

 

 

  • The image below shows eczema.

 

 

Option C) Nummular eczema is the other name for Discoid eczema. Nummular dermatitis/Nummular eczema/Discoid Eczema presents as a well demarcated coin shaped erythematous plaque with vesicles surrounding it.

 

  • Common locations involved are:
    • Trunk
    • Extensor surfaces of extremities:
      • Men: pretibial areas
      • Women: Dorsal aspects of hand
  • The image below shows nummular dermatitis.

 

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, volume 2, Chapter 39, page no. 39.1-3, 39.7-8, 39.25

choices.text: Constitution of All India Health Service on the pattern of the Indian Administrative Service (IAS)
Establishment of separate staff for the Family Planning Programme
Creation of “bands of para-professionals & semi-professional health workers”
Major changes in medical education to prepare “Social Physicians”

questions.text: In 1946, the Bhore Committee was established to make recommendations for improving the health care system in India. This committee's proposals have had a lasting impact on the country's health infrastructure and medical education. One of their key recommendations focused on a significant aspect of medical education. Which of the following was a major recommendation of the Bhore Committee?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Major changes in medical education to prepare “Social Physicians”

 

  • The Bhore Committee, formed in 1946, emphasized the transformation of medical education with a specific focus on creating “Social Physicians.”
  • This recommendation was aimed at integrating preventive and social medicine into medical education, including a proposed 3-month internship training in these fields.
  • The committee's vision was to produce physicians who were not only medically proficient but also attuned to the social and preventive aspects of healthcare, reflecting a holistic approach to health and well-being.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Constitution of All India Health Service on the pattern of IAS. This was a recommendation of the Mudaliar Committee in 1962.

 

Option B) Separate staff for Family Planning Programme. This was recommended by the Mukherji Committee in 1965, focusing specifically on the implementation and management of family planning services.

 

Option C) Creation of “bands of para-professionals & semi-professional health workers”. This recommendation came from the Srivastava Committee in 1975, which focused on expanding the healthcare workforce with various levels of trained workers to enhance healthcare delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Transposition of the great arteries

questions.text: A neonate is found to have a congenital heart defect. Physical examination reveals that the patient is not cyanotic, but a harsh holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. No other murmurs are heard on auscultation. From which of the following congenital heart defects is this neonate most likely suffering?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular septal defect

 

  • A ventricular septal defect is a hole in the wall (septum) that separates the two lower chambers (ventricles) of the heart.
  • It commonly presents with a harsh holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border, and the patient is typically not cyanotic.
  • This description matches the neonate's symptoms in the question.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Atrial septal defect (ASD). An atrial septal defect is a hole in the wall (septum) that separates the two upper chambers (atria) of the heart. It typically presents with a fixed split second heart sound (S2) and a systolic ejection murmur. It does not typically cause a harsh holosystolic murmur.

 

Option B) Tetralogy of Fallot. Tetralogy of Fallot is a complex congenital heart defect that consists of four components: pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect (VSD), overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. While it does include a VSD, it also presents with other features like cyanosis (blueness) due to decreased pulmonary blood flow. The neonate described in the question is not cyanotic, making Tetralogy of Fallot less likely.

 

 

Option C) Transposition of the great arteries. Transposition of the great arteries is a congenital heart defect where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched in position. It typically presents with cyanosis. The presence of a harsh holosystolic murmur without cyanosis is not characteristic of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the clinical presentations of common congenital heart defects and their associated murmurs. Healthcare professionals should be able to recognize the characteristic signs and symptoms to make accurate diagnoses and provide appropriate care to neonates and children with congenital heart defects.

choices.text: Inhaled beta agonist

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office asking for antibiotics to treat a "sinus infection". He reports recurrent episodes of nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and dry cough. The patient has used over-the-counter allergy medicines with some relief but continues to feel uncomfortable and has difficulty concentrating at work. He does not have shortness of breath, chest pain, or ocular symptoms. The patient has no prior history of allergies or asthma but had eczema during childhood. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37⁰C (98.6⁰F), blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min. Physical examination shows a transverse nasal crease, swollen and pale nasal turbinates, and a clear nasal discharge. There is no maxillary sinus tenderness. The posterior pharyngeal wall has a "cobblestone" appearance. Breath sounds are normal with no added sounds. Which of the following is the most effective therapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intranasal glucocorticoid

 

ALLERGIC RHINITIS

 

  • Symptoms:
    • ﻿﻿Rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, sneezing, nasal itching
    • ﻿﻿Cough secondary to postnasal drip
    • ﻿﻿Ocular itching & tearing
    • ﻿﻿"Allergic shiners" (infraorbital edema & darkening)
    • ﻿﻿"Allergic salute" (transverse nasal crease)
  • Physical examination:
    • ﻿﻿Pale, bluish, enlarged turbinates
    • ﻿﻿Pharyngeal cobblestoning
    • "Allergic facies" (high-arched palate, open-mouth breathing)
  • Treatment:
    • Allergen avoidance
    • Intranasal corticosteroids
  • This patient has typical features of allergic rhinitis including nasal congestion, clear rhinorrhea, and pale, edematous nasal mucosa.
  • Patients may also have nasal creases, pharyngeal cobblestoning, conjunctival edema, or thick, green nasal discharge.
  • During peak allergy seasons, patients can experience systemic (e.g., fever) or neuropsychiatric (e.g., fatigue, irritability) symptoms.
  • Atopic disorders (e.g., allergic rhinitis, "hay fever," asthma, eczema) frequently cluster in families, but individual patients usually experience only a subset of these manifestations.
  • Allergen avoidance can mitigate the symptoms of allergic rhinitis but is not always possible, and even low-level exposure can trigger bothersome symptoms.
  • Glucocorticoid nasal sprays (e.g., fluticasone, mometasone) are the most effective single agents. An initial response can be seen within several hours of administration, but maximal benefits may require continuous treatment for several days or weeks.
  • Non-sedating oral antihistamines (e.g., loratadine, cetirizine), antihistamine (e.g., azelastine) or cromolyn nasal sprays, and leukotriene modifiers (e.g., montelukast) are less effective but can be considered based on the patient's symptoms and drug tolerances.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Inhaled beta agonists are indicated for patients with asthma. Patients with wheezing should be evaluated for possible asthma, but a dry cough alone is a non-specific symptom.

 

Option B) Intranasal decongestant. Nasal decongestant sprays can reduce mucosal edema but are less effective overall than glucocorticoids and can cause rebound congestion (rhinitis medicamentosa).

 

Option D) Oral antibiotics. This patient has no fever or sinus tenderness to suggest bacterial sinusitis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Glucocorticoid nasal sprays are the most effective single agent for allergic rhinitis, although maximal benefits may require continuous treatment for several days or weeks.
  • Oral antihistamines, antihistamine or cromolyn nasal sprays, and leukotriene modifiers can be considered based on the patient's symptoms and drug tolerances.

questions.text: Identify the antiarrhythmic agent with the following mechanism of action.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flecainide

 

  • The given drug decreased the slope of phase 0 (Na channel blocker) but does not affect the APD (no effect on K channels). These are the properties of class Ic drugs.
  • Class Ic drugs include encainide and flecainide.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tocainide is class I b anti-arrhythmic drug.

 

Option C. Procainamide is class Ia drug.

 

Option D. Ibutilide is class III anti-arrhythmic drug.

choices.text: Chronic hemoglobin oxidation and precipitation
Inability to produce alpha or beta globin chains
Mechanical red blood cell membrane damage
Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text:
A 7-year-old Vietnamese boy is brought to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He underwent splenectomy a year ago for persistent anemia and jaundice. He has received the pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations and takes penicillin prophylaxis. His paternal uncle died from complications of hemolytic uremic syndrome 35 years ago. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing child. The sclerae are anicteric. The abdomen is soft and non-tender; no masses are palpable. Several well-healed laparoscopy scars are noted. Complete blood count is as follows:

 

 

Peripheral blood smear with Wright stain is shown in the image. This patient's findings are most likely related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

 

  • This patient has single, round, blue inclusions within red blood cells (RBCs) on peripheral smear, consistent with Howell-Jolly bodies. 
  • These bodies are retained RBC nuclear remnants that are typically removed by the spleen. 
  • The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies usually indicates either physical absence of the spleen (i.e., asplenia) due to congenital absence or surgical removal or functional hyposplenism due to splenic auto-infarction (e.g., sickle cell disease), infiltrative disorders of the spleen (e.g., sarcoidosis), or splenic congestion (e.g., thrombosis).
  • Both asplenia and functional hyposplenism increase the risk of sepsis because the spleen is normally responsible for clearing bacteria, particularly encapsulated organisms. 
  • However, splenectomy may be indicated in cases of chronic hemolysis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Chronic hemoglobin oxidation and precipitation. In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency disease, hemoglobin becomes oxidized and precipitates into insoluble Heinz bodies. Peripheral smear shows bite cells, and Heinz bodies appear as peripheral blue inclusions with special staining (e.g., crystal violet), not with Wright staining as in this patient.

 

Option B) Inability to produce alpha or beta globin chains. The inability to produce alpha (alpha thalassemia) or beta (beta thalassemia) globin chains causes hypochromic, microcytic RBCs and target cells (due to decreased hemoglobin production), which can be seen on peripheral smear.

 

Option C) Mechanical red blood cell membrane damage. Mechanical RBC damage occurs when RBCs shear within the vascular system. This occurs in hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. Schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) are seen on peripheral blood smear.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants within red blood cells typically removed by the spleen. 
  • Their presence strongly suggests asplenia or functional hyposplenism.

choices.text: Moisture content 10% by weight and Sodium chloride 90% by weight
Moisture content 5% by weight and Sodium chloride 97% by weight
Moisture content 8% by weight and Sodium chloride 80% by weight
Moisture content 15% by weight and Sodium chloride 90% by weight

questions.text: In a seminar on food safety regulations, a discussion focuses on the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act of 1954, specifically addressing the standards for iodized table salt. The facilitator explains that the PFA Act sets specific criteria for the composition of iodized table salt to ensure its quality and safety for public consumption. According to the PFA Act of 1954, what are the specified standards for the moisture content and sodium chloride concentration in iodized table salt?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moisture content 5% by weight and Sodium chloride 97% by weight

 

  • The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act of 1954 sets specific standards for the composition of iodized table salt to ensure it meets quality and safety requirements.
  • According to this act, the moisture content in iodized table salt must be less than 6.0% by weight.
  • This standard is crucial to prevent caking and to maintain the salt's free-flowing nature.
  • Additionally, the sodium chloride content must be more than 96.0% by weight, ensuring the purity and efficacy of the salt for consumption.
  • These standards are critical for maintaining the nutritional and safety aspects of table salt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iodisation of salt is the most widely used prophylactic measure against prevention of goitre.
  • Iodised salt is most convenient, effective, and economical method of mass prophylaxis in endemic areas.
  • According to Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act’ 1954:
    • Level of iodisation: Minimum 30 ppm at production level and 15 ppm at consumer level
    • Moisture content: < 6.0% by weight
    • Sodium chloride: > 96.0% by weight

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a 17-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and progressive renal failure is being considered for dialysis. Laboratory studies show normocytic, normochromic anemia. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to treat the anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythropoietin

 

  • Erythropoietin is a hormone produced by the kidneys that stimulates the bone marrow to produce red blood cells.
  • In patients with CKD, the production of erythropoietin is reduced, leading to anemia.
  • Administering synthetic erythropoietin (erythropoiesis-stimulating agents, ESAs) can effectively treat this type of anemia by compensating for the decreased endogenous production.
  • This makes erythropoietin the most appropriate choice for treating anemia in this patient.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Folic acid. Folic acid is necessary for the synthesis of DNA and, therefore, for the division and growth of cells, including red blood cells. While folic acid supplementation can be beneficial in cases of anemia due to folic acid deficiency, there is no indication in the scenario that this patient's anemia is due to folic acid deficiency. Therefore, it's not the most appropriate choice for this specific case.

 

Option C) Folinic acid. Folinic acid (leucovorin) is a form of folate that can be used to manage certain drug toxicities (e.g., methotrexate toxicity) and in combination with other medications for treating specific types of cancer. Like folic acid, it could theoretically support red blood cell production but is not indicated for anemia due to CKD.

 

Option D) Vitamin B1 (thiamine). Thiamine is essential for carbohydrate metabolism and neural function. Thiamine deficiency can lead to conditions such as beriberi or Wernicke encephalopathy but is not a cause of normocytic, normochromic anemia. Therefore, thiamine supplementation would not address the anemia in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic kidney disease, the most common cause of normocytic, normochromic anemia is a deficiency in erythropoietin production by the kidneys. The most appropriate treatment in such cases is the administration of synthetic erythropoietin (erythropoiesis-stimulating agents) to stimulate red blood cell production. Other supplements like folic acid, folinic acid, and vitamin B1 may be important in specific contexts but are not the primary treatment for anemia associated with CKD.

questions.text: A small town's healthcare system is evaluating the capacity of its mortuary. Over the last year, the town reported 600 deaths. The mortuary's policy is to store bodies for an average of 3 days. To optimize space and resources, the facility aims to maintain 80% occupancy rate. Based on these statistics, what is the minimum number of mortuary beds required to adhere to this occupancy target?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

In the given question,

 

  • Total Bed-days required per year = Total number of admissions per year × average length of stay in hospital = 600 x 3 = 1800
  • Total number of beds required when occupancy is 100% = Bed-days per year/365 days = 1800/365 = 4.93 = 5 beds
  • Total number of beds required when occupancy is 80% = Bed-days per year/(365 x 80%) = 1800/(365 × 80%) = 6.16 beds = 6 beds

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resource allocation and capacity planning: It involves applying basic arithmetic skills to calculate facility requirements based on event frequency (deaths), average duration of usage (storage in mortuary), and desired occupancy rates. This calculation is fundamental for effective healthcare administration, ensuring resources are optimally utilized without being overstretched.

questions.text:
In a tropical medicine class, students are learning about the Anopheles mosquito, a vector known for transmitting malaria. The lecturer emphasizes certain distinctive features of this mosquito species to aid in identification and understanding of its behavior and life cycle. Which of the following features are characteristic of the Anopheles mosquito?

  1. Stripes on wings
  2. Larva rests at an angle to water surface
  3. Adult rests at an angle to the surface of the skin
  4. Eggs laid in clusters
  5. No siphon tube in larvae
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 5

 

3. Adult rests at an angle to the surface of the skin. This is a distinguishing feature of the Anopheles mosquito. Unlike other mosquitoes, Anopheles tends to rest on surfaces, including human skin, at an angle, making it recognizable.

 

5. No siphon tube in larvae. Anopheles mosquito larvae are unique, in that, they do not have a siphon tube for breathing. They lie parallel to the water surface to breathe, unlike other mosquito larvae like the Culex, which hang down from the surface at an angle with a siphon tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Stripes on wings. This is not a specific feature of Anopheles mosquitoes. Wing patterns can vary among different mosquito species.

 

2. Larva rests at an angle to water surface. This is more characteristic of Culex mosquito larvae, not Anopheles.

 

4. Eggs laid in clusters. Anopheles mosquitoes do not lay eggs in clusters. They lay their eggs singly on the water surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIFFERENTIATING FEATURES

questions.text: In a comprehensive study conducted at a regional hospital, 200 patients were screened for Glaucoma using a new advanced imaging technique. To validate the imaging results, all patients subsequently underwent a detailed ophthalmologic examination, which is considered the gold standard for diagnosing Glaucoma. Out of 80 patients who tested positive in the imaging screening, 64 were confirmed to have Glaucoma during the examination. Among the 120 patients who tested negative in the screening, 96 were confirmed not to have Glaucoma in the examination. Based on these data, calculate the Positive and Negative Likelihood Ratios for the imaging technique used in screening for Glaucoma.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5.00 and 0.32

 

  • For calculation of Positive and Negative Likelihood Ratios (LR+ and LR-), first determine the True Positives (TP), False Positives (FP), True Negatives (TN), and False Negatives (FN) from the data.
  • TP: Patients who tested positive on the imaging and were confirmed to have Glaucoma = 64
  • FP: Patients who tested positive on the imaging but did not have Glaucoma = 80 – 64 = 16
  • TN: Patients who tested negative on the imaging and were confirmed not to have Glaucoma = 96
  • FN: Patients who tested negative on the imaging but were found to have Glaucoma = 120 – 96 = 24

 

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) = 64 / (64 + 24) = 64 / 88 ≈ 0.73

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP) = 96 / (96 + 16) = 96 / 112 ≈ 0.86

Positive Likelihood Ratio (LR+) = Sensitivity / (1 – Specificity) = 0.73 / (1 – 0.86) ≈ 5.1

Negative Likelihood Ratio (LR-) = (1 – Sensitivity) / Specificity = (1 – 0.73) / 0.86 ≈ 0.32

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Likelihood ratio incorporates both the sensitivity and specificity of the test and provides a direct estimate of how much a test result will change the odds of having a disease.
  • The Positive Likelihood Ratio indicates how much a positive test result increases the probability of having a disease and the Negative Likelihood Ratio indicates how much a negative test result decreases the probability of having a disease.

questions.text: Advanced bipolar energy sources can coagulate vessels directly upto what diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upto 7 mm

 

  • Surgeons have increasingly used advanced energy devices to facilitate dissection and to seal and divide blood vessels up to 7 mm in diameter.
  • There are three main types of advanced energy devices: bipolar electrosurgery, ultrasonic electrosurgery and combination device. 
  • Bipolar: New technology such as the LigaSure™ system (Medtronic) involves advanced bipolar technology that uses the body’s collagen and elastin to both seal and divide, allowing surgeons to reduce instrument handling when dissecting, ligating and grasping - a valuable asset particularly during laparoscopic surgery. The feedback-sensing technology incorporated in the instrument is designed to manage the energy delivery in a precise manner and results in automatic discontinuation of energy once the seal is complete.
  • Ultra-sonic: The harmonic scalpel is an instrument that uses ultrasound technology to cut tissues while simultaneously sealing them. It utilizes a hand-held ultrasound transducer and scalpel that is controlled by a hand switch or foot pedal. During use, the scalpel vibrates in the 20 000–50 000-Hz range and cuts through tissues, effecting haemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues by means of protein denaturation caused by vibration rather than heat (in a similar manner to whisking an egg white).
  • One product, the Thunder beat STM (Olympus), has combined both modalities in a single device. By simultaneously using ultrasonic vibration and bipolar diathermy, this device can seal and divide arteries and veins up to 7 mm in diameter.

questions.text: A health program manager is conducting a workshop on the key elements of evaluating health programs. The manager emphasizes the importance of certain criteria that must be considered while assessing any health program. However, one of the criteria mentioned is not typically recognized as an element of program evaluation. Which of the following is NOT considered a standard element of evaluation in the context of health program assessment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeatability

 

  • Repeatability is not typically considered a standard element of program evaluation in health management.
  • Program evaluation generally focuses on the relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, and acceptability of a health program, among other factors.
  • Repeatability refers more to the ability to get consistent results over multiple trials or experiments, which is more pertinent in scientific or clinical research rather than program evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Relevance. Relevance is a key element of evaluation, assessing whether the program meets the needs and priorities of the target population.

 

Option C) Acceptability. This aspect of evaluation looks at how well the program is received by the target population and other stakeholders.

 

Option D) Effectiveness. Effectiveness evaluates how well the program achieves its intended outcomes and objectives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

COMPONENTS/ELEMENTS OF EVALUATION PROCESS IN HEALTH SERVICES ARE:

 

  1. Relevance: Appropriateness (need) of a health service
  2. Adequacy: Sufficient attention to pre-determined course of action
  3. Accessibility: Proportion of population expected to use the service
  4. Acceptability: Socially and culturally acceptable
  5. Effectiveness: Extent of prevention/alleviation of underlying problem
  6. Efficiency: How well resources are utilized
  7. Impact: Overall effect of programme/service on health and development

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Imaging of the sinuses

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office due to nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and postnasal drip for more than a year. Symptoms fluctuate in intensity and are worsened by cigarette smoke and strong fragrances. Although symptoms do not change with the season, they worsen when the patient walks from indoors to outdoors on a cold day. She has no eye or ear symptoms, itching, wheezing, or skin rash. The patient has been using over-the-counter oral loratadine and pseudoephedrine without significant improvement. Medical history is unremarkable. On inspection, the nasal mucosa appears boggy and erythematous, and rhinorrhea is clear. The conjunctivae are normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intranasal glucocorticoids

 

 

  • This patient has rhinitis triggered by strong smells and sudden exposure to cold air. 
  • She lacks eye symptoms or triggers consistent with allergies (e.g., seasonal variation), and the symptoms do not improve with oral antihistamines. This presentation is consistent with non-allergic rhinitis (NAR), also known as vasomotor rhinitis.
  • In contrast to patients with allergic rhinitis, patients with NAR usually cannot identify specific allergic triggers (e.g., pollen counts), and they typically have negative testing for aeroallergens. 
  • However, many have very specific behavioural triggers (e.g., walking into cold air, eating). 
  • In addition, patients with NAR typically lack the sneezing and allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., itchy eyes, injected conjunctivae) that classically accompany allergic rhinitis.
  • First-line treatment for both allergic rhinitis and NAR is intranasal glucocorticoids. 
  • Intranasal antihistamines (e.g., azelastine, olopatadine) or intranasal ipratropium bromide can also be used. 
  • Combination therapy is often required for patients with moderate to severe symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Imaging of the sinuses. Imaging can be helpful for patients with chronic sinusitis, which can present with nasal congestion. However, patients with chronic sinusitis also typically have mucopurulent drainage, facial pain or pressure, and a decreased sense of smell.

 

Option C) CT PNS is usually advised for patients suspected for chronic rhinosinusitis, but not for allergic or non-allergic rhinitis.

 

Option D) Radio-allergo-sorbent test. A serum radio-allergo-sorbent test (RAST) can be helpful for identifying triggers in patients with allergic rhinitis. However, it is not usually helpful in patients with NAR because the results are typically negative; therefore, skin allergy or serum RAST testing is usually considered only if there is inadequate response to empiric treatment.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Non-allergic rhinitis usually presents with nasal congestion and rhinorrhea without specific allergic triggers. 
  • Patients should be treated with intranasal glucocorticoids; intranasal antihistamines can be added if needed.

questions.text:
In a legal briefing about the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act, a group of healthcare professionals is learning about the substances regulated under this act. The NDPS Act includes a range of substances that are controlled due to their potential for abuse and dependency. However, not all commonly known psychoactive substances are included under this act. Which of the following substances are NOT included in the NDPS Act?

  1. Alcohol
  2. Opium
  3. Cannabis
  4. Nicotine
  5. Morphine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

  • The NDPS Act specifically targets substances with narcotic and psychotropic properties, focusing on those with a high potential for abuse and dependency.
  • The act does not encompass all substances that have psychoactive effects.
  • Notably:

 

1. Alcohol. Alcohol, despite its psychoactive properties, is not included in the NDPS Act. It is regulated under different legal frameworks focused on alcoholic beverages.

 

4. Nicotine. Similarly, nicotine is not covered under the NDPS Act. It is primarily regulated under laws pertaining to tobacco products.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Opium. Opium is included in the NDPS Act due to its narcotic properties and potential for abuse.

 

3. Cannabis. Cannabis, also known as marijuana, is regulated under the NDPS Act.

 

5. Morphine. Morphine, a derivative of opium, is a controlled substance under the NDPS Act due to its powerful analgesic effects and potential for abuse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • List of some popular drugs included Amphetamine; Charas; Cocaine; Ganja (Marijuana); Heroin; LSD; Methadone; Morphine and Opium.

questions.text: A 25-year-old medical student presents to a health clinic with fatigue, a sore throat, and chills. His temperature is 101.6°F (38.7°C). Findings on physical examination are significant for a red oropharynx with exudate and tender enlarged lymph nodes. A rapid strep test is positive for Streptococcus-induced pharyngitis. The physician plans to prescribe penicillin, but the patient reports that the last time he took penicillin, he experienced severe airway swelling and difficulty breathing that required hospitalization. Which of the following is the best choice for treating this patient, given his penicillin allergy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Azithromycin

 

  • Meropenem is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic.
  • While the cross-reactivity between penicillin and carbapenem is very low, meropenem is generally reserved for more severe, hospital-acquired infections due to its broad-spectrum activity and the risk of promoting antibiotic resistance.
  • It would not be the first choice for treating simple Streptococcus pharyngitis in an outpatient setting, especially considering the patient's penicillin allergy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Amoxicillin. Amoxicillin is a penicillin antibiotic and shares a β-lactam ring similar to penicillin, making it likely to elicit an allergic reaction in patients with a history of penicillin allergy, especially those who have experienced severe reactions. Therefore, it is not a suitable option for this patient.

 

Option B) Azithromycin. Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic, which works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is often used as an alternative in patients with penicillin allergies for treating infections like streptococcal pharyngitis. Its different mechanism of action and lack of a β-lactam ring make it a safe and effective alternative for patients with penicillin allergies.

 

Option C) Cephalexin. Cephalexin is a cephalosporin, another class of β-lactam antibiotics. While the overall cross-reactivity rate between penicillins and first-generation cephalosporins like cephalexin is low, it's generally advised to avoid cephalosporins in patients with a history of severe allergic reactions to penicillin, such as anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational objective is to understand the management of bacterial pharyngitis in the context of a patient with a penicillin allergy. When treating bacterial infections in patients allergic to penicillin, it is important to select antibiotics with minimal cross-reactivity and appropriate spectrum of activity. Macrolides like azithromycin are effective alternatives for treating Streptococcus-induced pharyngitis in patients with a penicillin allergy. It's also important to consider the severity of the allergic reaction to penicillin when considering a β-lactam alternative, reserving broad-spectrum antibiotics for more severe or resistant infections to avoid the development of antibiotic resistance.

choices.text: Enterocele forms a bulge at the posterior fornix
Rectocele may bulge into the lower vagina
Pubococcygeus portion of levator ani assists urinary flow
Broad ligament is an important uterine support to prevent prolapse

questions.text: A 62-year-old female from a rural area and a mother to six children presented to gynec OPD with complaints of back pain and the sensation of something “coming down” her vagina, especially when she was standing. She also complained of feeling of wetness when she coughed, sneezed, or lifted a heavy object. She also complained that her frequency to micturate has increased about fifteen times per day. Pelvic examination revealed a first degree uterine prolapse and prolapse of the bladder base. Vaginal hysterectomy and an anterior colporrhaphy were performed and the patient was subsequently relieved of her symptoms. Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Broad ligament is an important uterine support to prevent prolapse

 

  • Several fascial ligaments, including the round ligament of the uterus and the rectouterine ligaments, and the cardinal ligaments help maintain the orientation of the uterus and cervix, and aid in supporting the pelvic viscera but broad ligament and other peritoneal folds exert negligible support for uterus.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Enterocele forms a bulge at the posterior fornix. Loops of the small intestine in the rectouterine pouch may cause a bulge at the posterior fornix.

 

Option B) Rectocele may bulge into the lower vagina. Rectum may bulge into the lower vagina.

 

Option C) Pubococcygeus portion of levator ani assists urinary flow. Urinary flow is controlled voluntarily by the striated urethrovaginal sphincter muscle. This action is assisted by the pubococcygeus portion (levator prostate in the male) of the levator ani.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd edition, vol. II, Abdomen, page no. 257

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he punched a wall and now has pain in his hand. The physician tells the patient that he has broken his hand. Which of the following is the most likely site of this patient’s fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metacarpals

 

  • Metacarpal fractures are a common result of punching or striking an object with a closed fist.
  • The metacarpals are the long bones in the hand that connect the fingers to the wrist.
  • Fractures of the metacarpals are often referred to as "boxer's fractures" when they occur at the neck of the metacarpal bones.
  • These fractures are more likely in situations involving trauma to the hand.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Distal radius. Fractures of the distal radius are commonly known as Colles' fractures. These fractures are often seen in older individuals, typically due to a fall on an outstretched hand. They may cause deformity of the wrist and are less common in teenagers, especially when the injury is caused by punching.

 

 

Option B) Hamate. The hamate is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist. Fractures of the hamate are less common and are usually associated with specific activities like golfing or racquet sports. It is unlikely to be the site of a fracture resulting from punching.

 

Option D) Phalanges. Phalangeal fractures refer to fractures of the finger bones (phalanges). While finger fractures can occur when punching, they are usually not as common as metacarpal fractures in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the common sites of hand fractures based on the mechanism of injury. In this case, recognizing that metacarpal fractures are more likely to occur when someone punches an object or sustains a direct impact to the hand. Healthcare professionals should be aware of the typical patterns of hand fractures to provide appropriate diagnosis and treatment in such cases.

questions.text: A 68-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated due to decreased vision in the left eye. The patient has a history of advanced ovarian cancer and has been treated with combination chemotherapy. Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital with small bowel obstruction. There was no improvement with non-operative management, so she underwent exploratory laparotomy and bowel resection 14 days ago. The post-operative course was complicated by an anastomotic leak. The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition and piperacillin-tazobactam. Over the past 2 days, she has had floaters and progressive blurring of the vision in the left eye. The patient reports no eye pain or headache. Temperature is 38⁰C (100.4⁰F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min. Left eye visual acuity is decreased, and fundoscopy reveals fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions with ill-defined borders. The central venous catheter site has no erythema or tenderness. There is no discharge from the abdominal incisions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal endophthalmitis

 

  • Description: An infection inside the eye caused by fungi.
  • Relevance: This is a likely cause given the patient's immunocompromised state (due to cancer and chemotherapy), recent surgery, and the use of central venous catheters. The fluffy, yellow-white lesions in the eye are characteristic of this type of infection.
  • Based on the symptoms, medical history, and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is Fungal Endophthalmitis.
  • The presence of fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions, along with her immunocompromised state and recent invasive procedures, strongly points to this diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cerebral Metastasis.

 

  • Description: This refers to cancer spreading to the brain.
  • Relevance: While cerebral metastasis can affect vision, the specific finding of fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions in the eye is not typical for this condition.

 

Option B) Drug-induced Glaucoma.

 

  • Description: Certain medications can increase eye pressure, leading to glaucoma.
  • Relevance: This could affect vision, but the specific funduscopic findings described (chorioretinal lesions) and the lack of eye pain or headache make drug-induced glaucoma less likely.

 

Option D) Paraneoplastic Optic Neuritis.

 

  • Description: An autoimmune reaction associated with cancer that affects the optic nerve.
  • Relevance: This condition could be considered given her cancer history. However, the fundus changes seen in the eye are more indicative of an infectious process like fungal endophthalmitis rather than an autoimmune reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational point here is recognizing the risk factors and clinical presentation of fungal endophthalmitis. Patients with a compromised immune system, recent surgery, or central venous catheters are at increased risk. Fundoscopic examination revealing characteristic fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions is crucial for diagnosis. Prompt recognition and treatment are important due to the potential for severe vision loss.

choices.text: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants
Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH
Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops
Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it

questions.text: During a seminar on environmental health, a discussion arises about various indices used to assess the quality of natural resources. One of the participants asks about the "Saturation Index." This term refers to a specific method of assessment in environmental science. Which of the following best describes the Saturation Index?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

 

  • The Saturation Index is a measure used primarily in the assessment of water quality.
  • It is a calculation that considers factors like hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH to determine the scaling potential of water.
  • It indicates whether water will precipitate, dissolve, or be in equilibrium with calcium carbonate.
  • This index is critical in water treatment processes and in understanding the corrosive or scaling nature of water, particularly in industrial and municipal water systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants. This typically involves measuring pollutants like particulate matter, nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide, etc.

 

Option C) Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops. While soil quality is important for agriculture, the Saturation Index does not pertain to soil quality or its suitability for crop growth.

 

Option D) Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it. Milk quality assessments usually focus on factors like bacterial count, fat content, and adulteration, which are not related to the Saturation Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LANGLIER’S SATURATION INDEX (LSI)

 

  •  
  • LSI provides an indicator of the degree of saturation of water with respect to calcium carbonate.
  • LSI is based on estimating Hardness (calcium concentration), Total dissolved solids (TDS), Alkalinity, pH, and Temperature.
  • LSI Positive indicates Scaling; LSI negative indicates corrosion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient visits a nutrition clinic for a body composition assessment. The dietician plans to use skin-fold thickness measurement to estimate the patient's body fat percentage. This method involves measuring the thickness of skin-folds at specific sites on the body. However, some areas are more commonly used than others due to the reliability and ease of measurement. Based on standard practices in body composition assessment, which of the following sites is not commonly used for the measurement of skin-fold thickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluteal area

  • The gluteal area is not a common site for measuring skin-fold thickness.
  • Skin-fold measurements are usually taken at specific sites where the fat deposits are more representative of the total body fat and are easily accessible.
  • The gluteal area is generally not used due to the difficulty in obtaining accurate and consistent measurements in this region.
  • Skin fold thickness (SFT): Rapid & non-invasive method of fat assessment. Harpenden skin callipers are good for estimation of SFT.
    • Main drawback: Poor repeatability (Poor precision)
    • Measurement at 4 sites: Mid-triceps, biceps, sub-scapular, supra-iliac regions
      • Sum > 50 mm in girls indicate obesity
      • Sum > 40 mm in boys indicate obesity

 

 

Harpenden skin callipers

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Single best measurement site of skin fold thickness: Mid triceps
    • 18 mm in boys indicate obesity.
    • 32 mm in girls indicate obesity.

questions.text: An inherited disorder of carbohydrate metabolism is characterized by an abnormally increased concentration of hepatic glycogen with normal structure and no detectable increase in serum glucose concentration after oral administration of fructose. These two observations suggest that the disease is a result of the absence of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is crucial for the final step of both glycogenolysis (conversion of glycogen to glucose) and gluconeogenesis (generation of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources).
  • Deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase leads to Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), also known as von Gierke disease.
  • In GSD I, the inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the liver and an inability to raise serum glucose levels, even after fructose administration.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Fructokinase.

 

  • Fructokinase is the enzyme responsible for phosphorylating fructose to form fructose-1-phosphate in the first step of fructose metabolism.
  • Deficiency in fructokinase leads to hereditary fructose intolerance.
  • In this condition, accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate can inhibit other enzymes, such as aldolase B, leading to symptoms when fructose is consumed.
  • However, it does not typically result in increased hepatic glycogen with normal structure.

 

Option B) Glucokinase.

 

  • Glucokinase is primarily involved in glucose metabolism, specifically in the liver and pancreas.
  • It phosphorylates glucose to form glucose-6-phosphate.
  • Deficiency in glucokinase is associated with a form of diabetes known as maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), but it does not directly relate to the described phenotype of increased hepatic glycogen with normal structure and no increase in serum glucose after fructose administration.

 

Option D) Phosphoglucomutase:

 

  • Phosphoglucomutase is involved in interconverting glucose-1-phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate during glycogen metabolism.
  • Deficiencies in phosphoglucomutase can lead to certain glycogen storage diseases but do not typically lead to the described phenotype of increased hepatic glycogen with normal structure and no increase in serum glucose after fructose administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand that Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), characterized by increased hepatic glycogen with normal structure and an inability to raise serum glucose levels after fructose administration, is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Recognizing the enzyme deficiencies associated with specific inherited metabolic disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

choices.text: Avoidance of alcohol and cigarette use
Delaying sexual activity
Diet and exercise

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal P5L5 woman sees her gynecologist for a yearly well-woman check-up. Her body mass index is 34 kg/m². Results of a bimanual examination and a breast examination are normal. The patient mentions that her grandmother died of endometrial cancer, and claims that she will stop drinking and smoking if it will save her from the agony her grandmother experienced. The physician reviews the patient’s medical history with her and discusses her risk factors for endometrial cancer. Which of the following interventions would have best decreased the risk for developing endometrial cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diet and exercise

 

  • Obesity is a well-established risk factor for endometrial cancer, largely due to increased peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens in adipose tissue, which leads to a state of unopposed estrogen.
  • This can stimulate the endometrial lining and increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.
  • Maintaining a healthy weight through diet and exercise can reduce the amount of adipose tissue and, consequently, the estrogen exposure to the endometrium, thereby reducing the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Avoidance of alcohol and cigarette use. While avoiding alcohol and smoking is beneficial for overall health and can reduce the risk of several types of cancers, they are not the most significant factors specifically for endometrial cancer risk compared to the impact of obesity and unopposed estrogen exposure.

 

Option B) Delaying sexual activity. Delaying sexual activity is more relevant for reducing the risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and their associated risks, such as cervical cancer linked to human papillomavirus (HPV). It does not have a direct impact on endometrial cancer risk.

 

Option D) Nulliparity. Nulliparity (having no children) is a risk factor for endometrial cancer because it is associated with a higher cumulative exposure to estrogen over a woman's lifetime without the interruption of ovulation that occurs during pregnancy. However, this patient is already G5P5 (gravida 5, para 5), indicating she has had five pregnancies that resulted in births, so she is not nulliparous. Therefore, nulliparity cannot be an intervention for her.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to behavioural changes. The mother says, "He has always been an active child and can be loud at times; however, over the past few months, he has been more irritable. He usually gets along well with his classmates but got into a fight with one last week". The mother also notes that the patient gets upset in the mornings because he does not want to go to school. Since the starting of third grade 6 months ago, his academic performance has declined, and he has been having below average grades. A progress report from his teacher states that he does not participate in group activities and is unable to complete class assignments on time. When interviewed privately, the patient reports that his classmates call him a baby because he uses his fingers to count and reads slowly. He has no significant medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits; height and weight curves are tracking consistently. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Specific learning disorder

 

 

  • This patient's academic difficulties and behavioural issues related to school are most likely due to a specific learning disorder. 
  • Learning disorders are characterized by difficulty acquiring one or more core academic skills (e.g., reading, writing, and/or mathematics) and manifest as academic achievement below the individual's potential. 
  • Learning disorders frequently come to attention with the stress of increasing academic demands and can contribute to the development of a negative self-concept, social anxiety, and behavioural issues. 
  • This patient's embarrassment at being a slow reader and using fingers to count are likely contributing to his reluctance to go to school, lack of class participation, irritability, and uncharacteristic conflict with peers.
  • Learning disorders should be considered in any child with academic, behavioural, or social difficulties at school. 
  • Comprehensive evaluation includes educational testing, hearing and vision assessment, and ruling out other psychiatric (e.g., anxiety, depression, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) or neurologic/chromosomal disorders. 
  • Early intervention (e.g., quality instruction, academic support and accommodations) can be helpful in improving self-esteem and social skills and preventing further academic decline.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) ADHD. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder can cause a decline in academic performance (e.g., due to inattention) and associated behavioural difficulties. However, diagnosis requires a pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity across at least 2 settings, whereas this patient's behavioural issues are limited to the school setting.

 

Option B) Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of irritability, defiant behaviour, and vindictiveness. This patient's behaviours are triggered in the school setting when his academic weaknesses are revealed. There is no indication that he is routinely defiant or argumentative.

 

Option C) Social anxiety disorder. This patient's reluctance to go to school and discomfort around his peers are most likely secondary to fears of being teased about his learning difficulties. Social anxiety disorder is not diagnosed when anxiety and avoidance behaviour are better explained by another disorder.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A specific learning disorder (difficulties with key academic skills: reading, writing, and math) should be considered a diagnostic possibility in any school-aged child with academic, behavioural, or social difficulties at school. 
  • Early intervention can be helpful in improving self-esteem, social skills, and preventing further academic decline.

questions.text: A patient has a point mutation at a specific site which results in disruption of the α-helical structure in a segment of the resultant mutant protein. The most likely change that can occur in the primary structure of this mutant protein is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methionine to proline


The α-helix is a secondary structure of proteins stabilized mainly by hydrogen bonds between backbone atoms. Certain amino acids can disrupt this structure:

  • Proline is known as a helix breaker
  • Structure: Its side chain is covalently bonded to the nitrogen of its amino group, forming a rigid ring.
  • Effect: This rigidity prevents the nitrogen from forming the hydrogen bond needed for α-helix stability, introducing a kink in the helix.
  • Result: Replacement of another amino acid (like methionine) with proline disrupts the α-helix.
     

Other options:

  • Option A. Glutamate → Aspartate
    • Both are acidic amino acids with similar size and charge — minimal effect on α-helix stability.
  • Option B. Lysine → Arginine
    • Both are basic and positively charged — substitution would not significantly disturb the α-helix.
  • Option D. Valine → Leucine
    • Both are non-polar, branched-chain amino acids — similar properties, unlikely to disrupt the α-helix.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The educational objective here is to understand how specific amino acid changes can affect protein structure. 


Mutations that disrupt α-helical structures often involve amino acids like proline, which can introduce structural irregularities due to its rigid cyclic side chain.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, P2L2, is in the postpartum unit after an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery with involuntary dribbling of small amounts of urine. It has been 6 hours since the delivery and the patient has been unable to empty her bladder. During labor, she received epidural anesthesia for severe pain with contractions and her bladder was intermittently catheterized. The patient has no chronic medical conditions, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows a firm uterine fundus palpable at the umbilicus and fullness and tenderness above the pubic symphysis. The perineum and vagina are edematous but without lacerations. Sensation is intact in the lower extremities, but the patient is unable to void a measurable amount. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urethral catheterization

 

  • Postpartum urinary retention can occur due to several factors, including the effects of epidural anesthesia, trauma during delivery leading to swelling and pain, and the temporary impairment of bladder sensation or contractility.
  • Urethral catheterization is the immediate and standard management to relieve the bladder, prevent over distension, and reduce the risk of urinary tract infections or long-term bladder dysfunction.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Oxybutynin therapy. Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication used to treat overactive bladder symptoms, such as urgency and frequency, not urinary retention. It would not be appropriate in this acute postpartum setting.

 

Option B) Pessary placement. A pessary is a device inserted into the vagina to support pelvic organs and manage pelvic organ prolapse or stress urinary incontinence. It is not indicated for acute urinary retention.

 

Option C) Suprapubic catheterization. While this is an alternative method to relieve urinary retention, it is more invasive than urethral catheterization and typically reserved for situations where urethral catheterization is not possible or has failed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize and manage acute urinary retention in the postpartum period. Urethral catheterization is the immediate and standard treatment to relieve retention, prevent bladder over distension, and avoid further complications. It is important to assess and monitor postpartum women for urinary retention, especially those who have had regional anesthesia during labor.

questions.text: Dr. Patel is reviewing the imaging studies of a 52-year-old male patient, Mr. Ram, who has been suffering from episodic severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for several years. The patient has a history of heavy alcohol use and recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. Recently, Mr. Ram has reported increased frequency and intensity of his abdominal pain, accompanied by weight loss and diarrhea, prompting further evaluation. A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan is performed, which shows diffuse pancreatic parenchymal atrophy, extensive intraductal and parenchymal calcifications, and a dilated pancreatic duct with irregular contours. There are no signs of acute inflammation or necrosis. Based on the patient's history and imaging findings, Dr. Patel is considering the diagnosis of a chronic pancreatic condition. Considering Mr. Ram's clinical history and the CT scan findings, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the imaging results?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic relapsing pancreatitis

 

  • Chronic relapsing pancreatitis is characterized by progressive inflammatory changes in the pancreas that lead to permanent structural damage, which can manifest as atrophy, calcifications, and ductal changes described in imaging.
  • The patient's history of heavy alcohol use and recurrent acute pancreatitis episodes supports this diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Pancreatic cystadenoma. This benign tumor would typically present as a well-defined cystic lesion in the pancreas and would not cause the diffuse changes or calcifications associated with chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option B) Pancreatic adenocarcinoma. While pancreatic cancer can cause ductal irregularities and atrophy, it usually presents as a more focal mass with possible obstruction of the pancreatic or bile duct, leading to jaundice. The diffuse calcifications and the absence of a mass lesion make adenocarcinoma less likely.

 

Option D) Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. These tumors are often well-defined masses that may appear hypervascular on contrast-enhanced imaging. The diffuse nature of the changes seen in Mr. Ram's pancreas, along with the extensive calcifications, does not fit the typical presentation of a neuroendocrine tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the imaging findings and clinical presentation of chronic relapsing pancreatitis, which include diffuse pancreatic parenchymal atrophy, intraductal and parenchymal calcifications, and a dilated pancreatic duct with irregular contours. The condition is often associated with a history of heavy alcohol use and recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis.

choices.text: Located between 5 cm and 1 cm above GE junction
Located between 2 cm above and 1 cm below GE junction
Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction
Located between 1 cm above and 1 cm below GE junction

questions.text: Which of these represents true GE junction tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction

 

  • Sievart’s classification of GE junction tumors (adenocarcinomas):
    • Sievart type 2 are true GE junction tumors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer presents with pulmonary symptoms including a productive cough and chest pain. A CT scan reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. A sputum sample is obtained, and microscopy shows hyphal elements that fragment into rectangular arthroconidia. Which of the following types of fungal spores is most likely observed under the microscope?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthrospores

 

  • Arthrospores are formed by the fragmentation of hyphae into single, rectangular units that are resistant and can be inhaled, leading to infection.
  • This is characteristic of fungi such as Coccidioides species, which can cause pulmonary cavitary lesions and are often associated with agricultural work in endemic areas.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Conidiospores are asexual fungal spores that are not formed by fragmentation of hyphae and are typically seen in Molds such as Aspergillus species.

 

Option C) Basidiospores are produced by Basidiomycetes, which include mushrooms and are not typically associated with human disease.

 

Option D) Ascospores are produced within an ascus by Ascomycetes and are not typically associated with the direct fragmentation of hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SPORES PRODUCED BY MEDICALLY IMPORTANT FUNGI

questions.text: Class I antiarrhythmics are sodium channel blockers that slow or block cardiac conduction, especially in depolarized cells. Which of the following antiarrhythmics will increase both the action potential and the effective refractory period?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Procainamide

 

  • Procainamide is a Class IA antiarrhythmic agent.
  • It blocks sodium channels and also has potassium channel blocking effects, which leads to an increase in the action potential duration and the effective refractory period.
  • Thus, procainamide fits the description of increasing both the APD and ERP.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Propafenone. Propafenone is primarily a Class IC antiarrhythmic, known for its potent sodium channel blocking effects that result in significant slowing of conduction. It has only a minor effect on the action potential duration and does not significantly increase the ERP.

 

Option B) Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a Class IB antiarrhythmic. It shortens the action potential duration and is used especially in acute ventricular arrhythmias, particularly post-MI, and in digitalis-induced arrhythmias.

 

Option D) Encainide. Encainide is a Class IC antiarrhythmic drug. It markedly slows conduction through the heart but has minimal effect on the action potential duration or the effective refractory period. Therefore, it would not be expected to increase both the APD and ERP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the classification of Class I antiarrhythmic drugs and their effects on the action potential duration and effective refractory period. Class IA agents, like procainamide, not only block sodium channels but also have a moderate potassium channel blocking effect, leading to an increase in both the action potential duration and the effective refractory period. This is in contrast to Class IB and IC agents, which do not have this combined effect.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of a painless, progressively enlarging mass in the central aspect of the upper eyelid. This has resulted in distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common eyelid malignancy.
  • It often presents as a painless, slow-growing mass with features like distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes.
  • BCC is associated with sun exposure and typically occurs in older individuals, making it a fitting choice given the presented scenario.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Sebaceous gland carcinoma. This type of carcinoma arises from the sebaceous glands, usually in the eyelid. It can cause a firm, painless mass but typically presents with other signs like irregular blood vessels, ulceration, and may involve the conjunctiva. Given the specific details provided, it seems less likely.

 

Option B) Squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma can occur on the eyelid, causing a non-healing ulcer or nodule. It is often associated with sun exposure. However, the description of a painless, progressively enlarging mass with distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes might not align perfectly with the typical presentation of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Option C) Amelanotic melanoma. Melanomas are known for pigment production, but amelanotic melanomas lack typical pigmentation. They can present as a mass on the eyelid, and the absence of pigmentation might make them appear pink or skin-coloured. While they can be painless and grow, the lack of mention of pigment in the provided information makes it less likely.

 

  • Considering the specific details of a painless, progressively enlarging mass in the upper eyelid with distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes, option D) Basal cell carcinoma appears to be the most likely diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The educational objective is to evaluate the understanding of different eyelid malignancies, their characteristic features, and the ability to differentiate between them based on clinical presentation. It tests the knowledge of common signs and symptoms associated with specific types of eyelid tumors

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents with painful uterine contractions. She also complains of minimal vaginal blood mixed with some mucus. Which of the following describes the most likely etiology of her bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bloody show

 

  • Bloody show is a common occurrence towards the end of pregnancy or during early labor, characterized by the passage of a small amount of blood or blood-tinged mucus.
  • This happens as the cervix begins to dilate and efface, causing the mucus plug that blocked the cervical opening during pregnancy to be discharged.
  • The presence of blood is typically due to the rupture of small cervical capillaries as the cervix dilates.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Placenta previa. This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervical os. It is typically associated with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding. The presentation described does not fit placenta previa, especially since painful contractions are more typical of labor or placental abruption.

 

Option B) Placenta abruption. Placental abruption involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall and can lead to dark red vaginal bleeding. It is often accompanied by abdominal pain, but the bleeding is usually more significant than what is described as "minimal" in this case.

 

Option D) Vasa previa. This rare condition occurs when fetal blood vessels cross or run near the internal os of the cervix beneath the fetal presenting part. It can lead to fetal vessels rupturing, resulting in painless vaginal bleeding that is typically significant and accompanied by fetal distress, which is not described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand that bloody show is a common and normal occurrence towards the end of pregnancy or during early labor, characterized by minimal vaginal bleeding mixed with mucus, signifying cervical dilation and effacement. It is important to differentiate it from other causes of antepartum hemorrhage, such as placenta previa, placental abruption, and vasa previa, based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing the vitreous humor in determining the post-mortem interval. Which constituent of the vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the post-mortem interval?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) K

 

  • Potassium (K) levels in the vitreous humor are particularly useful in estimating the post-mortem interval. 
  • The potassium concentration at the time of death is 5 to 8 mmol/l.
  • The rise of potassium concentration per hour is 0.17 to 0.238 mmol per hour.
  • The reason for varying range may be due to electrolyte imbalances at the time of death.
  • The variation between the two eyes may be up to 10%.
  • There is a linear relationship between vitreous potassium concentration and time elapsed after death up to 120 hours.
  • The 95% limits of confidence are ±20 hours up to 100 hours.
  • The rise is mainly due to diffusion from the retina into the centre of the globe.
  • Temperature, chillness, and urea retention affect the range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Sodium levels change post-mortem but are not as reliable as potassium for estimating time since death. Sodium decreases by about 0.9 mmol/l/h after death.

 

Option C) Chlorides level decreases by rate of less than 1 mmol/l/h in post-mortem period but are not as useful as potassium levels for this purpose.

 

Option D) The vitreous glucose usually falls after death and can reach zero within a few hours. A vitreous glucose of more than 11.1 mmol/l indicates diabetes, and less than 1.4 mmol/1 of hypoglycaemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A steady rise in the potassium values occur in the vitreous humour after death up to 100 hours.

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department after having a seizure in day care. The staff reports that "she suddenly fell down and started shaking," but they also note that the patient has seemed quieter and has repeatedly pulled at her hair over the past month. The patient's mother says, "My daughter used to say 'mama' and 'papa' and babble away but has begun to talk less in the past few months. She's also become more needy, wanting me to feed her rather than using a spoon herself". Medical history is significant for 3 ear infections in the past year and another seizure thought to have been febrile in origin. Family history is significant for early-onset Alzheimer disease in the patient's paternal grandfather and retinoblastoma in a paternal cousin. The patient is afebrile, and other vital signs are normal. On physical examination, the patient makes eye contact with the physician but speaks no words. She is noted to have a lurching gait. Which of the following would most likely establish a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA analysis

 

 

  • This patient's speech regression, loss of purposeful hand movements, gait disturbance, and seizures are key features of Rett syndrome (RS).
  • RS is an X-linked genetic disorder that occurs mainly in girls and is characterized by neurodevelopmental regression at age 6-18 months after a period of normal development. 
  • In addition to loss of purposeful hand movements (e.g., inability to feed herself, stereotypical movements such as hair-pulling) and gait disturbances (e.g., lurching gait), other findings can include seizures, which occur in the majority of patients (like this girl), as well as breathing abnormalities (e.g., hyperventilation, hypoventilation) and autistic behaviours. 
  • Deceleration of head growth is also an early sign of disease.
  • Evaluation of any child with neurodevelopmental regression should include a DNA analysis to identify pathogenic mutations. 
  • A diagnosis of RS is confirmed if an MECP2 gene mutation is detected in a patient with characteristic clinical features. 
  • Further genetic testing may be required to identify rare mutations in other genes if MECP2 analysis is negative.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Enzyme analysis (e.g., hexosaminidase A, sphingomyelinase) is performed for a suspected lysosomal storage disease such as Tay-Sachs or Niemann-Pick, which can cause neurodevelopmental regression, particularly of motor skills. However, presentation is typically before age 6 months, and repetitive hand movements (i.e., hair-pulling) would not be expected.

 

Option C) MRI brain. Although MRI of the head is frequently a part of the workup for neurodevelopmental disorders and seizures, imaging would not establish the diagnosis of RS because findings are generally non-specific (e.g., cerebral hypoplasia).

 

Option D) Ophthalmologic examination. A friable, white retinal mass on ophthalmologic evaluation can confirm the diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Although a positive family history increases the risk, retinoblastoma causes leukocoria, strabismus, and nystagmus. These signs are not seen in this patient, whose neurologic deterioration is consistent with RS, a condition not associated with ophthalmologic abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rett syndrome occurs mainly in girls and is characterized by neurodevelopmental regression (i.e., loss of speech and purposeful hand movements, gait disturbance) after a period of normal development. 
  • Seizures are also common, and a MECP2 mutation on DNA analysis confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with atherosclerotic heart disease has increasing lethargy for the past 5 years. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show serum creatinine of 6 mg/dL and urea nitrogen of 64 mg/dL. He has the microscopic appearance in his kidneys seen here. Which of the following findings on urinalysis is most specific for the underlying disease leading to this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microalbuminuria

 

  • Microalbuminuria refers to the presence of small amounts of albumin in the urine, and it is often associated with diabetic nephropathy and hypertension-related kidney damage.
  • In this case, the patient has a history of atherosclerotic heart disease, and the elevated blood pressure is a significant clue.
  • Hypertensive nephropathy is a common cause of chronic kidney disease in individuals with hypertension, and microalbuminuria is a specific marker for hypertensive nephropathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) WBC casts. White blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine are typically associated with acute pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis. They are not specific for the underlying disease in this case, which is chronic in nature.

 

Option B) Uric acid crystals. Uric acid crystals in the urine can be seen in conditions like gout or tumor lysis syndrome, but they are not specific for the underlying disease leading to chronic kidney disease in this patient.

 

Option C) CMV inclusions. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) inclusions in the renal tissue are associated with CMV nephritis, which can occur in immunocompromised individuals, but this is not the most likely underlying disease leading to chronic kidney disease in a patient with atherosclerotic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the importance of microalbuminuria as a specific marker for underlying kidney disease, particularly in the context of hypertension-related kidney damage, such as hypertensive nephropathy. Microalbuminuria refers to the presence of small amounts of albumin (a protein) in the urine and is often an early sign of kidney damage. It is specific to renal pathology and can indicate underlying conditions such as hypertensive nephropathy, diabetic nephropathy, or other kidney diseases. In this case, the patient's elevated blood pressure and atherosclerotic heart disease increase the likelihood of hypertensive nephropathy as the underlying cause of his kidney damage, making microalbuminuria a relevant and specific finding on urinalysis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a sudden onset of severe pain in her left eye with blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms began a few minutes ago, while she was watching a movie in a nearby theatre. Her temperature is 36.8⁰C (98.4⁰F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination reveals decreased visual acuity. Her left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated, fixed pupil. Her left eye is stony hard to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute angle closure glaucoma

 

  • Description: A rapid increase in eye pressure due to fluid build-up when the drainage angle of the eye becomes blocked.
  • Relevance: This condition presents with sudden onset of severe eye pain, blurred vision, redness, a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, dilated and fixed pupil, and a hard eye upon palpation. These symptoms align closely with the patient's presentation.
  • Based on the sudden onset of severe pain, blurred vision, red and hard eye, hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated, fixed pupil, the most likely diagnosis is Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma.
