  • This is an ocular emergency requiring immediate treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Primary Open Angle Glaucoma.

 

  • Description: A chronic condition where increased pressure in the eye leads to gradual vision loss.
  • Relevance: This type of glaucoma typically has a slow onset and lacks acute symptoms like severe pain, redness, or a hazy cornea.

 

Option B) Conjunctivitis.

 

  • Description: Commonly known as pink eye, it's an inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid.
  • Relevance: Conjunctivitis can cause redness and discomfort, but it doesn’t usually lead to severe pain, nausea, vomiting, or the specific eye findings described here.

 

Option D) Anterior Uveitis.

 

  • Description: Inflammation of the middle layer of the eye.
  • Relevance: While it can cause redness and pain, the acute onset of severe symptoms and the specific eye findings (like the hazy cornea and hard eye) are more indicative of acute angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point here is recognizing the signs and symptoms of acute angle closure glaucoma, a true eye emergency. It's characterized by a sudden increase in intraocular pressure resulting in severe eye pain, redness, blurred vision, a hazy cornea, and a dilated, non-reactive pupil. Immediate medical intervention is necessary to prevent irreversible damage to the optic nerve and permanent vision loss.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of Kangaroo Mother Care?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

 

  • Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, and exclusive breastfeeding are components of Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).
  • Eligibility criteria for KMC:
  1. Indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies.
  2. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy.
  3. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.
    •  
    • Birthweight < 1200g: It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
    • Birthweight 1200-1800g: Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
    • Birthweight > 1800g: KMC can be initiated immediately after birth
  4. All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.
  • Positioning for KMC:

 

  • The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position.
  • The hips are abducted and flexed in 'frog position' and the arms are also flexed.
  • The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium.
  • In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.
  • Components of KMC:
  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the baby on the mother's chest
  • Exclusive breastfeeding
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care
  • Support for the mother and her family for taking care of the baby
  • Duration of KMC:
    •  
    • Gradually increase from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.
    • KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Other details:
    •  
    • Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birth weight babies.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man visited his primary care physician one month ago because of chest pain that he had experienced four times in the past four months. The onset of the pain is sudden and radiates to his left jaw. He has experienced this pain while watching television but has never felt it during exercise. During last month’s visit, the physician prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin, and the patient reports that this has shortened the duration of his episodes. Last month’s ECG is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s chest pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prinzmetal’s angina

 

  • Prinzmetal's angina, also known as vasospastic angina, is characterized by transient coronary artery spasms that can lead to chest pain.
  • It often occurs at rest and can be relieved by nitroglycerin.
  • ECG changes during an episode may show transient ST-segment elevation, which is consistent with vasospasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Myocardial Infarction. Myocardial infarction (heart attack) is typically characterized by a prolonged and severe chest pain that often occurs with exertion. It is associated with ECG changes such as ST-segment elevation, which is not evident in the provided ECG.

 

Option B) Pericarditis. Pericarditis can cause chest pain, but it is often described as sharp and pleuritic (worsened by breathing or lying down). It may be associated with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation. The ECG does not show specific changes associated with pericarditis.

 

Option D) Stable Angina. Stable angina typically presents with chest pain (angina) that occurs predictably with exertion and is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. It is not associated with significant ECG changes at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to familiarize individuals with the different potential causes of chest pain, emphasizing the need for clinical evaluation, ECG interpretation, and diagnostic tests to determine the underlying etiology.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman visits her gynaecologist for a routine check-up and to discuss birth control options. She expresses interest in combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) but is also curious about their additional health benefits beyond contraception. The gynaecologist explains that combined OCPs not only prevent pregnancy but also offer several other health advantages. Based on current medical knowledge, which of the following benefits can be attributed to the use of combined oral contraceptive pills?

  1. Reduction in the risk of hepatocellular adenoma
  2. Decreased risk of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  3. Prevention of ovarian cysts
  4. Alleviation of symptoms of fibrocystic breast disease
  5. Lowered risk of ectopic pregnancy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, and 5

  • The gynaecologist explains that combined oral contraceptive pills offer several health benefits beyond contraception.
    1.  
    2. Decreased risk of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). Combined OCPs help reduce the risk of PID. The hormones in the pills thicken the cervical mucus, which acts as a barrier to bacteria, thereby reducing the likelihood of bacteria ascending from the vagina into the upper reproductive tract.
    3. Prevention of ovarian cysts. OCPs suppress ovulation, which can prevent the formation of certain types of ovarian cysts, particularly functional cysts.
    4. Alleviation of symptoms of fibrocystic breast disease. Women taking combined OCPs often experience relief from the symptoms of fibrocystic breast disease due to the hormonal regulation provided by the pills.
    5. Lowered risk of ectopic pregnancy. By preventing ovulation, combined OCPs significantly reduce the chance of an ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduction in the risk of hepatocellular adenoma. This is not a benefit of OCP use. In fact, long-term use of oral contraceptives has been associated with a slightly increased risk of benign liver tumours.

 

Educational objective:

 

COMBINED OCPs AND CARCINOGENESIS:

 

  • Reduction in cancers: Ovarian cancer, Endometrial cancer, Fibrocystic disease of breast, Cystic disease of ovary
  • Increase in cancers: Breast cancer, Cervical cancer
  • Beneficial effects of Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs):
    • Benign breast disorders (Fibrocystic disease, Fibroadenoma)
    • Benign ovarian disease (Ovarian cysts)
    • Malignant ovarian disease (Ovarian cancer)
    • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Iron deficiency anemia
    • Endometrial cancer

questions.text: A 67-year-old man previously diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma complains of severe shortness of breath when he walks or climbs stairs. Examination reveals regular venous pressure of 18 cmH2O, bi-basilar rales, an S3 gallop, and 2+ lower-extremity edema. His physician suspects an adverse effect of treatment is causing this patient’s symptoms. The pharmacologic agent most likely responsible for the symptoms in this patient has the same mechanism of action as which of the following cancer drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doxorubicin

 

  • Doxorubicin is an anthracycline antibiotic that intercalates into DNA and inhibits the enzyme topoisomerase II, leading to breaks in DNA strands and cell death.
  • Doxorubicin is well-known for its cardiotoxic effects, which can range from acute changes to chronic dose-dependent cardiomyopathy.
  • Given the patient's presentation with heart failure symptoms and a history of cancer treatment, doxorubicin is the most likely culprit.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cisplatin.

 

  • Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug that forms covalent bonds with DNA, leading to DNA cross-links and inhibiting DNA replication and transcription in rapidly dividing cancer cells.
  • Cardiotoxicity: Cisplatin is not typically associated with cardiotoxicity.
  • Its main adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, neurotoxicity, and gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option B) Cyclophosphamide.

 

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that cross-links DNA strands, preventing DNA replication and transcription in cancer cells.
  • Cardiotoxicity: Cyclophosphamide can cause cardiotoxicity, especially at high doses or with prolonged use. Cardiac side effects may include myocarditis, pericarditis, and congestive heart failure.

 

Option D) Methotrexate.

 

  • Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, interfering with the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins in rapidly dividing cells.
  • Cardiotoxicity: Methotrexate is not typically associated with cardiotoxicity. Its side effects are more commonly related to bone marrow suppression, hepatotoxicity, and gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the cardiotoxic effects of chemotherapeutic agents, particularly doxorubicin, an anthracycline antibiotic. Doxorubicin's mechanism of action involves intercalation into DNA and inhibition of topoisomerase II, leading to DNA damage and cell death. However, its use is limited by its dose-dependent cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as acute changes or chronic cardiomyopathy. Recognizing the signs and symptoms of cardiotoxicity in patients previously treated with doxorubicin is crucial for timely management and intervention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from Delhi with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. On examination, he is found to have photophobia and a positive Brudzinski's sign. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows an elevated protein level with a low glucose concentration. India has a high prevalence of tuberculosis; however, fungal infections are also considered in differential diagnosis due to his immunocompromised state. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the causative agent in this patient's CSF?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) India ink preparation

 

  • India ink preparation is used to visualize Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that can cause meningitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.
  • The test takes advantage of the organism's thick polysaccharide capsule, which does not take up the ink, resulting in a clear halo around the yeast cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Ziehl-Neelsen stain. This is typically used to identify acid-fast bacilli, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and would not be appropriate for detecting Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Option C) Gram stain. While Gram stain can identify a variety of bacteria, it is not the best choice for fungi as the thick capsule of Cryptococcus may resist staining.

 

Option D) KOH preparation. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used for detecting fungal elements in skin, nails, and hair but is not the optimal choice for visualizing Cryptococcus in CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate diagnostic tests for identifying infectious agents in the CSF of an immunocompromised patient is India ink preparation.
  • India ink preparation is a specific test for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a common cause of meningitis in HIV/AIDS patients.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple blood stains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the blood stains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spectroscopic test

 

  • Spectroscopic method is the most delicate and reliable test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains (can provide information about the age of the stains).
  • Less than 0.1 mg of blood is sufficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Luminol test. This is a presumptive test that can detect trace amounts of blood by producing a chemiluminescent glow. It is sensitive but not specific for blood, and it doesn't provide information about the age of the stain.

 

Option B) Benzidine test. It's an older test that is no longer used due to its potential to cause cancer. It is a colour test that would turn blue in the presence of blood. It is also a presumptive test, sensitive but not specific.

 

Option C) O-tolidine test. This is another colour test used for presumptive identification of blood. Like the Benzidine test, it is not as specific or informative regarding the age of the blood stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood stains can be identified by following tests:

questions.text: A 45-year-old shepherd presents with persistent abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. He reports frequent contact with dogs on his farm. An ultrasound of his abdomen shows multiple cystic lesions in the liver. Blood tests reveal eosinophilia. Considering his occupational history and clinical presentation, the location of the adult worms of the parasite causing his condition needs to be identified. What can be the potential location of the adult worms of the parasite in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dog’s intestine

 

  • Adult worms of Echinococcus granuloses primarily reside in the intestines of definitive hosts, which are typically dogs.
  • Humans are intermediate hosts and develop cystic echinococcosis (hydatid disease) mainly in the liver, as seen in this patient, after ingesting eggs shed in the faeces of infected dogs.

 

 

A. Hydatid cyst Macroscopic specimen; B. Surgically excised cyst from Liver; C. Adult worm (schematic) 

 

 

CT scan showing calcifying hydatid cyst in the liver

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Human’s intestine. Humans are intermediate hosts; they develop cysts, not adult worms.

 

Option C) Human’s liver. Humans develop cysts in the liver, but adult worms do not reside there.

 

Option D) Dog’s liver. Dogs, as definitive hosts, harbour adult worms in their intestines, not the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ​​Dogs serve as the definitive hosts for these parasites, harbouring the adult worms in their intestines.
  • Humans, as intermediate hosts, can develop cystic echinococcosis (hydatid disease), primarily in the liver, after ingesting eggs from the faeces of infected dogs.
  • This is consistent with the patient's condition, where liver cysts were observed.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the primary care office because she has had worsening numbness and tingling in her right hand over the past four months. During the past week, she also has had shooting pains from the wrist to the hand that wakens her from sleep. On physical examination, results of Phalen and Tinel tests are positive. Which of the following studies of the wrists and hands is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nerve conduction studies

 

  • This test measures the speed of electrical impulses through the nerves.
  • In the context of carpal tunnel syndrome, it can specifically assess the function of the median nerve and is considered the gold standard for diagnosing this condition.
  • It can quantify the degree of nerve impairment.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) CT Scan. Computed tomography (CT) scans provide excellent detail of the bones and joints but are less effective for assessing soft tissues like nerves. It is not the preferred method for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves compression of the median nerve.

 

Option B) MRI. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is very effective for visualizing soft tissue and can detect changes in the wrist structure and surrounding tissues. While it can be used in the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome, it is not typically the first-line diagnostic tool due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to other methods.

 

Option D) Ultrasonography. Ultrasound can visualize the median nerve and can be used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome by measuring the size of the nerve and observing its movement. However, it is less definitive and operator-dependent compared to nerve conduction studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerve conduction studies are the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirming carpal tunnel syndrome, as they specifically assess the function of the median nerve and can quantify the degree of nerve impairment. This helps in distinguishing carpal tunnel syndrome from other conditions that might cause similar symptoms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain started 2 hours ago while he was watching television. His medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On examination, his blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, heart rate is 98 bpm, and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. His physical examination is unremarkable except for mild tenderness over the chest wall. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops are noted on auscultation. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no abnormalities. A chest radiograph is ordered. Which of the following findings on the chest radiograph is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Widened mediastinum

 

  • A widened mediastinum on chest radiograph is a classic finding in patients with aortic dissection, as the dissection can cause an apparent enlargement of the aortic silhouette due to the presence of a false lumen created by the dissection of blood between the layers of the aortic wall.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Enlarged cardiac silhouette. This finding is more suggestive of conditions leading to cardiomegaly, such as heart failure or pericardial effusion, rather than aortic dissection.

 

Option B) Kerley B lines. These are indicative of pulmonary edema, which might be seen in acute heart failure but is not a specific finding associated with aortic dissection.

 

Option D) Pleural effusion. While pleural effusion can occur in many conditions, including some cardiovascular diseases, it is not a specific finding for aortic dissection and would not be the most likely finding given the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the classic presentation and radiographic findings of aortic dissection. A widened mediastinum on chest radiograph is a key finding that should raise suspicion for aortic dissection in patients presenting with sudden onset severe chest pain, especially when the pain radiates to the back and is accompanied by significant hypertension.

choices.text: The statement X is true, the statement Y is false
The statement X is false, the statement Y is true
Both the statements X and Y are true
Both the statements X and Y are false

questions.text:
Statement X: The neuronal membrane permeability to sodium will be higher at resting conditions.

 

Statement Y: More calcium channels will remain open around the resting membrane potential of the neurons.

 

Which of the following holds right regarding these two statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the statements X and Y are false

 

  • The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the neurons will be around -70 mV (more negative inside) under physiological conditions.
  • This potential will be near to the equilibrium potential for the potassium ions.
  • More potassium channels (not calcium channels) will be open than sodium channels at rest, so the membrane permeability to potassium ions (not sodium ions as mentioned in the question) will be greater.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 90

choices.text: Acute myelogenous leukemia
Plasma cell leukemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has noted a progressively worsening cough for one month. On physical examination, a few small lymph nodes are palpable in his axillae, and the tip of the spleen is palpable. Laboratory studies show Hb of 10.2 g/dL, HCT of 31.1%, MCV of 90 fL, WBC count of 67,400/microliter, and platelet count of 36,220/microliter. His peripheral blood smear is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute myelogenous leukemia

 

  • The peripheral blood smear shows the presence of myeloblasts, which are immature myeloid cells, indicating a myeloid lineage involvement. AML is characterized by the proliferation of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow and peripheral blood.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Plasma cell leukemia. Plasma cell leukemia is characterized by the presence of a high number of abnormal plasma cells in the peripheral blood. This condition is typically associated with multiple myeloma, but it does not present with myeloblasts in the blood smear.

 

Option C) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL primarily involves the proliferation of small mature lymphocytes, which do not resemble the myeloblasts seen in the blood smear.

 

Option D) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). ALL is characterized by the proliferation of lymphoblasts, which are immature lymphoid cells, not myeloblasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to recognize the characteristic features of AML on peripheral blood smear, including the presence of myeloblasts. AML is a type of acute leukemia that involves the proliferation of immature myeloid cells, and identifying these cells in the peripheral blood smear is crucial for diagnosing the condition. Understanding the different types of leukemias and their associated blood smear findings is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is thrown from a motorcycle. He is taken to the emergency department, where he is alert and awake but in severe pain. On physical examination, he has very limited abduction of his left shoulder and flexion of his left elbow. On observation, the left shoulder is externally rotated. His forearm is pronated, and his elbow is extended. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Teres minor

 

  • The teres minor muscle is one of the rotator cuff muscles, responsible for shoulder external rotation.
  • In the context of Erb's palsy, which affects the C5 and C6 nerve roots, the teres minor can indeed be paralyzed, leading to the characteristic findings of limited abduction, external rotation, and elbow extension. Therefore, Teres minor is the correct answer.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Flexor carpi ulnaris. The flexor carpi ulnaris muscle is responsible for flexing the wrist. It is not directly involved in the described deficits of shoulder and elbow movement.

 

Option B) Flexor digitorum superficialis. The flexor digitorum superficialis muscle flexes the wrist and fingers. Like option A, it is not directly related to the deficits described in the patient.

 

Option C) Latissimus dorsi. The latissimus dorsi muscle is a large muscle of the back that plays a significant role in shoulder adduction, extension, and internal rotation. While it contributes to shoulder movement, it is not primarily responsible for the specific deficits of limited abduction, external rotation, and elbow flexion described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical findings associated with Erb's palsy, a brachial plexus injury, and understand which muscles are typically affected by this condition. Healthcare professionals should be able to differentiate between different nerve injuries and their associated muscle deficits to provide appropriate diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Closed reduction of the patella
Open reduction of the patella

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after she sustained an injury to the right knee while rollerblading. The patient says she felt sudden, severe pain in the knee when she turned a corner quickly. She fell to the ground and was unable to bear weight on the right leg. Physical examination shows swelling and deformity of the right knee as well as inability to fully extend and straighten the right lower extremity. X-ray studies show dislocation of the patella. In addition to administration of analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed reduction of the patella

 

  • This is the initial treatment of choice for an acute patellar dislocation.
  • It involves manually manipulating the patella back into its normal position.
  • It is a non-surgical method and is usually performed under analgesia to relieve pain and muscle spasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Arthroscopic Lateral Release. This procedure involves cutting the tight lateral structures to balance the patella within the trochlear groove. It's more commonly used in chronic patellar instability rather than acute dislocations.

 

Option B) Arthroscopic Medial Plication. This surgical procedure involves tightening the medial structures to stabilize the patella. Like the lateral release, it's typically indicated in cases of recurrent patellar instability, not for an acute dislocation.

 

Option D) Open Reduction of the Patella. This is a surgical approach used if closed reduction is unsuccessful or if there are associated injuries that need repair (such as osteochondral fractures). However, it's not typically the first line of treatment for an isolated acute patellar dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute patellar dislocation, closed reduction is the initial management of choice. Surgical interventions are typically reserved for cases where closed reduction is unsuccessful or for recurrent dislocations. Early and appropriate management is crucial for minimizing discomfort and preventing further injury.

choices.text: No effect on the Mesangium

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with concerns about high blood pressure and fluid retention. During the evaluation, the healthcare provider discusses the role of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP) in regulating Blood Pressure. What will be the effect of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide on the Mesangial Cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mesangial Relaxation

 

  • Mesangial cells are located in the glomerulus, a key component of the kidney responsible for filtering blood to form urine.
  • When ANP is released, it acts on mesangial cells and causes them to relax. This relaxation results in the dilation of the glomerular capillaries and an increase in the surface area available for filtration.
  • The increased surface area allows for more efficient filtration of blood plasma, which, in turn, leads to an increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This means that more fluid and solutes are filtered from the blood into the renal tubules for eventual excretion as urine.
  • By increasing GFR, ANP promotes the removal of excess fluid and sodium from the bloodstream, which helps reduce blood volume and blood pressure. This is a key mechanism for regulating blood pressure and preventing fluid overload in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ANP's primary effect on mesangial cells is to promote their relaxation, which, in turn, leads to increased GFR and helps maintain fluid and electrolyte balance in the body.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 678

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has been a cigarette smoker since the age of 18, averaging a pack a day of unfiltered cigarettes. She works as a dispatcher for a trucking company. She has had several episodes of hemoptysis in the past two weeks along with fatigue, headache, nausea, and anorexia. On physical examination, her sensorium is clouded. A chest radiograph shows an ill-defined hilar mass. A transbronchial lung biopsy is performed and the microscopic appearance is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyponatremia

 

  • These neoplastic cells have a small overall size, and the nuclei are markedly hyperchromatic and there is scant cytoplasm (high N/C ratio).
  • Their appearance is most characteristic for small cell anaplastic ('oat cell') carcinoma of the lung, which is a neuroendocrine carcinoma often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as the syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH).
  • Hyponatremia refers to a lower-than-normal concentration of sodium in the blood.
  • It can occur as a result of a paraneoplastic syndrome known as the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH) secretion, which is common in small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
  • SIADH causes the body to retain too much water, leading to dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Hypergammaglobulinemia.

 

  • Hypergammaglobulinemia refers to elevated levels of gamma globulins, which are a class of antibodies in the blood.
  • While it is possible for various conditions to cause an increase in gamma globulins, it is not a typical finding in SCLC or the associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Option C) Hyperbilirubinemia.

 

  • Hyperbilirubinemia is an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood and is often associated with liver or biliary problems.
  • It is not a typical finding in SCLC or its paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Option D) Hypercalcemia.

 

  • Hypercalcemia refers to an elevated level of calcium in the blood. While hypercalcemia can occur in various conditions, it is not typically associated with SCLC or its paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To emphasize the association between small cell lung cancer and the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH), which can lead to hyponatremia. Understanding the relationship between certain cancers and paraneoplastic syndromes is crucial for clinical diagnosis and management. Additionally, it's important to be aware that laboratory findings can provide valuable diagnostic clues when evaluating patients with suspected cancer-related complications.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no point of maximal impulse. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration of 19.3 μmol/L (N= 5-15). Serum lipid concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following amino acids is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is the amino acid directly involved in homocysteine metabolism.
  • Homocysteine can be remethylated to methionine in a reaction that requires methionine synthase, which depends on the coenzymes folate and vitamin B12.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in methionine or cofactors like folate and vitamin B12 can lead to elevated homocysteine levels.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Arginine.

 

  • Arginine is an amino acid, and it plays a role in the urea cycle and the synthesis of nitric oxide.
  • Elevated homocysteine levels can result from defects in enzymes related to the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine or from inadequate levels of cofactors like folate, vitamin B12, and pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6).
  • Arginine is not directly involved in homocysteine metabolism.

 

Option B) Leucine.

 

  • Leucine is one of the branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism.

 

Option C) Lysine.

 

  • Lysine is another amino acid and is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand the relationship between amino acids, specifically methionine, and homocysteine metabolism.
  • Recognizing that deficiencies in methionine or cofactors like folate and vitamin B12 can lead to elevated homocysteine levels is important for understanding the underlying mechanisms of hyperhomocysteinemia and its potential cardiovascular implications.
  • Monitoring and managing homocysteine levels can be a part of cardiovascular risk assessment and prevention.

choices.text: Blockade of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase resulting in increased cAMP levels
Inhibition of the degranulation of mast cells
Stimulation of adenylyl cyclase resulting in increased cAMP levels

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a 32-pack-year smoking history presents to his physician because of a 3-month history of productive cough. He is diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease after x-ray of the chest demonstrates hyperinflated lungs and a flattened diaphragm. The physician prescribes inhaled steroids, a β2- agonist, and ipratropium bromide. Ipratropium bromide will produce bronchodilation through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blockade of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors 

 

  • This is the correct mechanism of action for ipratropium bromide.
  • By blocking muscarinic receptors in the airways, ipratropium bromide reduces the bronchoconstrictive effect of acetylcholine, leading to bronchodilation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Inhibition of phosphodiesterase resulting in increased cAMP levels.  Phosphodiesterase inhibitors, such as theophylline, work by inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase, which leads to an increase in cAMP levels and subsequent bronchodilation. This is not the mechanism of action for ipratropium bromide.

 

Option C) Inhibition of the degranulation of mast cells. Agents that inhibit mast cell degranulation, such as cromolyn sodium, are used primarily for their anti-inflammatory effects in asthma to prevent allergic reactions. They do not directly cause bronchodilation through muscarinic blockade.

 

Option D) Stimulation of adenylyl cyclase resulting in increased cAMP levels. Beta-2 agonists work by stimulating adenylyl cyclase, which increases cAMP levels and leads to bronchodilation. While beta-2 agonists are part of the treatment prescribed to the patient, this is not how ipratropium bromide works.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the mechanism of action of ipratropium bromide in the treatment of COPD. Ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic agent that works by blocking muscarinic receptors in the airways, preventing acetylcholine-induced bronchoconstriction and leading to bronchodilation. This mechanism is distinct from other bronchodilators, such as beta-2 agonists, which work by stimulating adenylyl cyclase to increase cAMP levels.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with white, corrugated, non-removable lesions along the lateral borders of his tongue (as shown in image). 

 

 

These lesions are asymptomatic and were noted incidentally during a routine dental examination. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)

 

  • Oral hairy leukoplakia is an oral lesion that typically occurs in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV.
  • It is most commonly associated with EBV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Cytomegalovirus (CMV). CMV can cause disease in immunocompromised patients, but it is not commonly associated with oral hairy leukoplakia.

 

Option B) Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). While oral hairy leukoplakia is often seen in patients with HIV. It is EBV that directly causes the lesions.

 

Option D) Human Papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is associated with other oral lesions, such as squamous papillomas, but not with oral hairy leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • EBV causes oral hairy leukoplakia, an opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV, characterized by white patches on the lateral aspect of the tongue.

questions.text: Which method is not typically used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disk diffusion method

 

  • The disk diffusion method, also known as the Kirby-Bauer test, is used for antibiotic susceptibility testing but does not provide an MIC value.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Gradient diffusion method. Also known as the E-test, can be used to determine MIC.

 

Option B) Broth micro dilution method. Standard method for determining MIC. 

 

Option D) Agar dilution method. Quantitative method that can be used to determine MIC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MIC can be determined by Gradient diffusion method, Broth micro dilution method and Agar dilution method.

choices.text: Reassure patient and schedule regular follow-up

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of acne. The patient has seen several doctors over the past few years for his "huge pimples" and has tried multiple non-prescription acne preparations without benefit. He spends hours a day checking his skin in the mirror for new pimples and scars and researching the latest acne treatments. He avoids socializing and dating due to fears of being rejected based on his appearance. The patient purposely styles his hair to conceal his forehead and cheeks. He has no medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is wearing a baseball cap and hesitantly removes it. Physical examination shows a small papule on his forehead and a few closed comedones on his nose that are noticeable only on close inspection. His skin is otherwise clear without scarring or hyperpigmentation. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start escitalopram

 

  • This patient's preoccupation with perceived defect in his appearance and time consuming, repetitive behaviour is consistent with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).
  • Common manifestations of BDD include disliking perceived appearance flaws in the following:
    • Skin: as in this patient who is concerned about significant acne despite barely noticeable comedones with no scarring or hyperpigmentation.
    • Hair pattern: balding, too much hair
    • Nose: size, shape
  • Compulsions (e.g., repeatedly checking one's appearance in mirrors) are characteristic.
  • Patients with BDD typically have poor insight and often request unnecessary cosmetic and surgical treatments to correct perceived flaws.
  • Treatment options for BDD include pharmacotherapy with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) (e.g., escitalopram) and/or cognitive-behavioural therapy adapted for BDD.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Prescribe low-dose aripiprazole. Antipsychotic medications (e.g., aripiprazole) are used primarily in psychotic and bipolar disorders and are not first-line treatments for BDD. Patients with delusions involving perceived appearance flaws are diagnosed with BDD rather than delusional disorder and may have varying degrees of insight (e.g., BDD with absent insight/delusional beliefs, BDD with poor insight, BDD with good insight). SSRIs are first line in BDD, regardless of degree of insight.

 

Option B) Reassure patient and schedule regular follow-up. Reassurance and regular follow up are important components of managing somatic symptom disorder, characterized by preoccupation with physical symptoms (e.g., leg pain, dizziness, bloating), and of illness anxiety disorder, characterized by fears of a specific illness (e.g., cancer, lupus). In contrast, BDD is characterized by an excessive preoccupation with appearance flaws (e.g., acne, hair pattern) accompanied by compulsions; it requires high doses of SSRIs.

 

Option C) Refer for dermatology consult. Patients with BDD are rarely satisfied with cosmetic, medical, or surgical interventions. This patient has already seen several physicians and has only mild symptoms that do not warrant the intervention of a specialist. Referral to a dermatologist is not indicated.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment of body dysmorphic disorder consists of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and/or cognitive-behavioural therapy. Cosmetic treatments and surgery should be avoided.

choices.text: Prompt, high-dose (1 g/day) IV corticosteroid therapy is indicated to preserve vision.
Oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is started till the investigation reports are awaited.
Visual prognosis remains poor, regardless of intervention.
One should wait till visual acuity falls below 6/18, before planning any intervention.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female with no history of medical, ocular, or neurologic problems presents with pain on ocular rotation of the left eye, a mild visual loss for 4 days, decreased visual acuity of 6/9 OS, and a mild sense of colours being washed out in the left eye. Aside from mild relative central scotoma in the left eye and a left relative afferent pupillary defect (0.6 lac units), examination results are normal (All OD results are normal). She is not very bothered by her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prompt, high-dose (1 g/day) IV corticosteroid therapy is indicated to preserve vision.

 

  • ⁠This option is correct because optic neuritis, as suggested by the patient's symptoms, often benefits from high-dose corticosteroid therapy to reduce inflammation and improve visual outcomes.
  • Rapid initiation of treatment is crucial to prevent further damage to the optic nerve and promote recovery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is started till the investigation reports are awaited. Oral prednisone (1 mg/kg) is sufficient treatment because high-dose IV therapy provides no advantage in terms of visual outcome. This option is incorrect. Studies have shown that high-dose IV corticosteroid therapy is more effective than oral prednisone alone in accelerating visual recovery in optic neuritis cases.

 

Option C) Visual prognosis remains poor, regardless of intervention. ⁠This option is incorrect. Early intervention with corticosteroids has been shown to improve visual outcomes in optic neuritis cases, reducing the risk of long-term visual impairment.

 

Option D) One should wait till visual acuity falls before planning further intervention. ⁠This option is incorrect. Delaying treatment until visual acuity falls may lead to irreversible optic nerve damage. Optic neuritis should be addressed promptly to maximize the chances of recovery.

 

  • In summary, option A) is the most appropriate strategy, as it aligns with current medical recommendations for optic neuritis management.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with no significant medical history presents with a five-month history of persistent weakness despite taking vitamins and supplements. Physical examination is completely benign, with normal blood pressure and no peripheral edema. Laboratory studies show hyponatremia, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and an increased plasma renin level. Renal biopsy reveals juxtaglomerular cell hyperplasia. Which of the following diuretics acts at the same location as the defect in the patient’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Furosemide

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that works on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, where it inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter.
  • This action is similar to the defect in Bartter syndrome, which also involves impaired function in this part of the renal tubule.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Acetazolamide. This diuretic acts on the proximal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, leading to increased excretion of bicarbonate, sodium, and water. This mechanism and location of action do not match the defect in Bartter syndrome.

 

Option C) Hydrochlorothiazide. This diuretic acts on the distal convoluted tubule, where it inhibits the Na+/Cl- cotransporter, leading to increased sodium and water excretion. This action does not match the defect in Bartter syndrome, which is in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

 

Option D) Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts on the collecting ducts by antagonizing aldosterone, leading to increased sodium excretion and decreased potassium excretion. This action is not related to the defect in Bartter syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the pathophysiology of Bartter syndrome and its similarity to the action of loop diuretics like furosemide. Both Bartter syndrome and furosemide affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, leading to similar electrolyte disturbances and metabolic alkalosis. Recognizing the similarities between the effects of certain diuretics and inherited tubulopathies can aid in understanding the underlying mechanisms of these conditions.

choices.text: Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates
There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia
A rise in serum creatinine levels in pregnancy could be a sign of acute rejection
The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents at 10 weeks pregnant. She is a renal transplant recipient and had a transplant 3 years earlier. On examination, her BP is 130/ 80 mmHg. The ultrasound shows a single live fetus of 10 weeks. Which of the following is incorrect regarding pregnancy in a renal transplant patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

 

  • The rates of caesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys.
  • Although caesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications, occasionally the transplanted kidney obstructs labor, and the overall caesarean delivery rate approaches 80 percent.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates. This is a correct statement.

 

Option B: There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia. This is also true.

 

Option C: A rise in serum creatinine levels in pregnancy could be a sign of acute rejection. In a patient with a renal transplant, during pregnancy, if a significant rise in the serum creatinine level is detected, its cause must be determined. Possibilities include:

 

  • Acute rejection
  • Cyclosporine toxicity
  • Preeclampsia
  • Infection
  • Urinary tract obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREGNANCY IN WOMEN WITH RENAL TRANSPLANT

 

  • Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates.
  • Close surveillance is necessary.
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria is treated, and if it is recurrent, suppressive treatment is given for the remainder of the pregnancy.
  • Serial hepatic enzyme concentrations and blood counts are monitored for toxic effects of azathioprine and cyclosporine (if the patient is on these drugs).
  • Gestational diabetes is more common if corticosteroids are taken.
  • Preeclampsia is more common.
  • Surveillance for opportunistic infections from herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasmosis is important because these infections are common.
  • Renal function is monitored, and the GFR usually increases 20 to 25 percent.
  • If a significant rise in the serum creatinine level is detected, its cause must be determined. Possibilities include:
    • Acute rejection
    • Cyclosporine toxicity
    • Preeclampsia
    • Infection
    • Urinary tract obstruction
  • Evidence of pyelonephritis or graft rejection should prompt admission for aggressive management.
  • Imaging studies and kidney biopsy may be indicated.
  • The woman is carefully monitored for development or worsening of underlying hypertension, and especially of superimposed preeclampsia.
  • Vigilant fetal surveillance is indicated because of the higher incidences of fetal-growth restriction and preterm delivery.
  • Although cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications, occasionally the transplanted kidney obstructs labor, and the overall cesarean delivery rate approaches 80 percent.

choices.text: Decreased levels of angiotensin II
Increased levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is seen by his doctor after measuring his blood pressure at home and finding it to be 168/100 mm Hg. The patient is concerned because he has had high blood pressure for the past 12 months that has not improved with dietary changes, exercise, or medication. A physical examination is unremarkable except for a thrill heard when auscultating the abdomen just to the left of the midline. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevated levels of aldosterone

 

  • This is the most likely cause in this scenario.
  • Aldosterone, part of the RAAS, promotes sodium and water retention by the kidneys, leading to increased blood volume and blood pressure.
  • Renal artery stenosis can lead to elevated aldosterone levels due to the increased release of renin by the affected kidney, which stimulates the production of angiotensin II and, subsequently, aldosterone.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Decreased levels of ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone). ADH primarily affects water reabsorption in the kidneys and plays a role in blood pressure regulation. However, decreased levels would typically lead to diuresis and potentially lower blood pressure, not hypertension.

 

Option B) Decreased levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor and a key component of the RAAS, which increases blood pressure. Decreased levels would be expected to lower, not raise, blood pressure.

 

Option D) Increased levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). While ACE levels might be elevated in conditions that activate the RAAS, they are not typically measured in clinical practice for the diagnosis of hypertension. The role of ACE is to convert angiotensin I to angiotensin II. However, it is the effect of angiotensin II (and subsequently aldosterone) that is directly involved in the pathophysiology of hypertension related to renal artery stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the role of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system in secondary hypertension, particularly in the context of renal artery stenosis. Renal artery stenosis can lead to activation of the RAAS, resulting in elevated levels of aldosterone and subsequent sodium and water retention, which contributes to hypertension. Identifying physical examination findings, such as an abdominal thrill, can be crucial in suspecting and diagnosing renal artery stenosis as the underlying cause of secondary hypertension.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has a restricted diet that includes no fresh citrus fruits or leafy green vegetables. His teeth are loose and his gums bleed easily. This patient’s disorder most likely results from a defect in collagen synthesis that involves which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydroxyproline

 

  • The patient's symptoms of loose teeth, bleeding gums, and a restricted diet deficient in vitamin C are characteristic of scurvy, which results from a defect in collagen synthesis due to the lack of hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues, specifically hydroxyproline.
  • Hydroxyproline is a modified amino acid found in collagen.
  • It is formed by the hydroxylation of proline residues and is essential for collagen stability and structure.
  • Defects in hydroxyproline formation, which is vitamin C-dependent, can lead to collagen abnormalities seen in scurvy, such as loose teeth, bleeding gums, and impaired wound healing.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Arginine.

 

  • Arginine is an amino acid involved in protein synthesis and other metabolic processes but is not directly related to the hydroxylation of collagen.

 

Option B) Cysteine.

 

  • Cysteine is another amino acid used in protein synthesis and is also not directly related to collagen hydroxylation.

 

Option C) Histidine.

 

  • Histidine is an amino acid with various roles in enzyme catalysis and protein structure but is not involved in the hydroxylation of collagen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand the role of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) in collagen synthesis. Vitamin C is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen, particularly for the formation of hydroxyproline. A deficiency in vitamin C leads to the clinical manifestations of scurvy, which is characterized by impaired collagen synthesis and structural abnormalities in connective tissues.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a stab wound to the abdomen is taken to surgery. While repairing the small intestine, the surgeon notices the presence of a 1 cm circumscribed submucosal mass in the ileum. The lesion is resected and on gross examination, has a firm, yellow-tan cut surface. Microscopically, the mass is composed of nests of cells with uniform small round nuclei and cytoplasm with small purple granules. The cytoplasm is positive with antibody to chromogranin on immunohistochemical staining. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to accompany this man’s lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Another similar lesion

 

  • The presence of a submucosal mass in the ileum with nests of cells showing uniform small round nuclei, small purple granules in the cytoplasm, and positivity with chromogranin on immunohistochemical staining is highly suggestive of a neuroendocrine tumor (carcinoid tumor).
  • These tumors can occur at multiple sites in the gastrointestinal tract, and it's not uncommon for patients with one carcinoid tumor to have another lesion elsewhere in the GI tract.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Liver metastases. Liver metastases are not a typical finding associated with a primary submucosal mass in the ileum. Liver metastases usually occur when cancer cells from another primary site spread to the liver.

 

Option C) Multiple gastric ulcerations. Multiple gastric ulcerations are not directly related to a primary submucosal mass in the ileum. They may have a different etiology, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use.

 

Option D) Pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is a different type of cancer and is not typically associated with the described pathology in the ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the typical characteristics and distribution of neuroendocrine tumors (carcinoid tumors). Carcinoid tumors can occur at various sites along the gastrointestinal tract, and it is not uncommon for patients with one carcinoid tumor to develop another lesion in a different location within the GI tract. Recognizing this pattern can aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presented with headaches for the past month. On physical examination, she has no abnormal findings. A lumbar puncture is performed and examination of the CSF shows a protein of 82 mg/dL, glucose of 58 mg/dL (serum glucose of 74 mg/dL), and cell count with 2 mononuclear leukocytes/microliter. A head CT scan shows a discrete mass beneath the dura compressing the underlying right parietal region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meningioma

 

  • Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that originate from the meninges, the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • They are often located beneath the dura mater, and their slow growth can cause compression of adjacent brain tissue, leading to symptoms such as headaches.
  • The CSF findings in this case, including an elevated protein level and a mild increase in mononuclear leukocytes, are consistent with the presence of a mass effect in the brain.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Schwannoma. Schwannomas typically originate from Schwann cells and are more commonly associated with peripheral nerves rather than being located beneath the dura. They are less likely to present with the described CSF findings.

 

Option B) Ependymoma. Ependymomas are tumors that arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles of the brain or the central canal of the spinal cord. They are not typically located beneath the dura and may have different CSF findings.

 

Option D) Tuberculoma. Tuberculomas are lesions in the brain caused by tuberculosis infection. While they can present as discrete masses, they are typically associated with other clinical and imaging findings suggestive of tuberculosis infection, such as granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors that arise from the meninges and are often located beneath the dura mater.
  • They can cause symptoms due to compression of adjacent brain tissue, including headaches.
  • Meningiomas are typically benign tumors and are common in adults.

questions.text: A recent study investigated the relationship between maternal hypertension and the incidence of Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) in fetuses. The study reported an Odd’s Ratio (OR) of 1:5 for the likelihood of developing an IUGR fetus in the presence of maternal hypertension. How should this finding be interpreted in terms of the association between maternal hypertension and IUGR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inverse association

 

  • An Odd’s Ratio (OR) of 1:5 indicates that the odds of the outcome (IUGR) are lower in the presence of the exposure (maternal hypertension) compared to the absence of the exposure.
  • This means that maternal hypertension is associated with a decreased likelihood of IUGR, indicating an inverse relationship.
  • In other words, mothers with hypertension are less likely to have fetuses with IUGR compared to mothers without hypertension.
  • Odd ratio (OR) is used to measure strength of association in a case control study.
  • It is also known as ‘Cross product ratio’ or Relative odds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Positive association. This would be indicated by an OR greater than 1, suggesting that the exposure increases the likelihood of the outcome.

 

Option B) Common association. This option is vague and does not directly relate to the interpretation of the OR.

 

Option D) Rare outcome. This option does not directly address the relationship between the exposure and the outcome as indicated by the OR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of Odds ratios (OR) is similar to Relative risk (RR) in cohort study (as OR is an estimate of RR).
    • OR > 1: Cases have so-many times higher odds than controls of having the history of exposure under study.
    • OR = 1: Cases have equal odds as controls of having the history of exposure under study; thus exposure IS NOT ASSOCIATED with disease under study.
    • OR < 1: Cases have so-many times lesser odds as controls of having the history of exposure under study; thus exposure IS PROTECTIVE for the disease under study.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, myalgia, and a severe headache. He reports that these symptoms started a few days ago and have progressively worsened. His medical history is unremarkable except for frequent camping trips in wooded areas. On physical examination, he is noted to have a high fever, and laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. The patient mentions that he noticed several rodents around his camping site during his most recent trip. The emergency physician is considering various differential diagnoses based on the patient's symptoms and history of potential exposure to wildlife. Which of the following diseases is least likely to be associated with the patient’s recent exposure to rodents?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oriental sore

 

  • In this case, the patient's symptoms and history of exposure to rodents in a wooded area raise concerns for zoonotic infections.
  • However, Oriental sore (cutaneous leishmaniasis) is the least likely in this scenario. It is caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies, not through direct contact with rodents.
  • The patient's camping activities and exposure to wildlife increase the likelihood of diseases such as Leptospirosis, Rat Bite fever, or Tularemia, all of which can be associated with rodents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Leptospirosis. This bacterial disease can be contracted through contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected rodents, fitting with the patient's history.

 

Option B) Rat Bite fever. This is transmitted by bites or scratches from infected rodents, or through contact with a rodent's urine or mucous secretions.

 

Option C) Tularemia. Also known as "rabbit fever," it can be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, or through insect bites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DISEASES ASSOCIATED WITH RODENTS

questions.text: In a patient with venous ulcer, the following components are used in the management except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anticoagulation

 

  • Anticoagulation is used in management of DVT.

 

Other options:

 

  • The cause of a venous leg ulcer is venous hypertension and the keystone of management is to decrease this hypertension using venous ablation (Option B) and compression therapy for symptomatic benefit (Option C). 
  • Pentoxifylline (Option D), which increases microvascular perfusion by decreasing plasma cellular viscosity and cytokine inhibition, has been demonstrated to be a useful adjunct to compression by augmenting ulcer healing.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Superficial venous ablation or surgery: In patients with venous leg ulcers, treatment of superficial venous incompetence has been demonstrated to accelerate healing and reduce recurrence; therefore, expeditious referral to a vascular service for assessment is recommended.
  • Compression: The most clinical and cost-effective compression regimes are two-layer compression hosiery or four-layer compression bandaging. The ideal interface pressure in pure venous ulceration is 35-40 mmHg. Skilled application of these dressings is essential for both safety and efficacy.
  • Pentoxifylline, which increases microvascular perfusion by decreasing plasma cellular viscosity and cytokine inhibition, has been demonstrated to be a useful adjunct to compression by augmenting ulcer healing.
  • Horse chestnut seed extract has been shown to be a safe and efficacious treatment for chronic venous hypertension, improving symptoms and reducing leg volume.
  • A number of biological dressings have been developed, including fetal keratinocytes and collagen meshes, which have been shown to improve healing; however, they are not cost-effective for the majority of ulcers.
  • Pinch grafts and ulcer excision with mesh grafting have been shown to provide good early healing with moderate long-term results (50% healed at 5 years).

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Edition, Page no. 1040-41

questions.text: A patient comes 6 hours after consuming morphine and presents with pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression. The half-life of morphine is 3 hours and Volume of distribution (Vd) is 200 L. Plasma concentration of morphine at this time is 0.5 microgram/ml. Calculate the initial morphine dose consumed.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 400 mg

 

  • Current Plasma concentration of morphine (after 6 hours of intake) = 0.5 microgram/ml
  • As t1/2 = 3 hours, so, it must have become ¼ in 6 hours (In one half life, concentration becomes 50 percent and in two half-lives, it becomes 25 percent)
  • So, Plasma concentration at the time of consumption = 0.5 x 4 = 2 microgram/ml = 2 mg/L
  • So, applying the formula,

 

Loading dose = Vd x plasma concentration (at time of consumption of morphine)

 

Loading dose = 200 x 2 = 400 mg

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to persistent diarrhea and failure to thrive. On examination, the infant appears to be malnourished with signs of fat malabsorption. Blood tests reveal a notable absence of cholesterol and triglycerides. Lipoprotein electrophoresis shows the absence of both VLDL and LDL fractions. Further microscopic examination of a blood sample indicates the presence of acanthocytes. Based on these findings, the pediatrician believes that a deficiency in a specific protein involved in lipid metabolism may be the underlying cause. Genetic sequencing of which of the following genes is most likely to confirm the pediatrician's suspicion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

 

  • The infant's clinical presentation with persistent diarrhea, failure to thrive, fat malabsorption, absence of cholesterol and triglycerides, and acanthocytes in the blood sample is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.
  • Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene.
  • Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) plays a crucial role in the assembly and secretion of lipoproteins, including chylomicrons and VLDL.
  • In individuals with abetalipoproteinemia, the absence or dysfunction of MTP leads to the inability to form and secrete these lipoproteins, resulting in malabsorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lipoprotein lipase.

 

  • Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is involved in the hydrolysis of triglycerides within lipoproteins.
  • Deficiency of LPL is associated with disorders such as familial chylomicronemia syndrome but would not lead to the complete absence of VLDL and LDL as seen in abetalipoproteinemia.

 

Option C) Cholesterol Ester transfer protein.

 

  • Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP) is involved in the transfer of cholesterol esters between lipoproteins.
  • Deficiency of CETP is not associated with the specific clinical features described in abetalipoproteinemia.

 

Option D) Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl transferase.

 

  • Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) is involved in the esterification of cholesterol.
  • Deficiency of LCAT is associated with disorders such as familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency, but it does not lead to the characteristic features of abetalipoproteinemia, including the absence of VLDL and LDL

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to gain an understanding of abetalipoproteinemia, recognizing its genetic underpinning with mutations in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene.
  • Students should have ability to differentiate abetalipoproteinemia from other lipid metabolism disorders by correlating clinical manifestations and laboratory results.

choices.text: Arthroscopic debridement of the shoulder
Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder
Open repair of the rotator cuff

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is referred to the clinic by his primary care provider because he has pain in his left shoulder that has been worsening over the past six months. The patient says the pain has progressed to the extent that he can no longer play golf or enjoy his hobby of cabinet making. He has been treated with one injection of a corticosteroid and has been compliant with physical therapy for the past three months, but he has not had significant relief of his pain. He has no history of injury to the shoulder. On physical examination, range of motion of the shoulder shows forward flexion and abduction to 75 degrees. X-ray study of the shoulder is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reverse total arthroplasty of the shoulder

 

  • Given the patient's age, the severity and duration of symptoms, the lack of significant relief from conservative management (corticosteroid injection and physical therapy), and his functional limitations, the most appropriate next step is likely Reverse Total Arthroplasty of the Shoulder.
  • This option is especially relevant if the X-ray indicates severe arthritis or a complex rotator cuff tear, which are common in this age group and present similarly to the patient's symptoms.
  • This surgical procedure involves replacing the shoulder joint with a prosthesis, with the ball and socket reversed from their natural positions.
  • It is particularly effective in treating severe shoulder arthritis, especially in patients with concomitant rotator cuff tears where conventional total shoulder arthroplasty might not be as effective.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Arthroscopic Debridement of the Shoulder. This procedure involves the removal of damaged tissue from the shoulder joint. It can be beneficial in cases of mild to moderate osteoarthritis or rotator cuff tears. However, its effectiveness may be limited in more severe cases, especially if there is significant joint damage or a large rotator cuff tear.

 

Option C) Hemiarthroplasty of the Shoulder. This is a partial shoulder replacement, where only the humeral head is replaced. It can be considered in cases of severe shoulder arthritis with an intact rotator cuff. However, its effectiveness can be less in the presence of a rotator cuff tear or advanced joint disease.

 

Option D) Open Repair of the Rotator Cuff. This involves surgically repairing torn rotator cuff tendons. This option is considered when there is a significant rotator cuff tear, but it may not be as effective in older patients with advanced shoulder arthritis and severe rotator cuff degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with severe shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and failure to respond to conservative treatment, reverse total arthroplasty is often the most effective management, particularly in the presence of severe arthritis and/or significant rotator cuff pathology. This procedure can provide substantial pain relief and functional improvement, especially in those with complex shoulder conditions.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of several painless ulcers on her genitalia. She reports a new sexual partner 2 months ago but cannot provide his medical history. Physical examination reveals multiple, shallow ulcers with a non-purulent base on the labia majora and no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A dark field examination of the ulcer exudate is planned. What organism, seen under dark field microscopy (image below), would be diagnostic in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

  • Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can be identified by its characteristic morphology and motility using dark field microscopy.
  • The presence of painless genital ulcers is consistent with primary syphilis, and the identification of T. pallidum would confirm the diagnosis.

 

 

Direct microscopy of T. pallidum: A. Dark ground microscope; B. Direct fluorescent antibody staining for T. pallidum (DFA-TP); C. Silver impregnation method

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents with painful genital ulcers, not painless.

 

Option C) Herpes simplex virus causes painful vesicular or ulcerative lesions that can be diagnosed using PCR or viral culture.

 

Option D) Klebsiella granulomatis is the cause of granuloma inguinale and would not be visualized using dark field microscopy but rather identified by Donovan bodies on tissue smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary syphilis is diagnosed by identifying Treponema pallidum in ulcer exudate using dark field microscopy.

choices.text: a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

questions.text: A toxicologist is reviewing laboratory reports for patients suspected of lead poisoning. To confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of lead exposure, the toxicologist refers to specific biomarkers and their critical levels. Match the following biomarkers with their respective critical levels that are indicative of lead poisoning.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).
  • Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic.
  • Clinical picture of lead poisoning:
    • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
    • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
    • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
    • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
    • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
    • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
    • Lead encephalopathy
    • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds
  • Clinical symptoms of plumbism occur when lead level in blood >70 mcg/100 mL.
  • A sensitive parameter of haematological response is Basophilic stippling of RBCs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of pain with intercourse and dysmenorrhea that worsens one-two days before her period starts. Ultrasonography reveals unilateral adnexal masses, and laparoscopy shows reddish-brown cysts on the ovaries. This patient is at increased risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infertility

 

  • The likely diagnosis here is Endometriosis.
  • Endometriosis can lead to infertility through several mechanisms, including distortion of the pelvic anatomy, adhesions, endometriomas, and inflammatory changes in the pelvis that can affect gamete transport, implantation, and overall reproductive function.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Carcinoma. While there is some association between endometriosis and certain types of ovarian cancer (specifically, endometrioid and clear cell ovarian carcinomas), the overall risk remains relatively low. Infertility is a more direct and common complication of endometriosis.

 

Option C) Intracranial haemorrhage. There is no direct link between endometriosis and an increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage. This condition is not related to the reproductive system pathology seen in endometriosis.

 

Option D) Masculinization. Endometriosis does not lead to masculinization. Masculinization, or virilization, involves the development of male physical characteristics and is typically related to conditions involving excessive androgen production, which is not a feature of endometriosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize that endometriosis, characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, can lead to significant reproductive morbidity, including infertility. Understanding the implications of endometriosis on fertility and the typical presentations of the disease is crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Decreased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule
Increased bicarbonate reabsorption by the proximal tubule
Volume depletion and increased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule

questions.text: After four days of flu-like symptoms, a patient is feeling unsteady on her feet and dizzy when she attempts to stand up. During her illness, she has eaten very little and has had frequent emesis. Blood tests reveal an arterial pH of 7.5 and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 53 mmHg. What is the most likely etiology of this acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume depletion and increased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule

 

  • This is the most likely explanation.
  • Vomiting leads to loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), which results in a net increase in bicarbonate in the body, causing metabolic alkalosis.
  • Volume depletion secondary to vomiting and decreased oral intake further exacerbates the alkalosis by stimulating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, leading to increased sodium (and hence, bicarbonate) reabsorption, and increased hydrogen ion excretion at the distal tubule.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Consumption of antacids. While excessive use of antacids can lead to metabolic alkalosis, there's no information provided that the patient has been consuming antacids. The history of vomiting is a more direct and relevant cause of the metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option B) Decreased hydrogen excretion in the distal tubule. This would lead to acid retention and acidosis, not alkalosis. It does not explain the patient's elevated pH.

 

Option C) Increased bicarbonate reabsorption by the proximal tubule. This could contribute to metabolic alkalosis, but it's more commonly associated with conditions leading to bicarbonate retention, such as chronic respiratory acidosis. The patient's history of vomiting is a more immediate cause of bicarbonate retention due to loss of gastric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the mechanisms by which vomiting can lead to metabolic alkalosis. Vomiting causes loss of hydrochloric acid from the stomach, resulting in an increase in blood bicarbonate levels and subsequent metabolic alkalosis. Volume depletion due to vomiting and reduced oral intake enhances renal bicarbonate reabsorption and hydrogen ion excretion, further contributing to the alkalosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man has complained of heartburn for the past 5 months. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper GI endoscopy is performed. Biopsies are taken of an erythematous area of the lower esophageal mucosa. There is no mass lesion and no hemorrhage. The biopsies have the microscopic appearance shown here.
