questions.text: A 22-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with hemoptysis. He has never had an episode like this before. He does recall having a cold approximately three weeks earlier and has been experiencing increased fatigue and breathlessness since then, but he denies any current symptoms of rhinorrhea, sore throat, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. X-ray of the chest shows diffuse opacities in both lower lung fields, and urinalysis reveals RBCs in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goodpasture syndrome

 

  • This is the correct diagnosis given the patient's symptoms of renal involvement (hematuria) and pulmonary involvement (hemoptysis and diffuse pulmonary opacities).
  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies that target the basement membranes of both the kidneys and lungs, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This condition typically follows a streptococcal infection of the throat or skin and primarily affects the kidneys, leading to hematuria, edema, and hypertension. It does not typically involve the lungs or cause hemoptysis.

 

Option B) Alport syndrome. This is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive nephritis and often hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. It does not typically present with pulmonary symptoms or acute hemoptysis.

 

Option C) Berger disease (IgA nephropathy). This is the most common form of primary glomerulonephritis worldwide and presents with episodic gross hematuria, often following upper respiratory infections. However, it does not commonly involve the lungs or cause hemoptysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome, which involves both the renal and pulmonary systems, manifested as glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage, respectively. The presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies is diagnostic for this condition. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent progression and preserve organ function.

questions.text: Blood supply of the marked structure in the given specimen is derived from which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior cerebral artery

 

  • Marked structure is fornix.
  • Blood supply to most of the structures over the medial surface of cerebral hemisphere is by anterior cerebral artery.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Middle cerebral artery lodges over the posterior ramus of lateral sulcus and is the major source of blood supply on the superolateral surface.

 

Option B) Internal carotid artery lies in the floor of cavernous sinus along with Abducent nerve, then it pierces the roof of cavernous sinus to supply the cerebral hemispheres.

 

Option D) Vertebral artery. The fourth part of vertebral artery enters cranial cavity through foramen magnum and the arteries of both sides unite to form basilar artery.

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of clinical neuroanatomy, 2nd edition, page no. 176-178

questions.text: During normal screening for phenylketonuria, a male newborn has a serum phenylalanine concentration of 35 mg/dL (greater than 20 mg/dL is considered a positive test). Signs of tyrosine deficiency also are apparent. Enzymatic analysis using cultured fibroblasts, obtained after circumcision, shows normal activity of phenylalanine hydroxylase. A possible explanation for these findings is a deficiency in function of which of the following coenzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopterin

 

  • Biopterin, specifically tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), is a cofactor required for the function of phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • A deficiency in BH4 can lead to impaired phenylalanine metabolism and result in elevated phenylalanine levels, as seen in phenylketonuria (PKU).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Adenosylcobalamin.

 

  • Adenosylcobalamin is a coenzyme form of vitamin B12 and is not directly involved in phenylalanine metabolism.
  • It plays a role in certain other metabolic pathways.

 

Option C) Dihydroquinone.

 

  • Dihydroquinone is not a known coenzyme related to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D) Pyridoxal phosphate.

 

  • Pyridoxal phosphate is the active form of vitamin B6 and is involved in various enzymatic reactions, but it is not directly related to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand the role of coenzymes, specifically tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), in phenylalanine metabolism.
  • A deficiency in BH4 can lead to elevated phenylalanine levels and phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • Recognizing the role of coenzymes in metabolic pathways is important for understanding the underlying mechanisms of genetic disorders like PKU and for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: 28-year women with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility of 3 years. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrosalpinx

 

  • The above scenario is that of a hydrosalpinx.
  • Points in favor of this are:
    • H/o ectopic pregnancy 
    • H/o subfertility
    • Recurrent discharge PV 
    • USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hydrosalpinx, USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection as shown below:

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is apprehensive of general anesthesia and prefers a regional anesthetic. Decision is made to conduct spinal anesthesia for the repair of inguinal hernia along with midazolam and fentanyl to allay anxiety. During the procedure, he suddenly loses consciousness. There is profound hypotension with systolic blood pressure of 44 mm Hg and a heart rate of 28 bpm. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is started. The next most appropriate intervention is administration of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epinephrine

 

  • Epinephrine is another sympathomimetic medication that can rapidly increase heart rate and blood pressure.
  • It is a potent vasopressor and is often used in emergency situations to reverse severe hypotension and bradycardia.
  • Epinephrine would be appropriate in this case.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Atropine. Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used to treat bradycardia. It works by blocking the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system, which slows down the heart rate. However, atropine is not the most appropriate initial intervention in this case because it primarily addresses bradycardia and may not effectively address the profound hypotension.

 

Option B) Ephedrine. Ephedrine is a sympathomimetic medication that acts as a vasopressor and increases both heart rate and blood pressure. It is commonly used to treat hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia. Given the patient's severe hypotension and bradycardia, ephedrine is a suitable choice to address both issues.

 

Option D) Flumazenil. Flumazenil is a medication used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines like midazolam. It is not indicated in this scenario because the patient's loss of consciousness and profound hypotension are more likely related to anesthesia and not benzodiazepine overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand the management of severe hypotension and bradycardia during anesthesia.
  • Healthcare professionals should be able to identify and respond to adverse events promptly, recognizing the appropriate medications and interventions required to stabilize the patient.
  • Additionally, it's important to be aware of the use of vasopressors like ephedrine and epinephrine in managing anesthesia-related hypotension

questions.text: A recent breakthrough in malaria research has led to the development of a new vaccine strain targeting Plasmodium falciparum. This advancement is discussed among healthcare professionals, emphasizing its potential impact on malaria prevention. Which of the following is a new Plasmodium falciparum vaccine strain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RTS, S/AS01

 

  • RTS, S/AS01, known as Mosquirix, is the first and currently, the only vaccine showing efficacy against Plasmodium falciparum in clinical trials.
  • It is a recombinant protein-based vaccine.
  • It has been approved by the FDA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) PPV23. This is a pneumococcal vaccine, not related to malaria.

 

Option C) R14-4. Not a recognized malaria vaccine strain.

 

Option D) NYVAC-PF01. While a potential vaccine candidate, it does not have the established efficacy of RTS, S/AS01.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Various malaria vaccine with the site of action and names:

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman falls down a flight of stairs. A radiograph of the pelvis is taken to determine if fracture is present. The radiograph reveals the presence of small calcified muscular arteries. The microscopic appearance of one of these arteries is depicted here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial calcific sclerosis

 

  • Medial calcific sclerosis, also known as Monckeberg's sclerosis, is a non-inflammatory condition characterized by calcium deposits within the medial layer of muscular arteries.
  • These calcifications can be seen on radiographs and often do not significantly obstruct blood flow.
  • This condition is typically associated with aging and does not usually lead to clinical symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a condition characterized by thickening and narrowing of small arteries, typically seen in patients with long-standing hypertension or diabetes. It is not associated with calcifications in the arteries.

 

Option C) Metastatic calcification. Metastatic calcification occurs when there is abnormal deposition of calcium in tissues due to systemic factors, such as hypercalcemia. It is not specific to muscular arteries and typically affects multiple tissues, including soft tissues and organs.

 

Option D) Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis is a type of arteriolar sclerosis that is associated with malignant hypertension. It involves the thickening of the arteriolar walls and a "string of beads" appearance on microscopic examination. It is not associated with calcifications in the arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Medial calcific sclerosis (Monckeberg's sclerosis) is a non-inflammatory condition characterized by calcium deposits within the medial layer of muscular arteries.
  • It is often an incidental finding on radiographs and is associated with aging, typically without significant clinical symptoms.
  • It does not cause narrowing or obstruction of the arteries.

questions.text: During a study on the zoonotic transmission of avian influenza, researchers introduce random mutations into the virus's genome. One mutated strain gained the ability to infect human respiratory epithelial cells. Which viral component's alteration would most likely allow the avian influenza virus to acquire the ability to infect human cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigenic glycoprotein

 

  • The ability of a virus to infect a host cell is primarily determined by the interaction of the virus's surface proteins with receptors on the host cell.
  • For influenza viruses, the hemagglutinin (HA) antigenic glycoprotein is responsible for binding to host cell receptors.
  • Mutations in the HA protein can change the virus's host specificity, allowing it to cross species barriers and infect new host species, such as humans.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Lipid bilayer envelope. The lipid envelope's primary role is to protect the viral proteins but does not usually confer specificity for host cell receptors.

 

Option C) mRNA endonuclease. This viral enzyme is involved in the replication process of the virus and does not typically affect the virus's ability to infect different species.

 

Option D) Nucleocapsid protein. The nucleocapsid protein binds the viral RNA genome and is involved in viral assembly. It does not usually play a direct role in host cell infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The infectivity of a virus towards a host cell is largely governed by the interaction between the virus's surface proteins and the host cell receptors.
  • In the case of influenza viruses, the hemagglutinin (HA) antigenic glycoprotein is crucial for this binding process.
  • Mutations in HA can alter the virus's host specificity, potentially enabling it to infect new species, including humans.

choices.text: Activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors
Decreases hepatic production of VLDL cholesterol
Forms insoluble complexes with bile acids in the gut

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. At his last visit 3 months ago, his serum total cholesterol concentration was 320 mg/dL. He then began a low-cholesterol diet. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Serum studies show a total cholesterol concentration of 310 mg/dL. Kidney and liver function test results are within normal limits. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibits 3-HMG-CoA reductase

 

  • Statins (e.g., atorvastatin, simvastatin) inhibit the enzyme 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase, which is a key enzyme in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway in the liver.
  • This leads to a significant reduction in LDL cholesterol and has been shown to decrease cardiovascular events and mortality in numerous studies.
  • Given the patient's high total cholesterol and the need for substantial reduction, statins are the most appropriate first-line pharmacotherapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs). Drugs that activate PPARs, such as fibrates (e.g., fenofibrate, gemfibrozil), primarily increase the oxidation of fatty acids and are most effective at lowering triglycerides and, to a lesser extent, increasing HDL cholesterol. They are not the first-line agents for reducing LDL cholesterol, which is the main target given for this patient's high total cholesterol.

 

Option B) Decreases hepatic production of VLDL cholesterol. Drugs like niacin can decrease hepatic production of VLDL, which can lead to reduced LDL cholesterol. However, niacin also has other effects like increasing HDL cholesterol and can cause side effects such as flushing and hepatotoxicity. It is not typically the first choice for primary LDL reduction.

 

Option C) Forms insoluble complexes with bile acids in the gut. Bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine, colestipol) bind bile acids in the intestine, preventing their reabsorption. This leads to increased conversion of cholesterol into bile acids in the liver, which can lower LDL cholesterol levels. However, these agents are not usually the first choice due to gastrointestinal side effects and less effectiveness compared to other options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for a patient with significantly elevated LDL cholesterol, especially in the context of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension, is a statin. Statins work by inhibiting the HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, leading to decreased cholesterol synthesis in the liver and increased clearance of LDL cholesterol from the blood. This mechanism directly addresses the need to lower LDL cholesterol, making it the preferred option in such cases. Other therapies like fibrates, niacin, and bile acid sequestrants have roles in specific lipid abnormalities but are not the first choice for primary LDL reduction.

choices.text: Stored in the spleen and absorbed in the intestine by albumin
Excreted in the urine as Fe2+
Stored in combination with ferritin
Absorbed in the ferric (Fe3+) form

questions.text: A 49-year-old male, a case of congestive heart failure with elevated liver enzymes and greyish pigmentation of the skin came to the OPD. Final diagnosis of CCF (Congestive Cardiac Failure), hepatitis with cirrhosis of the liver was made. A liver biopsy was done which shows marked increase in iron storage. Which of the following is true regarding molecular iron (Fe)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stored in combination with ferritin  

 

  • This statement is correct.
  • Iron is stored in the body primarily in the form of ferritin, an intracellular protein that binds and stores iron.
  • Increased iron storage, as seen in the liver biopsy of this patient, can lead to conditions like hemochromatosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Stored in the spleen and absorbed in the intestine by albumin. This statement is not accurate. Iron is primarily absorbed in the small intestine, mainly in the duodenum and proximal jejunum. It is absorbed in its ferrous (Fe2+) form, not by albumin. The statement also does not address the patient's condition.

 

Option B) Excreted in the urine as Fe2+. This statement is not accurate. Iron is not typically excreted in the urine. In fact, the body carefully regulates iron levels to prevent excessive loss through urine.

 

Option D) Absorbed in the ferric (Fe3+) form. This statement is partially accurate. Iron is absorbed in the ferrous (Fe2+) form in the small intestine, but it is often transported in the bloodstream bound to transferrin, a protein that can carry both ferrous (Fe2+) and ferric (Fe3+) iron.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to understand the role of ferritin in storing iron within the body.
  • Ferritin is an essential protein for iron storage, and increased iron storage can occur in conditions like hemochromatosis, which can lead to complications such as liver cirrhosis.
  • Recognizing the importance of iron storage mechanisms in the body is crucial for understanding and managing conditions related to iron overload.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute gastroenteritis, including diarrhoea and vomiting. She reports consuming shell fish at a local restaurant two days prior. Given the likely diagnosis of a viral gastroenteritis caused by shell fish ingestion, which of the following is the most common organism responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Norovirus

 

  • Norovirus is the most common cause of acute gastroenteritis associated with shell fish consumption.
  • It is known for causing outbreaks, especially in situations where contaminated food is served, such as shell fish that have not been properly cooked.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Calicivirus. While noroviruses are a type of calicivirus, the term "calicivirus" is too broad and non-specific in this context.

 

Option B) Enterovirus type 40, 41. These are typically not associated with shell fish consumption.

 

Option D) Rotavirus. While it causes gastroenteritis, it is more commonly associated with infections in children and is not typically linked to shell fish consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Noroviruses may be the most common infectious agents of mild gastroenteritis in the community and affect all age groups.
  • It accounts for the majority of adult outbreaks of gastroenteritis associated with shell fish and salad ingredients.

questions.text: Of all the mullerian defects, which has the lowest associated risk of recurrent miscarriage and is shown here in this three-dimensional sonographic image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arcuate uterus

 

  • Arcuate uterus is not associated with poor obstetrical outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C) Uterine didelphys will appear as 2 completely separate uterine cavities. It has a better obstetric outcome although it is associated with abortions, preterm labor, FGR and rarely malpresentations.

 

Option A) and Option D) Septate uterus and unicornuate uterus are both associated with infertility, increased abortions, preterm labor, malpresentations and FGR. A unicornuate uterus will appear as a single uterine horn and a septate uterus will appear with a much deeper division between both the horns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arcuate uterus is not associated with poor obstetrical outcome.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman has had episodes of lower abdominal and pelvic pain for the past 11 years. A bimanual pelvic examination reveals no abnormalities. A Pap smear is negative. She has an abdominal ultrasound scan that reveals no abnormalities. She undergoes laparoscopy, and several 0.2 to 0.5 cm brown nodular lesions are seen on serosal surfaces of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and appendix. These lesions are excised. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be present in these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometrial stroma

 

  • The presence of brown nodular lesions on serosal surfaces in the pelvis and the history of lower abdominal and pelvic pain for many years suggest a condition known as endometriosis.
  • Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue (which includes endometrial stroma) outside the uterus.
  • These ectopic endometrial implants can form nodular lesions on various pelvic structures.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Mesothelial cells. Mesothelial cells are the cells lining the serous membranes, and they are not typically associated with the formation of nodular lesions in the pelvis.

 

Option C) Metastatic adenocarcinoma. Metastatic adenocarcinoma would present as cancerous cells in tissues, and it would not typically form small brown nodular lesions on the pelvic serosal surfaces.

 

Option D) Capillary proliferation. Capillary proliferation may be seen in various pathological conditions but is not specific to the described scenario of brown nodular lesions on serosal surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the histopathological findings associated with endometriosis. Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue, including endometrial stroma, outside the uterus. Recognizing these histological features is important for diagnosing and managing patients with endometriosis, a common cause of chronic pelvic pain and fertility problems in women.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department following a bicycle accident. The patient was riding downhill when he hit a rock and lost control. He was thrown off his bicycle and hit the handlebars before tumbling onto the pavement. The patient was not wearing a helmet but did not lose consciousness. Blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows ecchymosis over the right superior orbit with underlying tenderness and a few scalp abrasions. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye. Using the right eye, the patient is unable to read the largest letter on the visual acuity chart and is only able to perceive light. There is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. Extraocular movements are normal, and the red reflex is symmetric bilaterally. Fluorescein dye testing is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Optic nerve injury

 

  • Description: Damage to the optic nerve, which connects the eye to the brain.
  • Relevance: This is a likely cause given the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect, severe vision loss, and the trauma history. Optic nerve injuries can occur from blunt trauma, like hitting the handlebars.
  • Based on the symptoms and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is Optic Nerve Injury.
  • The presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect, the severe reduction in vision in the right eye, and the history of trauma are all consistent with an injury to the optic nerve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Corneal Abrasion.

 

  • Description: A scratch on the cornea, the clear front part of the eye.
  • Relevance: While this can be painful and affect vision, the patient's symptom of only being able to perceive light in the right eye suggests a more serious injury. Additionally, fluorescein dye testing, which is usually used to detect corneal abrasions, was unremarkable.

 

Option B) Lens Dislocation.

 

  • Description: This occurs when the lens of the eye moves from its usual position.
  • Relevance: This could cause significant vision changes. However, the patient's symptoms, especially the relative afferent pupillary defect (an indication of optic nerve dysfunction), point to a problem with the optic nerve rather than the lens.

 

Option D) Retained Foreign Body.

 

  • Description: This refers to any foreign object that remains in the eye after an injury.
  • Relevance: While this could cause vision problems, the patient's specific symptoms, especially the relative afferent pupillary defect and the severe loss of vision, are more indicative of optic nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational point here is recognizing the signs of optic nerve injury, especially in the context of trauma. A relative afferent pupillary defect is a crucial clinical sign indicating potential optic nerve damage. It's important to promptly identify and manage such injuries, as they can have significant implications for a patient's vision and overall ocular health.

choices.text: CD4 lymphocytes infiltrating the dermis

questions.text: A clinical study is performed with subjects who developed a skin rash. Skin biopsies from these subjects are analyzed by immunofluoresence. Some of the subjects have the immunofluorescence pattern shown here, with antibody to IgG. This appearance is most likely to be based upon which of the following pathologic mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antigen-antibody complex deposition

 

  • Immunofluorescence patterns with the deposition of IgG typically indicate the presence of immune complexes formed by the binding of antibodies (IgG) to antigens.
  • These immune complexes can deposit in various tissues, including the skin, leading to immune-mediated damage and inflammation.
  • This pattern is often seen in conditions like autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) and immune complex-mediated vasculitis.
  • The other options are less likely to be associated with the described immunofluorescence pattern:

 

Option A) CD4 lymphocytes infiltrating the dermis. CD4 lymphocytes infiltrating the dermis may be associated with cellular immune responses but are not typically visualized with IgG immunofluorescence staining.

 

Option B) Degranulation of mast cells. Mast cell degranulation may release histamine and other mediators, but it is not typically associated with the deposition of IgG immune complexes.

 

Option D) Macrophage cytokine release. Macrophages release cytokines as part of the immune response, but this mechanism is not directly related to the deposition of IgG immune complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Immunofluorescence patterns with the deposition of IgG indicate the presence of immune complexes formed by antigen-antibody interactions.
  • This pattern is often seen in autoimmune diseases and immune complex-mediated conditions, leading to tissue damage and inflammation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of blurry vision. She states that for the past three weeks, her eyes have been very dry and itchy, and she is unable to make tears. She also states that she has had a very dry mouth despite drinking adequate fluids. Physical examination reveals bilateral dry, ulcerated corneas and fissures on the sides of her lips. In addition, both of her knees are erythematous and swollen. When asked about her knees, she says, “Yes, my knees and wrists tend to be swollen and stiff in the morning, but my mom had arthritis.” Testing for several autoantibodies reveals she is rheumatoid factor-positive and antibody-SS-B (La)-positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sjögren syndrome

 

  • This is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands, leading to dry eyes and dry mouth, respectively.
  • The presence of rheumatoid factor and anti-SS-B (La) antibodies, along with the described symptoms, strongly suggests Sjögren syndrome.
  • The joint symptoms described are also consistent with the musculoskeletal involvement that can occur in Sjögren syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) CREST syndrome. This is a variant of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) characterized by Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia. The primary symptoms presented by the patient do not align with CREST syndrome.

 

Option B) Cystic fibrosis. This is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs, pancreas, and other organs, leading to thick, sticky mucus production. The patient's symptoms do not suggest cystic fibrosis, which primarily presents with respiratory and digestive system complications.

 

Option C) Sicca syndrome. This term refers to the combination of dry eyes and dry mouth, which are symptoms of Sjögren syndrome, but Sicca syndrome by itself does not account for the joint symptoms or the specific autoantibodies present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features and diagnostic criteria for Sjögren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes, dry mouth, and other systemic manifestations. The presence of specific autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor and anti-SS-B (La), supports the diagnosis. Understanding the multi-systemic nature of Sjögren syndrome is crucial for diagnosis, as it often presents with extra-glandular manifestations such as arthritis.

choices.text: Reassurance that this is self-limiting
Early surgical repair
Wait for resolution till 6 months of age
Wait for resolution till 2 years of age

questions.text: A mother brings her male infant to the paediatrician with right-sided scrotal swelling, which is maximum at night, but disappears when the child wakes up in the morning. The swelling is soft and shows transillumination. What will be the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for resolution till 2 years of age

 

  • The clinical presentation described here is characteristic of a communicating/congenital hydrocele.
  • In a communicating hydrocele, there is an abnormal connection between the abdominal cavity and the scrotum, allowing fluid to flow in and out.
  • This fluid accumulation often increases when the child is upright or active (as in the evening) and decreases when lying flat (such as during sleep), explaining the variation in size.
  • The management of a communicating hydrocele in infants is usually conservative, as many of these hydroceles resolve spontaneously as the connection between the abdominal cavity and the scrotum closes naturally.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Reassurance as this is self-limiting. Though this is the initial step, it is not the best answer. Some congenital hydroceles may resolve, while some may require surgical intervention.

 

Option B) Early surgical repair. Surgery is considered in cases where the hydrocele does not resolve on its own by a certain age or if it's causing complications. However, immediate surgical intervention is not typically indicated in a simple communicating hydrocele without complications.

 

Option C) Wait for resolution till 6 months. While some hydroceles may resolve within the first few months of life, it is more common to observe them for a longer period before considering surgery.

 

Option D) Wait for resolution till 2 years. This is more aligned with the standard practice. Most pediatricians recommend waiting until the child is around 2 years old before considering surgical intervention, as many hydroceles will close spontaneously by this age.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate management option for this condition, given the child's age and the characteristics of the swelling, would be option D) Wait for resolution till 2 years. If the hydrocele persists beyond this age or if any complications arise, surgical intervention can be reconsidered.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postmenopausal woman, presented to the OPD with back pains. Initial screening shows serum calcium levels of 11.7 mg%, Vit. D is 55 ng/ml and elevated PTH. What might be the most common cause of such clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parathyroid Adenoma

 

  • Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vit. D Levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Causes:
    • PTH secreting adenoma: M/C cause
    • Multiglandular hyperplasia: seen in MEN syndrome

choices.text: a, b, c
b, c, d

questions.text:
A patient came to the surgical OPD with complaints of lower limb pain. After eliciting complete history, the surgeon considers the first differential to be intermittent claudication due to arterial disorder. Which of the following features would have prompted him to consider this differential?

 

  1. Brought on by walking
  2. Present on taking first step
  3. Relieved on resting for 5 mins
  4. Distance that patient is able to walk without stopping greatly varying every day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a. c

 

  • Intermittent claudication is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain in the muscles due to anaerobic muscle metabolism.
  • The characteristic features of intermittent claudication are as follows:
    • Brought on by walking (option a)
    • Not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis) (option b)
    • Relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (Option c) (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).
    • The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day (Option d). 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The muscle group affected by claudication is classically one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease and is usually felt in the posterior calf as the superficial femoral artery is the most commonly affected artery (70% of cases).
  • Aortoiliac disease (30% of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is buttock claudication combined with sexual impotence, which is secondary to arterial insufficiency.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 998

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 30-pound weight loss over the past two months presents to the physician with a history of nausea and bloating. Symptoms are most prominent following a meal. An outpatient gastric emptying study shows esophageal dysmotility. The best treatment option for this patient is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that enhances gastric motility by increasing the amplitude of gastric contractions and accelerating gastric emptying.
  • It also increases the tone of the lower esophageal sphincter and has antiemetic properties.
  • Given its mechanism of action, metoclopramide is an appropriate treatment option for symptoms of gastroparesis in diabetic patients.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Esophageal resection. This is a surgical intervention typically reserved for severe esophageal disease such as cancer or end-stage benign disease. It is not indicated for motility disorders like gastroparesis and carries significant risks.

 

Option C) Omeprazole. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used to reduce gastric acid production. It is used in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcer disease, and other conditions associated with excessive stomach acid. While it can relieve symptoms caused by acid, it does not address the underlying motility issue and is not the best option for this patient's primary symptoms.

 

Option D) Ondansetron. Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used primarily as an antiemetic to prevent nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery. While it can help manage nausea, it does not improve gastric emptying or motility and therefore would not be the most effective treatment for gastroparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the management of gastroparesis, particularly in diabetic patients. Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that can improve gastric emptying and reduce symptoms of gastroparesis by enhancing gastrointestinal motility and providing antiemetic effects. It is important to choose treatment options that address the underlying pathophysiology of the condition, which in the case of gastroparesis, involves delayed gastric emptying and impaired motility.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for evaluation of behavioural problems. The mother says, "She was sent to the principal's office last week after telling another student that she was 'stupid' for ignoring her in class. She blurts out whatever comes into her head, like telling a kid at football practice that her shoes were ugly." The patient's report card for the past year states that she "requires frequent redirection to remain seated, is disruptive in class, and speaks out of turn." The mother says, "She is always making excuses for not doing her homework and chores. She loses the instructions for assignments”. During the evaluation, the patient interrupts her mother to argue that it is not her fault her parents don't help her with homework. She is easily distracted by noises from outside the examination room and requires questions to be repeated multiple times. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

 

  • This patient presents with parental concerns of being socially inappropriate (e.g., blurting out offensive comments, intruding on classmates), uncooperative (e.g., "disruptive in class," incomplete chores), and defensive (e.g., "always making excuses"), which can occur in numerous childhood behavioural disorders (e.g., oppositional defiant disorder [ODD], disruptive mood dysregulation disorder [DMDD], conduct disorder).
  • However, social skill deficits and uncooperative behaviours are also common in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and parents of children with ADHD may present with concerns of the child's intentional defiance and purposeful social offense.
  • As seen in this patient, these behaviours are actually signs of untreated hyperactivity/impulsivity and inattention.
  • This constellation of symptoms often results in poor follow-through, social intrusions, and inappropriate activity, especially in situations where there are expectations of sustained attention or stillness (e.g., classroom).
  • These impairments can lead to increased rejection, conflict, and blame resulting in more frequent defensiveness, excuse making, and behavioural outbursts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Conduct disorder. In contrast to ADHD, conduct disorder involves a clear pattern of multiple serious social violations through aggression (e.g., physical threat or harm toothers), property destruction (e.g., fire setting, vandalization), lying, and/or stealing.

 

Option D. ODD (Oppositional defiant disorder) is characterized by a pattern of chronic angry/irritable moods, intentionally argumentative/defiant behaviour, and vindictiveness that is deliberate in nature. This patient's disruptions in class are likely a result of her impulsivity and difficulty sustaining attention rather than wilful defiance or aggression.

 

Option A. DMDD (Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder) involves frequent, severe verbal or physical outbursts disproportionate to developmental level and triggers (e.g., throwing desk at school after not understanding a math question) and leading to school and relational problems. This patient is not having severe outbursts.

 

Educational objective:

 

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) may present with parental concerns of intentional disobedience and purposeful social offensiveness resembling multiple childhood behavioural disorders. However, poor follow-through and social skill deficits can result from the unmanaged inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity of ADHD, not intentional defiance or wilful social misconduct.

choices.text: Paralytic ileus – Put a NG tube

questions.text: 3 years following open appendicectomy, a 28-year-old male presented with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. Abdomen showed hyper-peristalsis. X-ray abdomen showed the following. What is the likely pathology and the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adhesive obstruction – CECT abdomen

 

  • Adhesive obstruction is the MC complication (late) of appendicectomy.
  • X-ray shows mechanical obstruction – step ladder pattern of air fluid levels.
  • Next step in mechanical obstruction is CECT abdomen to identify etiology/site of obstruction and presence of bowel ischemia.
  • Causes of adhesions:
    • Acute inflammation: Sites of anastomoses, reperitonealisation of raw areas, trauma, ischaemia
    • Foreign material: Talc, starch, gauze, silk
    • Infection: Peritonitis, tuberculosis
    • Chronic infammatory conditions: Crohn’s disease
    • Radiation enteritis
  • Management:
    • Initial management is based on intravenous rehydration and nasogastric decompression; occasionally, this treatment is curative.
    • Although an initial conservative regimen is considered appropriate, regular assessment is mandatory to ensure that strangulation does not occur.
    • Conservative treatment should not usually be prolonged beyond 72 hours.
    • When laparotomy is required, although multiple adhesions may be found, only one may be causative.
    • If there is absolute certainty that this is the cause of the obstruction, this should be divided and the remaining adhesions can be left in situ unless severe angulation is present

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Edition, Page no. 1378, 1387

choices.text: Free nerve endings

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the neurology outpatient clinic with a history of inability to perceive slow vibrations and changes in texture on the skin. Which of the following cutaneous receptors are expected to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meissner corpuscles

 

  • The Meissner corpuscles are expected to be affected in this patient, which respond to changes in texture and slow (low frequency) vibrations (slow vibrations are the keyword).
  • The Meissner corpuscles are encapsulated dendritic endings, which are cutaneous mechanoreceptors.
  • Merkel cells are associated with touch and pressure.
  • Ruffini corpuscles are associated with sustained pressure and free nerve endings are associated with pain.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 160

questions.text:
In clinical practice, understanding the incubation periods of infectious diseases is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management. Among the following diseases, which have an incubation period of less than 10 days?

  1. Cholera
  2. Influenza
  3. Plague
  4. Measles
  5. Rubella
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

  • Cholera typically has a short incubation period, often less than 2 days.
  • Influenza also has a short incubation period, typically 1 to 4 days.
  • Plague has an incubation period ranging from 1 to 7 days.
  • Measles and Rubella, on the other hand, have longer incubation periods, usually 10 to 14 days and 14-21 days respectively.
  • Therefore, the diseases with an incubation period of less than 10 days are Cholera, Influenza, and Plague.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 45-pack-year history of cigarette smoking comes to the clinic complaining of chronic cough, dyspnea, and blood in his sputum. He says he has been feeling lethargic and has lost 18 kg (40 lb) over the past three months with no changes in diet or exercise. While awaiting x-ray of the chest, the patient suffers a seizure and is rushed to the emergency department of the nearest hospital. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ADH

 

  • ADH, also known as vasopressin, regulates water balance in the body.
  • Elevated levels of ADH can lead to a condition called Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH), which can result in hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels).
  • SIADH can be caused by various factors, including lung cancers.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone). ACTH is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the adrenal glands to release cortisol. Elevated levels of ACTH can occur in conditions like Cushing's syndrome, where there is excess cortisol production. However, it is less likely to be elevated in this patient's presentation.

 

Option C) Parathyroid Hormone (PTH). PTH is produced by the parathyroid glands and regulates calcium and phosphate levels in the blood. Elevated PTH levels can occur in primary hyperparathyroidism, but this condition is not typically associated with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D) Tumor Necrosis Factor-α (TNF-α). TNF-α is a proinflammatory cytokine that plays a role in various inflammatory and immune responses. Elevated levels of TNF-α can be associated with conditions like cancer, chronic inflammation, and autoimmune diseases. It can contribute to the systemic symptoms seen in cancer patients, such as cachexia (weight loss) and fatigue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the potential hormonal imbalances and biomarker changes associated with various medical conditions, including those related to malignancies and their systemic effects. It highlights the significance of recognizing specific hormone abnormalities in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child opened his father’s drawer and ingested multiple tablets of his cardiac medication, metoprolol. The child was brought to hospital with profound hypotension and bradycardia. What is the specific antidote used in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagon

 

  • Mechanism: Glucagon is a hormone that activates adenylate cyclase in cardiac cells, leading to increased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP). This results in increased intracellular calcium and improved contractility and heart rate.
  • Use in Toxicity: Glucagon is considered the specific antidote for beta-blocker toxicity. It works by bypassing the beta-adrenergic receptor blockade and stimulating cardiac function. It is particularly effective in cases of profound bradycardia and hypotension due to beta-blocker overdose.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Dobutamine.

 

    •  
  • Mechanism: Dobutamine is a sympathomimetic drug that primarily stimulates beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, leading to an increase in heart rate and contractility.
  • Use in Toxicity: While dobutamine can increase heart rate and cardiac output, it may not be the first-line antidote for beta-blocker toxicity. Other agents with more specific mechanisms are preferred.

 

Option C) Adrenaline (Epinephrine).

 

  • Mechanism: Adrenaline is a sympathomimetic drug that acts on both alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors. It increases heart rate, contractility, and systemic vascular resistance.
  • Use in Toxicity: Adrenaline can be used to treat beta-blocker overdose; however, it may not be the specific antidote. It can be less effective in cases of severe beta-blocker toxicity, as it competes with the blocked beta receptors.

 

Option D) Noradrenaline (Norepinephrine).

 

    •  
  • Mechanism: Noradrenaline primarily stimulates alpha adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and increased systemic vascular resistance.
  • Use in Toxicity: Noradrenaline can be used to treat beta-blocker overdose by increasing blood pressure through vasoconstriction. However, it is not the specific antidote for beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the specific antidote for beta-blocker toxicity, which is glucagon. Glucagon can effectively counteract the profound hypotension and bradycardia caused by beta-blocker overdose by stimulating cardiac function through an alternative signalling pathway (CAMP-mediated). It is important for healthcare providers to be aware of the appropriate antidotes and treatments for toxicities caused by various medications, especially in emergency situations involving children.

choices.text: Continue current therapy
Switch to atenolol
Switch to extended-release nifedipine

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss management of hypertension. She has chronic hypertension, which is managed with a stable dose of chlorthalidone. The patient is nulligravid but desires pregnancy within the next several months. She is a lifetime non-smoker and does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. The patient's mother was diagnosed with hypertension at age 35. Blood pressure is 130/81 mm Hg; repeat blood pressure is 128/77 mm Hg. BMI is 26 kg/m². Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows: Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL; Potassium: 3.7 mEq/L; Hemoglobin A1c: 5.7%. Which of the following is the best advice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Switch to extended-release nifedipine

 

  • Extended-release nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered relatively safe for use during pregnancy and can manage hypertension effectively.
  • It does not have the teratogenic risks associated with some other antihypertensive medications.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Add spironolactone. Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that is not recommended during pregnancy due to potential anti-androgenic effects on the fetus.

 

Option B) Continue current therapy. Continuing chlorthalidone is not recommended due to its potential adverse effects during pregnancy, including electrolyte imbalances and possible fetal or neonatal complications.

 

Option C) Switch to atenolol. Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is generally avoided in pregnancy when possible, especially in the first trimester, due to concerns about fetal growth restriction and other adverse neonatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize that when managing chronic hypertension in a woman planning pregnancy, it is important to use antihypertensive medications that are considered safe during pregnancy. Extended-release nifedipine is a suitable option due to its safety profile in pregnancy, while medications like chlorthalidone and spironolactone should be avoided due to potential risks to the fetus.

choices.text: The diagnosis is a classic case of angina pectoris
The afferent pain fibres enter the spinal cord via the posterior roots of the upper four thoracic spinal nerves
Superficial cardiac plexus is contributed by cardiac branch from inferior cervical ganglion of left sympathetic trunk and left vagus nerve
Deep cardiac plexus is situated in front of bifurcation of trachea

questions.text: A 72-year-old man felt heaviness in his chest while digging in his garden. He had similar episodes like this in the past few months. He found that the discomfort disappeared with rest after about 5 minutes. He visited the emergency department because this time, the chest discomfort had occurred with much less exertion. Which of the following comment concerning this case is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial cardiac plexus is contributed by cardiac branch from inferior cervical ganglion of left sympathetic trunk and left vagus nerve

 

  • Superficial cardiac plexus is formed by the cardiac branch from the superior cervical ganglion of left sympathetic trunk and lower cervical branch of left vagus nerve.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) The diagnosis is a classic case of angina pectoris. Preganglionic fibres arise from T1-T5 spinal segments.

 

Option B) The afferent pain fibres enter the spinal cord via the posterior roots of the upper four thoracic spinal nerves. Deep cardiac plexus lies in front of tracheal bifurcation behind the arch of the aorta.

 

Option D) Deep cardiac plexus is situated in front of bifurcation of trachea. Deep cardiac plexus is formed by cardiac branches of superior, middle and inferior cervical ganglia and upper four to five thoracic ganglia of both sympathetic trunks and superior cervical cardiac branch of left vagus, cardiac branches of right vagus and recurrent laryngeal nerves.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy, 41st edition, page no. 997

questions.text: A laboratory technician is processing various bacterial cultures from a series of clinical samples. One particular sample from a catheter site infection demonstrates a striking red pigment on the culture media after incubation. The attending microbiologist decides to use this opportunity to quiz the technician on the possible identity of the bacterium. Which of the following bacteria is known for producing a red pigment and is likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratia marcescens

 

  • Serratia marcescens is a gram-negative bacterium known for producing a characteristic red pigment, especially when cultured at room temperature. This pigment is called prodigiosin and can be a useful clue in identifying this organism in the laboratory.

 

 

Serratia on Nutrient Agar

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Escherichia coli does not typically produce a red pigment.

 

Option B) Bordetella Para pertussis is known for causing whooping cough and does not produce a red pigment.

 

Option C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa can produce various pigments, typically green-blue, not red.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serratia marcescens → characteristic production of a red pigment, prodigiosin, on culture media.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over several months to years and is now associated with dysphagia. On physical examination, a hard, woody thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues was noticed. How will you investigate further?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open biopsy

 

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis, which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy.
  • FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.
  • Open biopsy is considered the definitive method for diagnosing Riedel’s thyroiditis because it allows for the examination of the fibrous tissue that replaces normal thyroid tissue, which is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT can be useful in evaluating the extent of a thyroid mass, its effects on surrounding structures, and any possible involvement of other tissues. However, this will be done after confirming diagnosis on biopsy.

 

Option B) Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC). FNAC is a common diagnostic procedure for thyroid nodules to assess the nature of the cells within the nodule. However, in the case of Riedel’s thyroiditis, the gland is fibrous and hard, making FNAC difficult and often non-diagnostic because it cannot adequately sample the fibrous tissue.

 

Option D) Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Scan. An RAI scan is used to evaluate the function of thyroid tissue by observing how the gland takes up iodine. It is useful in the diagnosis of conditions like Graves' disease or to evaluate thyroid nodules' function. However, it would not be useful in diagnosing Riedel’s thyroiditis because it does not provide information on the fibrous nature of the gland.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male is posted for a surgery, which is likely to last for 4-6 hours. The best inhalational agent of choice for maintenance of anesthesia in such a case is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a recently developed, fluorinated congener of isoflurane which is quiet safe like isoflurane.
  • It can serve as a good alternative to isoflurane for routine surgery as well as prolonged operations (here, operation is long and lasts for 4-6 hrs).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Methoxyflurane.

 

  • It is highly nephrotoxic and this limits its use.
  • In old patients, the G.F.R. is already low, so any nephrotoxic agent should be avoided.

 

Option B) Ether. Ether was very popular in the past but it is not used now because of its inflammable and unpleasant properties.

 

Option C) Trichlorethylene. It forms explosive mixtures and should not be used in closed circuit.

 

Educational objective:

 

PROPERTIES OF DESFLURANE

 

  • No renal and hepatic toxicity, has no arrythmogenic action.
  • Coronary circulation is maintained.
  • Very low solubility in blood and tissues because of which, induction and recovery are very fast.
  • Agent of choice for induction of anaesthesia in Geriatric patients → Etomidate, Thiopentone
  • Inhalational agent of choice for maintenance of anaesthesia in Geriatric patient → Isoflurane

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after his parents found a dark red stool in his diaper. He has been eating and drinking well but seems more tired than usual. The family lives on a ranch, raising cattle and goats. Temperature is 37⁰C (98.6⁰F). Examination shows a pale, cooperative boy. The abdomen is soft, non-distended, non-tender, and without masses. There are no anal fissures or haemorrhoids. A fecal occult blood test is positive. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

 

Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Technetium-99m pertechnate scan

 


 

  • This patient has painless dark red stool (gastrointestinal bleed) concerning for a Meckel diverticulum, the most common gastrointestinal congenital anomaly. 
  • Meckel diverticulum results from a partial remnant of the fetal vitelline duct, an embryologic structure that typically obliterates in the first trimester. 
  • A Meckel diverticulum may contain ectopic gastric mucosa (or, less commonly, pancreatic tissue), which secretes hydrochloric acid. 
  • Acidity can cause surrounding small-bowel ulceration and subsequent bleeding, which may lead to pallor and anaemia if chronic, as in this case. 
  • Stools can range in colour from dark red or maroon to black depending on colonic transit time; the latter is more common in adults. 
  • Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and vomiting are uncommon.
  • The best diagnostic test is a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan (Meckel scan), which shows increased uptake of technetium-99m by gastric mucosa and therefore, identifies ectopic gastric tissue. 
  • This test is non-invasive, highly sensitive and specific, and emits little radiation. 
  • In symptomatic patients, surgical resection is necessary to prevent further bleeding or other complications (e.g., intussusception, obstruction).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Abdominal CT scan. CT scans cannot reliably differentiate the diverticulum from other loops of bowel.

 

Option B) Abdominal ultrasound. Meckel diverticulum is a potential lead point for intussusception, which classically presents as severe, intermittent abdominal pain with or without hematochezia. Workup of intussusception includes abdominal ultrasonography and/or diagnostic and therapeutic air enema. This patient has no pain, making intussusception unlikely.

 

Option D) Upper GI endoscopy is often performed for upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which presents with hematemesis and melena (black, sticky stools), neither of which are seen in this patient.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Meckel diverticulum often presents in young toddlers as painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding without abdominal pain, diarrhoea, or vomiting. 
  • Diagnosis is with a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan, which can identify ectopic gastric mucosa.

choices.text: Loss of elasticity of skin

questions.text: You are a resident performing a post-mortem examination under the supervision of the medical examiner. The body of a recently deceased individual shows several physiological changes. As part of your training, you are asked to identify the findings that are not typically associated with the early post-mortem period. Which of the following is not considered an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of voluntary power

 

  • Loss of voluntary power is the immediate/earliest sign of death.
  • They are found in cases of prolonged fainting attack, vagal inhibitory phenomenon, epilepsy, trance, catalepsy, narcosis, electrocution, etc.
  • Forensic taphonomy is the interdisciplinary study and interpretation of post-mortem processes of human remains in the dispositional context, i.e., the history of changes of a body following death.
  • A knowledge of the signs of death help to differentiate death from suspended animation.
  • The changes which take place may be helpful in estimation of the approximate time of death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Corneal opacity (early sign) can occur shortly after death due to dehydration of the corneal epithelium. The opacity is due to drying and is delayed for about two hours if the lids are closed after death. If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled (artefact).

 

 

Tache Noire

 

Option B) Loss of elasticity of skin (early sign). Skin becomes pale and ashy-white and loses elasticity within a few minutes of death. The lips appear dark-red to black, dry and hard due to drying.

 

Option D) Post-mortem cooling/Algor mortis (early sign) refers to the body cooling down to match the ambient temperature after death, which begins as soon as circulatory and respiratory functions cease. Rate of cooling is 0.4 to 0.6°C per hour for next 12 to 16 hours after death. In tropical climates, the heat loss is roughly 0.4 to 0.6°C and in temperate countries, it is 1°C per hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs of death appear in the following order:

choices.text: Copper accumulation in the basal ganglia
Gliosis of the caudate nucleus
Loss of pigmentation in substantia nigra

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of the gradual onset of involuntary limb and facial movements, mood swings, and trouble with his memory. He says that his father displayed similar symptoms when he was in his 40s. Which of the following changes would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gliosis of the caudate nucleus

 

  • Gliosis is a process of glial cell proliferation in response to brain injury or neurodegeneration.
  • In Huntington's disease, there is characteristic atrophy and gliosis of the caudate nucleus and other basal ganglia structures, which correlates with the symptoms described.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Accumulation of neuritic plaques. This finding is characteristic of Alzheimer's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting memory and cognitive functions. While the patient has memory issues, the presence of involuntary movements and the described family history point more towards Huntington's disease.

 

Option B) Copper accumulation in the basal ganglia. This is indicative of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism, leading to copper deposition in various tissues, including the liver and brain. Wilson's disease can cause neurological and psychiatric symptoms, but the specific features and family history described are more consistent with Huntington's disease.

 

Option D) Loss of pigmentation in substantia nigra. This is seen in Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor, and postural instability. The clinical presentation of the patient, particularly the type of involuntary movements and the family history, does not primarily suggest Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical presentation and associated neuropathological changes of Huntington's disease. Huntington's disease typically presents with a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms and is often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The characteristic neuropathological change is atrophy and gliosis of the caudate nucleus and other parts of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic anemia presents with persistent fatigue despite adhering to prescribed iron supplementation. He reports regularly taking oral iron supplements due to iron-deficiency anemia diagnosed a year ago. The patient discloses consuming iron supplements along with meals rich in vitamin C. Which mechanism of cellular transport, crucial for ingesting dissolved iron particles, particularly relevant in intestinal absorption, is primarily responsible in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pinocytosis

 

  • Cellular process involving the uptake of dissolved substances and fluids by the cell through invagination of the cell membrane, important for absorbing particles in solution.
  • Also called as cell drinking – the ingested substances are in solution – vesicles formed here are smaller in size compared to phagocytosis.
  • The ingested particles are in solution in Pinocytosis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Exocytosis. The content of the vesicles are discharged extracellularly. Cellular process releasing substances from the cell by fusing vesicles with the cell membrane, often seen in secretion of hormones or neurotransmitters. Endocytosis – reverse of exocytosis – ingestion of substances.

 

Option C) Apoptosis. Programmed cell death, essential for maintaining tissue homeostasis by eliminating unwanted or damaged cells, regulated by specific cellular signaling pathways.

 

Option D) Phagocytosis. Cellular process where large particles, such as pathogens or cell debris, are engulfed and digested by specialized cells like macrophages or neutrophils as part of the immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this scenario is to understand that in the context of intestinal absorption, pinocytosis is the mode of cellular transport responsible for ingesting dissolved particles, such as iron ions in solution.
  • This process allows cells to engulf extracellular fluid and its dissolved substances, including nutrients like iron, to facilitate their uptake and utilization in the body

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 46

choices.text: The external opening is in upper half of anterior sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle
The internal opening is in front of posterior tonsillar pillar
The tract passes above carotid artery bifurcation
Treatment is complete excision of the tract

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about branchial fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The external opening is in upper half of anterior sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle

 

  • This statement is incorrect.
  • The external orifice of a branchial fistula is typically found in the lower third of the neck along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, not the upper half.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) The internal opening is in front of posterior tonsillar pillar. This is correct. The internal orifice of a second branchial fistula usually opens internally on the lateral pharyngeal wall, anterior to the posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

Option C) The tract passes above carotid artery bifurcation. This is also correct. The tract of a second branchial fistula typically passes between the internal and external carotid arteries, above the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.

 

Option D) Treat is complete excision of the tract. This is correct. The standard treatment for a branchial fistula is complete surgical excision of the tract to prevent recurrence and resolve the symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incorrect statement about branchial fistula is that the external opening is in the upper half of the anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle; in reality, it is typically located in the lower third of the neck along the anterior border of the muscle (junction of middle and lower third).
  • Complete excision of the tract is necessary for treatment to avoid recurrence.

choices.text: IgM antibodies to B. burgdorferi

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician’s office with a six-month history of low back pain and stiffness that wakes him up during the night and is worst in the morning. The patient was diagnosed with bilateral sacroiliitis four months ago because of his tenderness to percussion of the sacroiliac joints and pain on springing the pelvis up. He has severe limitation of motion of his lumbar spine. Laboratory tests are most likely to be positive for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human leukocyte antigen B27

 

  • HLA-B27 is a genetic marker associated with an increased risk of developing certain autoimmune disorders, including ankylosing spondylitis, which is a type of spondyloarthropathy.
  • The presence of HLA-B27 is highly suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis in patients with symptoms like those described.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Antinuclear antibodies (ANA). ANA are most commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other connective tissue diseases. While ANA can be positive in a wide range of autoimmune diseases, they are not specifically associated with spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option (C) Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). ANCA are most commonly associated with vasculitides, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) and microscopic polyangiitis. They are not typically associated with spondyloarthropathies.

 

Option D) IgM antibodies to B. burgdorferi. These antibodies would indicate exposure to Borrelia burgdorferi, the bacterium that causes Lyme disease. Lyme disease can cause a variety of symptoms, including arthritis, but the clinical presentation described does not specifically suggest Lyme disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the clinical features and associated laboratory findings of ankylosing spondylitis, a type of spondyloarthropathy. Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents with chronic low back pain and stiffness that improves with exercise but not with rest, and it is often associated with HLA-B27 positivity. Understanding the association between HLA-B27 and ankylosing spondylitis is crucial for the diagnosis and management of patients presenting with suggestive clinical features.

questions.text: An obese diabetic patient was on metformin monotherapy, but his sugar levels were not well controlled. He is allergic to sulfa drugs and does not comply with injectable drugs. He has a history of pancreatitis, and family history of bladder carcinoma. In view of the raised glucose levels, you wish to add another anti-diabetic drug. Which one would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

  • The answer to this question can be known by ruling out three options.
    • Liraglutide is an injectable drug (name ends with tide), so cannot be the answer.
    • Sitagliptin can cause pancreatitis, so would not be preferred in a patient with history of pancreatitis.
    • Pioglitazone increases the risk of urinary bladder carcinoma, therefore contra-indicated in patients with increased risk of this cancer (in this patient, there is family history).
    • So, by ruling out, canagliflozin becomes the answer to this question.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Essure

 

  • Essure is a permanent intratubal implant and a non-surgical transcervical sterilization procedure for women, not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation.
  • Another type of laparoscopic ligation method is by using the Falope rings (which is the GOI guidelines) and the Filshie clip.

 

Other Options:

 

Pomeroy, Parkland and Irving are all techniques of open (laparotomy) sterilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • This is the Essure device which is a permanent female sterilization method.
  • The device is introduced hysteroscopically.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is diagnosed with a squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung. While performing a pneumonectomy, the thoracic surgeon notes that the hilar lymph nodes are small, 0.5 to 1.0 cm in size, and jet black in colour throughout. The microscopic appearance of one lymph node is seen here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this lymph node?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracosis

 

  • Anthracosis, also known as coal worker's pneumoconiosis or black lung disease, is characterized by the deposition of black carbon particles (from coal dust or environmental pollution) in the lungs and nearby lymph nodes.
  • This condition can lead to the black discoloration of lymph nodes, which is consistent with the description provided.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Lipochrome deposition. Lipochrome is a pigment that is typically yellow or brownish in colour and is not associated with black discoloration of lymph nodes.

 

Option C) Hemosiderosis. Hemosiderosis is the accumulation of hemosiderin, an iron storage complex, within tissues. It can lead to brown discoloration but is not typically associated with black discoloration of lymph nodes.

 

Option D) Accumulation of melanin. Melanin is a pigment responsible for the color of the skin, hair, and eyes. Accumulation of melanin is not typically seen in lymph nodes and would not result in the described appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  
  • Anthracosis is the deposition of black carbon particles in the lungs and nearby lymph nodes, leading to black discoloration.
  • It is often associated with exposure to coal dust or environmental pollution.
  • This condition is important to recognize in occupational and environmental medicine and can mimic other conditions such as lung cancer on imaging.

choices.text: CT scan of the chest
Pulmonary function tests

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnoea for 10 days. The chest pain is bilateral, dull, persistent, and not worsened by exertion. The patient's medical history is significant for a normal spontaneous vaginal delivery 3 months ago, after which she had frequent episodes of dark, bloody vaginal discharge. The most recent bleeding episode was 6 days ago. The patient has no fever, chills, hemoptysis, orthopnea, or leg pain. Temperature is 37.5⁰C (99.5⁰F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min. BMI is 26.2 kg/m². Physical examination reveals bilaterally clear lungs. The extremities are warm and well perfused. There is no peripheral edema. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus, a closed cervix, and minimal dark blood in the vagina. Complete blood count and serum electrolytes are within normal limits. Chest x-rays reveal multiple bilateral infiltrates of various shapes. Which of the following would be most helpful in establishing this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quantitative β-hCG test

 

  • The likely diagnosis is a choriocarcinoma with lung metastases.
  • Choriocarcinoma can occur even after a normal delivery and this is associated with a worse prognosis.
  • Choriocarcinoma produces high levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), and a quantitative β-hCG test can help establish the diagnosis by detecting elevated levels of this hormone, which are indicative of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) CT scan of the chest. While a CT scan could provide more detailed imaging of the lung infiltrates and might be useful in assessing the extent of the disease, it would not be as definitive for diagnosing choriocarcinoma as measuring β-hCG levels.

 

Option B) Echocardiogram. An echocardiogram assesses heart function and structure and could be useful if there was suspicion of heart involvement or if cardiac symptoms were present. However, it would not directly assist in diagnosing choriocarcinoma.

 

Option C) Pulmonary function tests. These tests measure how well the lungs work but would not be diagnostic for choriocarcinoma. They could provide information on the impact of the lung infiltrates on lung function but would not identify the underlying cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational objective is to recognize the importance of measuring β-hCG levels in the evaluation of a patient with suspected gestational trophoblastic disease, such as choriocarcinoma, especially when presenting with symptoms consistent with metastasis. Elevated β-hCG levels are a hallmark of trophoblastic diseases and can aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of treatment response.

choices.text: Curved Mayo Scissors

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in the second stage of labor. The obstetrician determines that an episiotomy is necessary to facilitate the delivery of the baby's head. When performing an episiotomy, which of the following instruments is commonly used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Braun-Stadler scissors

 

  • An episiotomy is given by a Braun-Stadler Episiotomy Scissors which looks like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • This is a scissors that is characteristically angulated in the middle and very easy to identify.
  • The inside blade is guided by 2 fingers so as to avoid inadvertent injury to the fetus.
  • Episiotomy should NOT be given routinely; rather restrictively in conditions like:
    • Macrosomia
    • Assisted breech delivery
    • Use of instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia
    • Rigid perineum
  • The layers cut in an episiotomy from inside out are:
    • Vaginal mucosa
    • Muscle (superficial and deep transverse perinei, Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani)
    • Perineal skin
  • An episiotomy is a type of 2nd degree perineal tear

questions.text: Which of these intra-venous therapies is preferred while performing damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blood products
