  • Blood products, including packed red blood cells, plasma, and platelets, are the preferred choice in damage control resuscitation (DCR) because they provide essential clotting factors, maintain oxygen-carrying capacity, and help avoid dilutional coagulopathy.

 

Let's evaluate all the options to determine the preferred intravenous therapy while performing damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage:

 

Option A) Ringer’s Lactate. Ringer's Lactate is a crystalloid solution used for fluid resuscitation. While it can be used in the initial management of hemorrhagic shock, it does not contain clotting factors or carry oxygen and can lead to dilutional coagulopathy if used excessively.

 

Option B) Normal Saline. Normal Saline is another crystalloid solution. Similar to Ringer’s Lactate, it can be used for initial volume expansion but is associated with hyperchloremic acidosis and does not contain blood clotting factors or oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option C) Colloids. Colloids, such as hydroxyethyl starch, are sometimes used for volume expansion, but they can interfere with hemostasis and do not provide oxygen-carrying capacity or clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage, the preferred intravenous therapy is blood products, as they help maintain hemostasis, oxygenation, and coagulation without causing dilutional coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of cystic fibrosis presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increased sputum production, fever, and a new onset of left lower lobe crackles on auscultation. His sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following antibiotics would be most appropriate to treat this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piperacillin

 

  • Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum, beta-lactam antibiotic known for its efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is an important consideration in patients with cystic fibrosis who are at increased risk for this infection.
  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of a pulmonary exacerbation of cystic fibrosis due to Pseudomonas, and piperacillin, often in combination with a beta-lactamase inhibitor like tazobactam, is a first-line treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Cephalexin. While effective against many gram-positive organisms, it does not have the antipseudomonal activity needed to treat Pseudomonas infections.

 

Option B) Cloxacillin. This is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin used to treat infections caused by penicillin-resistant staphylococcal species, not Pseudomonas.

 

Option D) Dicloxacillin. Similar to cloxacillin, dicloxacillin is used for penicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and does not cover Pseudomonas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Piperacillin, broad-spectrum, beta-lactam antibiotics is the optimal choice for treating a pulmonary exacerbation of cystic fibrosis, particularly when Pseudomonas aeruginosa is suspected.
  • Piperacillin is often paired with a beta-lactamase inhibitor like tazobactam to enhance its efficacy.

choices.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag
Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag
Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
Pour 2% Lysol on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

questions.text: In a hospital setting, a known HIV positive patient underwent abdominal surgery and was subsequently admitted to an isolation ward. The day after the surgery, a resident doctor changed the patient's dressing and found it heavily soaked in blood. Considering the need for proper disposal of contaminated medical waste, especially in the context of an HIV positive patient, what is the most appropriate method for discarding the blood-soaked dressing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag

 

  • The correct protocol for discarding blood-soaked dressing, especially from an HIV positive patient, involves decontamination followed by incineration.
  • Pouring 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material effectively decontaminates it by killing pathogens, including HIV.
  • After decontamination, the dressing should be placed in an appropriate medical waste bag designated for incineration, ensuring safe and effective disposal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag. 5% hypochlorite is a stronger concentration than necessary for standard decontamination and can be corrosive.

 

Option C) Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration. This method skips the crucial step of decontaminating the dressing, which is necessary for safety.

 

Option D) Pour 2% Lysol on the dressing material and send it for incineration in an appropriate bag. While Lysol is a disinfectant, 1% hypochlorite is the standard and recommended decontamination solution for blood-soaked materials in healthcare settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • All HIV infected material, i.e. gauge pieces, bandages, cotton swabs, blood units, blood have to be incinerated.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus type 1
Varicella zoster virus

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office due to several days of right ear pain. This morning she had 2 episodes of dizziness and almost fell. The patient is currently taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for an uncomplicated urinary tract infection. She has had no subjective fever, vision loss, or headaches. Temperature is 37⁰C (98.6⁰F), blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Ear examination reveals several erythematous vesicles in the right external auditory canal with no drainage. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact. There is mild right-sided facial droop. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella zoster virus

 

  • This patient with a vesicular ear rash and facial droop likely has herpes zoster oticus (Ramsay Hunt syndrome).
  • This condition is caused by the reactivation of varicella zoster virus from the geniculate ganglion, disrupting motors fibres of cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) with subsequent spread to cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve).
  • The 2 defining manifestations are a painful, erythematous, vesicular rash on the auditory canal or auricle and ipsilateral facial paralysis.
  • Many patients also develop vestibular (e.g., vertigo, nausea/vomiting), hearing, and taste disturbances, but systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) are rare (<20%).
  • Treatment with an antiviral medication (e.g., valacyclovir) may speed resolution and limit adverse outcomes.
  • However, many patients are left with residual facial muscle weakness or paralysis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Borrelia burgdorferi. Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, and early disseminated Lyme disease can be associated with facial nerve palsy (~8% of cases). However, the rash of Lyme disease is erythema migrans, a slowly spreading erythematous lesion with central clearing. Vesicular lesions would be atypical.

 

Option B) Herpes simplex virus type 1. The reactivation of herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 is the leading cause of Bell’s palsy (acute-onset, unilateral facial paralysis). However, HSV usually causes vesicular lesions on the oral mucosa, not the auditory canal. The presence of ear lesions makes varicella zoster reactivation far more likely.

 

Option C) Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Although Stevens-Johnson syndrome is frequently associated with the use of antibacterial sulfonamides (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). This illness is usually marked by high fever; a flu-like prodrome; hemorrhagic oral/ocular lesions; and an erythematous, macular rash with a purpuric centre.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster oticus (Ramsay Hunt syndrome) is caused by the reactivation of varicella zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion, disrupting cranial nerve VII motor fibres, with subsequent spread to cranial nerve VIII.
  • Primary manifestations include a painful, erythematous, vesicular rash on the auditory canal or auricle and ipsilateral facial paralysis.

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), a healthcare team is caring for a preterm infant whose mother is unable to produce breast milk. The team is considering the best alternative feeding options for the infant to ensure proper nutrition and development. What is the most suitable feeding option for a preterm baby in the absence of maternal breast milk?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Donor mother’s milk

 

  • Donor mother's milk is the preferred alternative for feeding a preterm baby when the mother's own breast milk is unavailable.
  • It provides the necessary nutrients and immunological protection that are crucial for the growth and development of preterm infants.
  • Human milk banks screen and pasteurize donated milk to ensure safety and quality, making it a suitable choice for preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Preterm formula. While preterm formulas are designed to meet the specific nutritional needs of preterm infants, human milk is generally preferred for its immunological and developmental benefits.

 

Option C) Cow’s milk. Cow's milk is not recommended for infants, especially preterm babies, due to its inappropriate nutrient composition and potential for causing intestinal irritation and allergic reactions.

 

Option D) Standard term formula. Standard formulas are designed for full-term infants and may not meet the unique nutritional needs of preterm babies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If a mother’s own breast milk is not available, the second choice should be donor breast milk.
  • Studies have indicated that donor breast milk has short and long-term benefits as compared to preterm formula (WHO).

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a medical history of cancer presents with a two-week history of constant and severe headaches that are most severe when he wakes up in the morning. He also notes changes in vision associated with the headaches. Physical examination shows a healing ecchymotic lesion on the right forearm, papilledema in the left eye, a right-sided pronator drift, and weakness of the right arm. The diagnosis of an intracranial hemorrhage is confirmed with CT of the head. Which of the following cancers is most likely to have resulted in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Melanoma

 

  • Melanoma is known for its high propensity to metastasize to the brain, and when it does, it can often lead to hemorrhagic metastases, which can present with the acute neurological symptoms described.
  • Melanoma metastases have a higher likelihood of hemorrhage compared to many other types of cancer metastases to the brain.
  • Brain metastases from melanoma are more likely to be hemorrhagic, which can lead to the acute neurological symptoms and signs observed in this patient.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Angiosarcoma. This is a rare cancer that arises from the lining of blood vessels and can occur in any area of the body. While angiosarcomas can metastasize, they are less commonly associated with brain metastases compared to melanoma.

 

Option B) Basal cell carcinoma. This is the most common type of skin cancer, characterized by its slow growth and minimal potential for metastasis. Basal cell carcinoma very rarely metastasizes, and brain metastasis is exceedingly uncommon.

 

Option C) Colorectal carcinoma. While colorectal cancer can metastasize to the liver and lungs more frequently, it is less commonly associated with brain metastases compared to melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to recognize the potential for certain cancers, particularly melanoma, to metastasize to the brain and cause hemorrhagic metastases, leading to acute neurological symptoms. Understanding the patterns of cancer metastasis is crucial for the diagnosis and management of patients presenting with neurological symptoms and a history of cancer.

questions.text: A 56-year-old previously healthy physician notices that his eyes are yellow and he has been losing weight. On physical examination, the patient has jaundice and scleral icterus with a palpable gall bladder lump. Transcutaneous ultrasound of the abdomen demonstrates biliary ductal dilation without gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Computed tomography (CT) scan

 

  • Painless jaundice with weight loss is suspicious for a pancreatic cancer involving the head or uncinate process of the pancreas.
  • A helical contrast-enhanced CT scan is the most appropriate study to evaluate for a pancreatic mass.
  • CT has a specificity of 95% or better with sensitivity exceeding 95% for tumors larger than 2 cm in diameter.
  • An ERCP is helpful in evaluating patients with obstructive jaundice without a detectable mass on CT scan.
  • An MRCP is preferred when CBD stones are suspected, and is not the first step in the evaluation of a patient with a suspected pancreatic mass.
  • EUS is beneficial in local staging of pancreatic masses.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a well-child visit. She was born precipitously at 35 weeks gestation due to preterm labor to a 22-year-old primigravida who did not receive prenatal care. The patient's neonatal course was notable for a 1-week hospital stay due to difficulty feeding. She was hospitalized for bronchiolitis at age of 3 months for 4 days. The patient can crawl but has not begun cruising. She has been babbling and repeating "mama." Height, weight, and head circumference track along the 25th percentile. She is alert and smiling at the examiner and her mother. Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals a white reflex in the left eye and a red reflex in the right. Extraocular movements are intact, and the pupils are equal and reactive to light. The corneal light reflex is symmetric. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

 

  • This patient has leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) concerning for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular tumor of childhood, which occurs due to inactivation of the tumor suppressor gene RB1. 
  • Sporadic retinoblastoma often presents as unilateral disease, whereas inheritable retinoblastoma is more commonly bilateral.
  • Retinoblastoma is typically diagnosed in children age <2 years and should therefore, be suspected in any infant or young child with an absent red reflex. 
  • Other presenting features include strabismus, nystagmus, vision impairment, and ocular inflammation. 
  • Immediate ophthalmologic referral is required for treatment to avoid metastasis to the contralateral eye and the brain. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI of the brain and orbits. 
  • Biopsy is not performed due to risk of tumor seeding.

 

Other options:

 

Options A and B) CMV and Congenital Rubella Syndrome. Cytomegalovirus and rubella are congenital infections contracted in-utero that can cause leukocoria due to cataracts (lens opacification). However, bilateral white pupillary reflexes and abnormalities such as hearing loss and microcephaly would be expected with these conditions.

 

Option C) Retinitis pigmentosa is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive retinal degeneration. Typical presentation includes night blindness, decreased visual acuity, and visual field loss. Cataracts can develop but are very rare in infancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Leukocoria, or white pupillary reflex, in an infant or young child should prompt immediate referral to an ophthalmologist to evaluate for retinoblastoma. 
  • Strabismus and nystagmus are other red flags.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a recent growth spurt of 15 cm (6 in) during the past year. She also has had increasing fatigue and palpitations during this period. Her paternal aunt has a history of palpitations and severe myopia. She is at the 95th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a long, thin face. Ophthalmologic examination shows dislocated lenses. Cardiac examination shows a hyperdynamic precordium with early click and systolic murmur. Echocardiography shows an enlarged aortic root and mitral valve prolapse. Abnormal synthesis of which of the following proteins is the most likely cause of this patient’s disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrillin-1

 

  • Fibrillin-1 is the correct protein associated with Marfan syndrome.
  • Marfan syndrome is primarily caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to abnormal synthesis of fibrillin-1.
  • Fibrillin-1 is a major component of microfibrils in connective tissues, including the aorta, ligaments, and the ciliary zonules that hold the lens in place.
  • Mutations in FBN1 result in the characteristic features of Marfan syndrome, including aortic root enlargement, mitral valve prolapse, dislocated lenses, and long bone overgrowth.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Collagen, type I.

 

  • Collagen type I is the primary structural protein in bone, skin, and tendons.
  • Defects in collagen type I synthesis lead to conditions such as osteogenesis imperfecta, but they are not associated with the features seen in Marfan syndrome, including aortic root enlargement, mitral valve prolapse, and dislocated lenses.

 

Option B) Elastin.

 

  • Elastin is a structural protein that provides elasticity to various tissues, including blood vessels, skin, and ligaments.
  • Defects in elastin synthesis or organization can result in connective tissue disorders such as cutis laxa, but they do not typically cause the characteristic features of Marfan syndrome, including aortic root enlargement, mitral valve prolapse, and dislocated lenses.

 

Option D) Laminin.

 

  • Laminin is a structural protein found in the basement membranes of various tissues.
  • Defects in laminin are associated with different conditions, including muscular dystrophies, but they are not related to the clinical features seen in Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective here is to recognize that Marfan syndrome is primarily caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to abnormal synthesis of fibrillin-1, a major component of microfibrils in connective tissues.
  • Understanding the genetic and structural protein basis of Marfan syndrome is important for diagnosis and management of this connective tissue disorder, which can affect various organ systems.
